LENGTH: 449 words

HEADLINE: Home Resales Keep Up Near-Record Pace

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Sales of previously owned houses rose in September to the third-highest pace on record, evidence that low borrowing costs were attracting buyers and helping sustain the economic expansion.
 The 3.1 percent increase brought sales last month to an annual rate of 6.75 million single-family houses, from 6.55 million in August, the National Association of Realtors said yesterday. The pace in June was a record 6.92 million. The association forecasts that 2004 will be the best year ever for sales. 
 ''Real estate has been and will continue to be a pillar of the economy,'' said James R. Gillespie, president and chief executive of Coldwell Banker Real Estate in Parsippany, N. J. ''There are no concerns for me at all as far as the economy and housing.''
 Declining mortgage rates are driving sales even as rising oil prices and lackluster job growth weigh on the economic expansion. The three hurricanes that pummeled Florida kept sales from rising further, the association said.
 The median forecast called for resales to fall to an annual rate of 6.51 million from a previously reported 6.54 million for August. 
 ''The housing market just refuses to falter,'' said Joel L. Naroff, president of Naroff Economic Advisors in Holland, Pa. ''With mortgage rates quite low, there is little reason to expect demand to drop suddenly.''
 Resales account for 85 percent of the residential real estate market in the United States. Sales were a record 6.1 million last year. The association forecast on Oct. 5 that sales this year would climb to an annual rate of 6.49 million before easing back.
 In a speech yesterday at a conference of mortgage bankers in San Francisco, Franklin Raines, the chief executive of Fannie Mae, warned that housing prices may be rising too fast in some markets.
 Gains in some areas of the country are being fueled in part by investor demand, Mr. Raines said. Fannie Mae is the biggest provider of mortgage financing in the United States.
 ''I've spent a lot of time over the past few years arguing that there is no 'housing bubble,''' Mr. Raines said. ''And nationally, that's still true. But we are seeing investor-driven price increases in certain markets, some within this region. And these markets could soften as investor demand wanes, as it inevitably does.''
 An index of housing prices is up 9 percent in the second quarter from a year before, the fastest four-quarter increase since 1979, Mr. Raines said. The difference, he said, is that in 1979 the rate of inflation was 11 percent, while today it is 2.4 percent.
 ''The data indicate that this price increase is being fueled in part by a big increase in investor demand over the past three quarters,'' Mr. Raines said.

HEADLINE: In His Own Words

 BODY:

Senator John Kerry
Remarks on Saturday in Pueblo, Colo.
 ''We need a president, my friends, who asks you to join together in voting not for your fears, but voting for your hopes for this country. That's what this is about.
 Let me tell you, it's time for us to join together to unite America, to come together around the ideals and hopes and aspirations of the American people, not the fears. This president keeps going around the country trying to scare people. He talks about only one thing; the only thing he wants to talk about is terror, the war on terror, national security. 
 Here's what we need in America: we need a president of the United States who can do more than one thing at the same time. 
 I know that as a country, whenever we had possibilities, we're the people who reach for the possibilities, that's who we are as Americans. If people had told you years ago, 'Oh, don't bother looking for a polio vaccine; you're giving people false hope. Don't bother looking for smallpox vaccine; you're giving people false hope' -- 
 Well, let me tell you something, I don't believe it's a false hope to look for those cures, and that's why I will be the president who opens up stem cell research for America so we can do what we need to do.
 Five million Americans have lost their health care under George Bush, and he's done nothing about it. Forty-five million Americans have no health care, but when I'm president, we're going to make sure, No.1 , every child in America will be covered automatically: Day1, you go to school, you're covered. You go to day care; you're covered. You've got health care. No.2, we're going to make it possible for every single American that wants to, to buy in to the same health care plan senators and congressmen give themselves 
 I pledge to you that I'm going to reduce that deficit. Over the span of four years, we're going to cut it in half in the first four years Every program I've laid out to America I've shown how I'm going to pay for it, and if we can't pay for it, we're not going to do it. It's that simple, folks. We're going to be responsible.
 We're going to restore America's future. This administration is stealing that future, and worse. He is quoted in last week's papers as saying he's going to move rapidly to privatize Social Security. Well, let me make it very clear to everybody here: I will not privatize Social Security, I will not cut the benefits, I will not raise the retirement age; I will strengthen it by strengthening the American economy and restoring fiscal responsibility.''

SECTION: Section G; Column 1; Voter Guide 2004; THE ISSUES; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 2245 words

HEADLINE: Fact Check

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

 BODY:

Yes, He Said That, But What He Really Meant Was . . .
 This fall and especially after the debates, The Times has analyzed the accuracy of statements made by the presidential candidates. Here are highlights of that coverage on some of the most important issues of the campaign.

IRAQ
 More than a dozen times in the first debate on Oct. 1, President Bush accused Senator John Kerry of continually shifting positions on Iraq. 
 A review of Mr. Kerry's public statements found that his position had actually been quite consistent. But as the politics changed, Mr. Kerry repeatedly changed his emphasis. News accounts reflected what he was emphasizing at the time. And Mr. Kerry was often unclear in expressing his views. 
 On Oct. 9, 2002, Mr. Kerry was planning to run for president, but had not yet announced his candidacy. Before he voted to give Mr. Bush the authority to use force against Saddam Hussein in Iraq, he declared on the Senate floor: ''I will support a multilateral effort to disarm him by force, if we ever exhaust those other options, as the president has promised, but I will not support a unilateral U.S. war against Iraq unless that threat is imminent and the multilateral effort has not proven possible under any circumstances.''
 That is essentially his position today. But look at what Mr. Kerry has said in the meantime: 
 In May 2003, two months after the United States invaded Iraq and routed Mr. Hussein's army, Mr. Kerry was the presumed front-runner for the Democratic nomination. Howard Dean, the former governor of Vermont, from the antiwar wing of the party, was not yet regarded as a serious threat. In a nine-candidate debate in Columbia, S.C., that month, Mr. Kerry declared: ''I would have preferred if we had given diplomacy a greater opportunity, but I think it was the right decision to disarm Saddam Hussein. And when the president made the decision, I supported him, and I support the fact that we did disarm him.'' 
 By October 2003, Dr. Dean had begun to emerge as a strong candidate and it had become clear that no unconventional weapons would be found in Iraq. Mr. Kerry asserted that month on the ABC News program ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos'': ''The president and his advisers did not do almost anything correctly in the walk-up to the war. They rushed to war. They were intent on going to war. They did not give legitimacy to the inspections. We could have still been doing inspections even today.'' 
Five days later, Mr. Kerry voted against a Republican bill to provide $87 billion more to support American troops and to pay reconstruction costs in Iraq and Afghanistan. Before that vote, he voted for a version of the measure Mr. Bush threatened to veto, a version that would have raised the $87 billion by repealing tax cuts for Americans with annual incomes of more than $200,000.
 By March, Mr. Kerry had won the early contests, essentially clinching the nomination. On March 16, he explained his vote against the $87 billion for the troops by saying, in a comment Mr. Bush has repeatedly ridiculed, ''I actually did vote for the $87 billion before I voted against it.'' 
 On Aug. 9, following the Democratic convention, Mr. Kerry told reporters during a trip to the Grand Canyon that he ''would have voted for the authority'' for Mr. Bush to use troops in Iraq even if he had known that unconventional weapons would not be found and that no close connection existed between Iraq and Al Qaeda. 
 This was the first time Mr. Kerry had expressed that view, and reports emphasized it. Many accounts, especially those on television, did not include his further explanation that ''it's the right authority for a president to have'' and that, referring to subsequent events in Iraq, he ''would have done this very differently from the way President Bush has.'' 
 Then last month on the radio program ''Imus in the Morning,'' the host, Don Imus, asked Mr. Kerry, ''Do you think there are any circumstances in which we should have gone to war in Iraq?'' Mr. Kerry replied: ''Not under the current circumstances, no. There are none that I see. I voted based on weapons of mass destruction. The president distorted that, and I've said that.'' 
 That was another new point, and nearly all accounts emphasized it. Many did not include the rest of what Mr. Kerry said: ''But I think it was the right vote based on what Saddam Hussein had done, and I think it was the right thing to do to hold him accountable. I've said 100 times, there was a right way to do it and a wrong way to do it. The president chose the wrong way.'' 

COALITION
 Mr. Bush said the war in Iraq was being waged by a large coalition; Mr. Kerry said that the coalition was shrinking and that eight countries had left it. 
 As of this month, 30 foreign countries had joined the United States, but they contribute only about 24,000 troops, with Britain supplying 8,000 of them. The United States has about 138,000 troops in Iraq, and 90 percent of the non-Iraqi casualties have been American. 
 Eight allied countries have withdrawn troops from Iraq since February: the Dominican Republic, Honduras, Nicaragua, Norway, the Philippines, Singapore, Spain and Thailand. 

AL QAEDA
 Mr. Bush's statement in the first debate that 75 percent of Osama bin Laden's ''people have been brought to justice'' is impossible to document. It appears to refer to terrorist leaders, a loosely defined category. 
There is no reliable tally of how many Qaeda operatives ever existed, and the administration has not provided the number who have been captured or killed.

DOMESTIC SECURITY
 Mr. Kerry complained in the first debate that money spent on the war could be better used for police, firefighters and other security measures at home. 
 He said the administration had put ''not one nickel'' into protection for vulnerable tunnels, bridges and subways. 
 That is an exaggeration. 
 Even Democratic critics demanding more spending on rail and transit security and lobbyists for transit systems say the federal government has spent millions of dollars, while local transit authorities have spent more than a billion dollars.
 Mr. Bush's statement that the administration had ''tripled the amount of money we're spending on homeland security to $30 billion a year'' was an 
approximation and embroidered somewhat the rate of growth. It depends in part on what programs are counted, and from what date.
 Money for programs inherited by the new Department of Homeland Security from other agencies has more than doubled since 2001, to about $24 billion in the fiscal year 2004, according to a report in April by the Congressional Budget Office.
 Related programs in other agencies have grown almost as fast, bringing total domestic security spending to about $41 billion, a doubling since 2001.
 Democrats have argued for even faster growth in spending on some of these programs.

IRAQ AND U.N. SANCTIONS
 In the second debate, on Oct. 8, President Bush and Senator Kerry drew contradictory conclusions from the 918-page report issued this month by Charles A. Duelfer, the top American arms inspector in Iraq, and their interpretations did not always accurately reflect the report's findings. 
 After Mr. Kerry said that the Duelfer report had demonstrated that United Nations sanctions against Iraq ''worked,'' Mr. Bush said the report's lesson instead was that it was ''naive and dangerous'' to ''just let the inspectors do their job.'' 
 In fact, that report did not draw a firm conclusion about whether the sanctions and inspections succeeded in disarming Iraq. It said that Saddam Hussein's ''primary goal from 1991 to 2003 was to have U.N. sanctions lifted.'' But it also said that between 2000 and 2001, Iraq ''managed to mitigate many of the effects of sanctions and undermine their international support.'' 
 Mr. Bush referred to findings pointing to how porous the sanctions were and showing Iraq's success between 1991 and 2003 at circumventing the restrictions, primarily through imports of conventional weapons.
 But Mr. Kerry emphasized what he portrayed as the restrictions' bottom-line success, in prompting what Mr. Duelfer said was the fundamental decision that Iraq made after the war in the Persian Gulf in 1991 to set aside its plans for illicit weapons, at least for the time being, to win an end to sanctions. 

JOBS
 Mr. Kerry said in the second debate that Mr. Bush's was the first presidency in 72 years in which the number of jobs had fallen and that the nation had lost 1.6 million jobs since 2000. Mr. Bush said 1.9 million new jobs had been created in the last 13 months. 
 Mr. Kerry's figure for job losses counted only private-sector jobs. More than 1 million government jobs have been created. The total jobs lost has been about 585,000 through last month. 
 Mr. Bush is the first president since Herbert Hoover to have had the number of jobs fall during his term. The nearly 2 million new jobs created in a little more than a year still leaves the administration in the hole.

TAXES AND THE BUDGET
 Mr. Bush said in the third debate that most of the tax reduction in his presidency had gone ''to low- and middle-income Americans.''
 In fact, Internal Revenue Service figures compiled by the Tax Policy Center of the Brookings Institution and the Urban Institute show that half of all the tax cuts in effect this year go to the wealthiest 10 percent of taxpayers, those with incomes above about $112,000.
 One-quarter of the cuts go to the richest 1 percent, those with incomes above about $357,000.
 Mr. Bush also said the cuts were needed ''to get us out of the recession.'' But he proposed the cuts in his last presidential campaign, in 2000, before anyone knew that a recession was at hand, and he justified them by saying the surplus should be returned to the taxpayers. 
 The president said, as he often has elsewhere, that Mr. Kerry had voted for tax increases 98 times. That is probably true. But many, if not most, of those were multiple votes on the same bills or on nonbinding resolutions and motions. Mr. Kerry voted against the tax increase pushed by the president's father in 1990 to reduce the budget deficit. He voted for one large tax increase -- the Clinton bill of 1993, which imposed most of the increases on upper-income payers. Mr. Kerry said Mr. Bush had proposed $3 trillion in new spending, and Mr. Bush said Mr. Kerry had proposed $2 trillion. Neither claim can be proved, because the details of their proposals are so vague.
 Mr. Kerry was correct when he said the budget had a projected $5.6 trillion surplus over 10 years when Mr. Bush took office and now has large deficits for the foreseeable future. 
 But Mr. Kerry was not accurate when he said he had shown ''exactly how'' he intended to pay for all his spending proposals. In fact, he lists as additional revenues such vague promises as closing corporate loopholes and making the government more efficient. 
 The Concord Coalition, a nonpartisan group that seeks deficit reduction, projects that Mr. Bush would cut taxes by $1.2 trillion in the coming decade, while Mr. Kerry would reduce revenues by $498 billion. New spending proposed by Senator Kerry would total $771 billion in the next decade, compared with $82 billion proposed by Mr. Bush.

BETTER OFF, WORSE OFF
 Much of the third debate turned on the question of whether Americans had more money in their pockets as a result of President Bush's policies. 
 Mr. Kerry offered an array of statistics that in his view showed that people were worse off than they were at the beginning of the Bush presidency. 
 Mr. Bush accused his challenger of ''a litany of misstatements'' and held that voters were in better financial shape because of his tax cuts. But, as with the Kerry data, the accuracy of the president's statements is not obvious. 
 The truth seems to be that, after adjustments for inflation, Americans on average may have more money at their disposal. But more people are worse off than are better off. 
 The trick is in the word ''average.'' Average income -- all the income in the country divided by the total number of people -- has gone up because of the large increase in after-tax income enjoyed by the very wealthy. 
 But median income -- the point at which half the people have more and half less -- has dropped.

SOCIAL SECURITY, THE DRAFT
 For weeks, the president attacked Mr. Kerry in ways that the Kerry campaign and outside commentators called distortions. After their last debate, Mr. Kerry began criticizing President Bush on Social Security and the draft in a manner that reached far beyond Mr. Bush's positions. 
 On Social Security, Mr. Kerry maintained that Mr. Bush planned a ''January surprise'' that could cost retirees up to 45 percent of their monthly checks. On the draft, Mr. Kerry said that involuntary extensions and National Guard call-ups amounted to a backdoor draft. He also told The Des Moines Register that there was ''the great potential of the draft'' if Mr. Bush won a second term. 
 Mr. Kerry's implication that people now retired stood to have their benefits cut was not fair. Mr. Bush has promised not to cut the Social Security benefits of current retirees or those nearing retirement age, and no plan under consideration would do that. 
 On the draft, Mr. Bush said flatly in the second debate that he had no plans to reinstate military conscription. There is hardly any political support for a draft, and the Pentagon is very much opposed to one. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS (91%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); US PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS (90%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (90%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (90%); INSPECTIONS (89%); POLITICAL DEBATES (78%); VETO (77%); US PRESIDENTS (77%); PLATFORMS & ISSUES (77%); POLITICS (77%); ELECTIONS (77%); IRAQ WAR (77%); US REPUBLICAN PARTY (76%); ARMIES (74%); GOVERNORS (72%); ARMED FORCES (64%); MILITARY WEAPONS (64%) Presidential Election of 2004; United States Economy; Election Issues

PERSON: SADDAM HUSSEIN (89%); GEORGE W BUSH (79%); JOHN KERRY (79%) David E Rosenbaum; George W (Pres) Bush; John (Sen) Kerry

GEOGRAPHIC: COLUMBIA, SC, USA (79%) SOUTH CAROLINA, USA (79%); VERMONT, USA (79%) IRAQ (94%); UNITED STATES (93%); AFGHANISTAN (79%) Iraq

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 26, 2004
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section G; Column 1; Voter Guide 2004; THE REPUBLICANS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 1742 words

HEADLINE: The Bush Philosophy: Resolute, No Matter What

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
GEORGE W. BUSH ran for president four years ago with a strategy intended to round his edges and soften ideology with personality. He was ''a new kind of Republican,'' a ''uniter not a divider'' and, of course, a ''compassionate conservative,'' to recall a few of the slogans that might have left many Americans not entirely certain of what kind of president they were putting in the Oval Office.
 As he faces the voters this year as an incumbent, Mr. Bush, 58, has assembled a weighty if polarizing record on foreign and domestic policy that leaves no doubt where he stands on the big issues. 
 After the 9/11 terrorist attacks, he carried out a national security strategy built on the conviction that nothing -- certainly not diplomatic niceties -- would stand in the way of trying to protect the American people from Islamic extremism, or the spread of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons. 
 He pushed through Congress four major tax cuts for individuals, hailing them as essential to the recovering economy, and he just signed another tax bill benefiting many corporations. He worked to reduce labor and environmental regulations, saying he could do so without sacrificing worker safety and clean air and water. He backed a proposed constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage, argued in favor of limiting affirmative action and nominated conservatives to the federal courts. 
 Yet Mr. Bush is not always ideologically rigid, with a record also marked by what could be viewed as pragmatism, opportunism or failure. He talks about holding down government spending, but has presided over the biggest expansion of the federal government since the Great Society of the 1960's. 
 He has been an advocate of expanded trade, but he imposed temporary tariffs on imported steel to help steel makers in the battleground states of Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Ohio. He has sought to bring market forces to bear on social welfare programs to hold down the growth in their costs, but enthusiastically signed into law the establishment of a prescription drug benefit for Medicare, the biggest expansion of an entitlement program in decades. 
 In pursuing his agenda with a Republican-led Congress, he has mixed charm, strong-arm politics, intense party discipline and a degree of certitude that has been inspiring to his supporters and maddening to his opponents. On many issues, big and small, his approach often seems binary: yes or no, good or evil, with us or against us. 
 With rare exceptions -- like the 2002 bipartisan education bill that imposed more accountability on schools but also gave them more federal money -- he has pushed for total victory rather than a middle ground. Yet when faced with sure legislative defeat or political setback, he has capitulated and unabashedly claimed victory. Who remembers that Mr. Bush originally opposed the creation of the Homeland Security Department, or the establishment of an independent commission to investigate 9/11?
 He can be impatient, peevish when challenged and, as a national television audience learned during his first debate with Senator John Kerry, he sometimes lets anger manifest itself in a scowl. But he tends to sunny optimism, action over contemplation and instinct over detailed analysis.
 It is not the type of presidency he thought he had won, albeit by the slimmest of margins under the most disputed of circumstances, in 2000. Back then, politics was consumed by issues like the Social Security ''lockbox,'' prosperity seemed a given and wars happened in hard-to-pronounce Balkan towns.
 Mr. Bush has never hesitated to use the powers of his office to the fullest, even before 9/11 transformed him into, as he puts it, ''a war president.'' From the start, he governed as if he had a clear mandate rather a razor-thin victory in which he lost the popular vote but won in the Electoral College, and only after the Supreme Court had ruled in his favor. And while he would be freed in a second term from the constraints of presidential electoral politics, he was hardly timid in pursuing his agenda in his first term.
 If there is an overarching theme to his re-election effort, it is his faith in what he calls ''the transformational power of liberty.'' By that, he means his belief that the long-term task for the United States is to at least plant the seeds of democracy in the Middle East and throughout those regions of the world that could otherwise continue to breed poverty, anger and pools of terrorists.
 Should he take the oath of office again on Jan. 20, it is the pursuit of that goal and its primary prerequisite -- bringing stability to Iraq -- that would surely dominate his second term.
 ''If you count the number of times he said ''free'' or ''freedom'' in relation to Iraq and the Middle East during the debates, you would have to assume his vision of liberating and transforming the Middle East would be at the top of any second-term agenda,'' said James P. Pinkerton, a policy aide in the administrations of Ronald Reagan and the first President Bush. ''His aides will say, ''No one is going to remember what you did on taxes or Social Security. For better or worse, Mr. President, this is who you are.''
 But while Mr. Bush will no doubt be subject to the same forces that lure most second-term presidents to put their energies into foreign policy over domestic issues, he still has ambitious domestic goals.
 He wants to create personal investment accounts within Social Security, a step that would fundamentally alter perhaps the most popular and successful government program. He has called for an overhaul of the tax system, though he has offered no details of what he has in mind. He wants to do more to protect doctors and businesses from lawsuits and to place a cap on what plaintiffs collect, allow more domestic oil and gas drilling, stiffen math and science requirements for high school students and expand tax breaks for the purchase of health insurance.
 With so little trust between the White House and the Democratic leadership, it would be all the more difficult to bring the two sides together on issues that require bipartisan trust, like dealing with the budget deficit. And whichever party controls Congress, there would almost surely be a poisonous atmosphere in confrontations over social issues and the likely nominations of new Supreme Court justices. 
 But that would not be likely to stop him from seeking what he wants. On domestic and foreign policy, Mr. Bush has been willing to take big risks for big payoffs. His agenda and his style have many critics, but his performance as president and as governor of Texas suggests that he is dogged in pursuit of the relatively few goals he decides are paramount.
 There is no assurance, of course, that any amount of tenacity will bring stability, much less full-fledged democracy, to Iraq. Whether to begin disengaging in Iraq and how quickly in the absence of clear progress, if it comes to that, will be questions with profound foreign policy and political implications. 
 Either way, Mr. Bush in a second term would also continue to deal with one unpredictable and hostile nation that already has nuclear weapons, North Korea. He would have to deal with another country that seems intent on acquiring them, Iran, and the prospect that still more countries as well as terrorist groups will try to join the nuclear club.
 The administration's effort to find an accommodation between Israel and the Palestinians has stalled. Relations with France and Germany remain deeply strained, and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain has paid a big price at home for standing shoulder to shoulder with Mr. Bush over Iraq.
 In Mr. Bush's action, especially in dealing with Iraq, his critics see a record of cowboy unilateralism that has eroded whatever moral authority the United States had with the rest of the world. 
 Mr. Bush and his aides say the critics have caricatured his foreign policy. They say he has a strong record of building alliances, addressing problems through diplomacy and respecting the needs and desires of the rest of the world. In dealing with North Korea, they say, he is working with South Korea, Japan, China and Russia. In confronting Iran, he has allowed the European allies to take the lead.
 Yet Mr. Bush's brand of internationalism, by his own account, is limited. ''I'll work with our allies, I'll build coalitions, but I will never turn over our national security decisions to leaders of other countries,'' he says in his stump speech.
 On the home front, Mr. Bush is vulnerable to criticism that his tax cuts have not generated anything close to the numbers of jobs the administration promised. He is, as Mr. Kerry is fond of repeating, the first president since Herbert Hoover to face the voters with a net loss of jobs during his term. In part because of the tax cuts, a huge budget surplus has given way to a substantial deficit. And many other indicators suggest that things have gotten worse rather than better for many Americans. The number of people without health insurance has grown. Poverty levels are up.
 To offset some of the spending increases for the war and measures to protect the nation from terrorism, Mr. Bush has sought to hold down spending on most social welfare programs.
 To listen to the White House, what is remarkable is how effective the tax cuts have been in helping to nurse the economy through a recession, terrorist attacks, war and corporate scandals. ''This economy is moving forward, and we're not going to go back to the days of big government, tax and spend,'' Mr. Bush says in his stump speech, suggesting that Mr. Kerry would give the economy the wrong medicine. Mr. Bush points to hopeful signs like the creation of 1.7 millions jobs in the last year, an unemployment rate that is lower than the average of any of the past several decades and record rates of home ownership.
 The bloodshed in Iraq, the economy's inability to generate jobs in large numbers, the tight presidential race, all have taken some of the swagger out of Mr. Bush, but not his basic self-confidence and optimism. As he prepared two months ago to accept his party's nomination for another term, he was asked how he had changed. He talked first about the presidency rather than himself, made clear his discomfort with introspection and finally settled on resolve as the appropriate characteristic to apply to himself.
 ''So one thing is,'' he said, ''I'm a very determined person.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush greeting Senator John Kerry after the debate on Oct. 13 in Tempe, Ariz. On issues, Mr. Bush reaches out sparingly. (Photo by Doug Mills/The New York Times) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: CONSERVATISM (90%); US REPUBLICAN PARTY (90%); US PRESIDENTS (90%); TAXES & TAXATION (90%); POLITICS (89%); US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT (89%); US PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS (79%); ELECTIONS (78%); PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS (78%); POLITICAL PARTIES (77%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (77%); TERRORIST ATTACKS (74%); NATIONAL SECURITY (74%); TERRORISM (74%); TAX LAW (72%); TAX RELIEF (72%); LEGISLATION (72%); EDUCATION LAW (71%); PUBLIC FINANCE (71%); ENVIRONMENTAL LAW (71%); DEFENSE & MILITARY POLICY (70%); CHEMICAL & BIOLOGICAL WEAPONS (69%); MEDICARE (69%); SPECIAL INVESTIGATIVE FORCES (69%); SEPTEMBER 11 ATTACK (69%); TARIFFS & DUTIES (68%); ECONOMIC RECOVERY (67%); INCOME ASSISTANCE (67%); PHARMACY BENEFITS (66%); MARRIAGE LAW (66%); CONSTITUTIONAL LAW (65%); GAYS & LESBIANS (65%); IRON & STEEL MILLS (62%); PRESCRIPTION DRUG INSURANCE (61%); AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (53%); RELIGION (53%); PRESCRIPTION DRUGS (50%); MARRIAGE (50%); SAME SEX MARRIAGE & UNIONS (50%) Presidential Election of 2004; United States Politics and Government

SECTION: Section C; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 835 words

HEADLINE: European Trade Chief Says Sanctions on U.S. Will End

BYLINE: By PAUL MELLER; Brian Knowlton contributed reporting from Washington for this article.

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Oct. 25 

 BODY:
The European trade commissioner, Pascal Lamy, announced an end to a five-year dispute with the United States on Monday, saying he was lifting $4 billion in sanctions on American products, after President Bush signed a law repealing tax breaks for large American exporters.
 But Mr. Lamy, despite his eagerness to sign off on the dispute that has shadowed a term in office soon to end, said he suspected that Washington had left some of the tax breaks in place.
 Mr. Bush signed the legislation on Friday ending tax breaks that have been worth billions of dollars over the last decade to exporters including Boeing, Microsoft and General Electric, and at the same time adding a range of new tax advantages for corporations. 
 The World Trade Organization, based in Geneva, had found that the tax program, known as the Foreign Sales Corporation, provided illegal subsidies.
 ''I am extremely pleased that this bill now has become law,'' Mr. Lamy said at his final news conference before stepping down from the post at the end of the week, ''and obviously I am very satisfied that our efforts have been rewarded after five years.''
 The United States said in a statement that it welcomed the European Union's action and that it felt sure that nothing more needed to be done to resolve the European complaints.
 The bill, which takes effect at the beginning of 2005, gives American companies two years to wean themselves off the old tax breaks. 
 The legislation allows the United States to give $4 billion, or 80 percent of the amount distributed under the Foreign Sales Corporation program, to American companies next year. In 2006 this will fall to $3 billion, or 60 percent.
 Mr. Lamy, while accepting the transition period, balked at a separate provision in the law that would allow American companies that make products with long delivery times, like Boeing, to continue getting the tax break if they have orders from abroad that were signed before Sept. 17, 2003.
 ''Our intuition is that this isn't in conformity'' with the W.T.O. ruling, Mr. Lamy said. He said that the amount involved was modest compared with the overall tax breaks, but that the provision still posed a problem.
 ''We have been trying to put the F.S.C. to bed for a long time,'' Mr. Lamy added. ''It is now in bed, but we need to just check before the lights go out.''
 A spokesman for the United States trade representative, Richard Mills, said Monday that the Congressional action had eliminated the provisions of the tax code that the W.T.O. found illegally subsidized exports.
 ''We will continue to explain to the E.U. and others how the new law brings the U.S. into compliance,'' he said.
 The task of checking will be handled by Mr. Lamy's successor, Peter Mandelson of Britain, who takes office next week. 
 The first step will be to ask the World Trade Organization to check if the legislation is, indeed, in compliance. This formal process takes 90 days. If the W.T.O. finds that it is not, then the European Commission may ask the W.T.O. for permission to draw up a new list of American products to face sanctions.
 Mr. Lamy played down the possibility of a new dispute over tax breaks. ''If the United States doesn't conform,'' he said, ''it would only be at that juncture that we would start talking of sanctions.''
 Trade experts based in Brussels said Mr. Lamy's mixed message welcoming the bill and at the same time warning that it did not go far enough was simply pragmatic.
 ''He recognizes that for the Americans to abolish the F.S.C. is a big deal because it means doing away with something that has been part and parcel of business life for decades,'' said Philip Bentley, a trade expert and partner in the Brussels office of the law firm Stanbrook & Hooper.
 ''He doesn't want to push the Americans too hard, especially before the presidential elections next week, because there is a risk they will strike back and worsen the trade atmosphere,'' he added. ''But nevertheless, he wants to leave the door open for future action if it's needed.''
 The United States has already opened a new front in its trade disputes with Europe. Earlier this month, it complained to the W.T.O. about the way European governments supported the commercial plane maker Airbus with subsidies.
 Within hours, Mr. Lamy filed a countercomplaint about American support for Boeing. On Monday, Mr. Lamy said he had proposed face-to-face talks on Nov. 4 and 5 to try to defuse this new dispute.
 The final pieces of the old dispute, along with the disagreement on aircraft subsidies, pose a problem for Mr. Mandelson, Mr. Bentley said.
 ''Lamy is taking the glory for settling the bulk of the F.S.C. dispute, but it could actually be harder to solve the small bits left for his successor,'' he said, adding that Mr. Mandelson would need a deft touch in dealing with these problems. 
 ''There won't be much glory in tidying up the loose ends of the F.S.C. dispute,'' Mr. Bentley said, ''but the price will be very high if he gets it wrong.''

INDUSTRY: NAICS336412 AIRCRAFT ENGINE & ENGINE PARTS MANUFACTURING (57%); NAICS335222 HOUSEHOLD REFRIGERATOR & HOME FREEZER MANUFACTURING (57%); NAICS335210 SMALL ELECTRICAL APPLIANCE MANUFACTURING (57%); NAICS511210 SOFTWARE PUBLISHERS (57%); SIC7372 PREPACKAGED SOFTWARE (57%); NAICS336414 GUIDED MISSILE & SPACE VEHICLE MANUFACTURING (57%); NAICS336411 AIRCRAFT MANUFACTURING (57%); SIC3761 GUIDED MISSILES & SPACE VEHICLES (57%)

SECTION: Section G; Column 3; Voter Guide 2004; THE ISSUES; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 1806 words

HEADLINE: Where They Stand, What They've Done

 BODY:

President George W. Bush

ABORTION
*Opposes abortion, except in cases of rape or incest or when a woman's life is endangered, but has said neither the country nor Congress is ready for a ban. Opposes federal funding for abortion. Signed legislation to outlaw a type of second- and third-trimester abortion procedure.

*Says he would not impose an abortion ''litmus test'' on judicial appointments, but cited justices who oppose abortion rights as model appointments and says he favors ''strict constructionists.''

*Criticized F.D.A.'s approval of morning-after pill.

DEATH PENALTY
*Supports the death penalty.

ECONOMY
*Signed tax cuts in each of the past four years, including a $1.35 trillion cut over 10 years in 2001, which he wants to make permanent. Says the cuts have helped the nation overcome recession and are responsible for a surge in economic growth. The cuts have contributed to deficits expected to surpass $400 billion this year. Pledges to cut the deficit in half after five years, in part by urging Congress to limit discretionary spending except for defense and homeland security.

*Would cut the corporate rate to 32 percent from 35 percent.

*Wants $3,000 re-employment accounts to help with jobsearch costs.

*Supports Nafta and World Trade Organization agreements. Supports liberalized trade.

*Opposes an increase in the minimum wage.

EDUCATION
*Supports taxpayer-financed vouchers for tuition at parochial and other private schools. Signed the 2002 No Child Left Behind Act, calling for increased annual testing in third through eighth grades by 2005-2006 and tying federal funding to results of tests.

*Opposes making preschool available to all 4-year-olds.

*Opposes making federally backed bonds available for school repair and construction.

*Signed a law providing some tax breaks for college tuition that the administration says saved students and their parents an estimated $9 billion.

ENVIRONMENT
*Rejected Kyoto Protocol on limiting global-warming gases on the ground it would hurt the nation's economy. Reversed a pledge to regulate carbon dioxide and proposed easing requirement that older factories and refineries to add pollution controls if they expand.

*Reduced plans for drilling off the Florida coast because of local opposition. Proposed opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling.

FOREIGN POLICY
*After the Sept. 11 attacks, instituted a policy of preemptive strikes, unilaterally if necessary, against suspected threats to the nation's security. Swift military victory in Iraq has been followed by a violent insurgency against the new government. Despite later findings that Iraq had no weapons of mass destruction and had only tenuous ties to Al Qaeda, Mr. Bush said that Saddam Hussein had the will and potential to develop such weapons and help terrorists and that ousting him has made the world safer and will encourage democracy in the Middle East.

*Waged a successful war against Taliban in Afghanistan, where elections were held this month.

*Won Congressional approval of $87 billion for continued military operations and aid in Iraq and Afghanistan.

*Calls for a Palestinian state as part of the peace plan known as the road map.

GAY RIGHTS
*Opposes gay marriage. Supports a constitutional amendment defining marriage as the union between a man and a woman, but says states should decide whether to allow civil unions for gay couples.

*Has continued Clinton policy allowing gays to serve in the military if they are not open about their sexuality.

GUN CONTROL
*Favors granting gun makers immunity from civil lawsuits arising from wrongful use of weapons.

*Supports renewing the ban on assault-type weapons and requiring background checks at gun shows, but let the 10-year-old ban on assault-type weapons expire.

HEALTH CARE
*Signed a law giving the elderly limited prescription drug coverage under Medicare for the first time, at an estimated cost of $534 billion over the next 10 years. It subsidizes costs for low-income patients and encourages private insurance companies to offer coverage for the elderly who drop traditional Medicare.

*Generally opposes importation of lower-cost drugs on grounds that the government cannot guarantee their safety.

*Supports expansion of tax-free medical savings accounts.

*The president's election-year budget proposes a $1,000 tax credit to help four million uninsured Americans buy health insurance.

*Argued against patients' right to sue federally regulated health plans and proposes capping medical malpractice awards.

HOMELAND SECURITY AND DEFENSE
*After resisting Congressional demands, created a new cabinet-level position to coordinate antiterrorism efforts; tripled spending on security.

*Argues that even illegal immigrants without known links to terrorist groups can be detained indefinitely.

*Reconfigured the F.B.I. to focus on preventing attacks.

*Signed the Patriot Act, which gave law enforcement agents expanded powers to apprehend suspects.

*Hopes to deploy a shield against ballistic missiles.

*Has increased defense spending by $100 billion, the most in real terms since the Korean War.

*Began redeployment of troops from South Korea and Europe. Pledges he will not reinstate the draft.

SOCIAL SECURITY
*Favors giving younger workers choice of placing some of their Social Security payroll tax into personal retirement accounts, with potential of a higher return in exchange for smaller Social Security benefits.

*Has not ruled out raising retirement age.

Senator John Kerry

ABORTION
*Supports abortion rights and federal funding for abortion and abortion counseling. Voted against the ban on a second- and third-trimester abortion procedure because it does not allow for abortion when the life of the woman is endangered.

*Says he will appoint only judges who support abortion rights to the Supreme Court.

*Says health plans should assure women coverage for contraceptives.

DEATH PENALTY
*Opposes the death penalty, except for terrorists.

ECONOMY
*Would repeal Mr. Bush's tax cuts for taxpayers with incomes above $200,000 and promises not to raise taxes for people earning less. Favors $18 billion a year in health care tax credits for low- and moderate-income workers, including a 75 percent credit for those earning up to 300 percent of the poverty level.

*Criticizes Mr. Bush because during his presidency, the country has lost at least 585,000 jobs. Calls for $50 billion over an unspecified period for job-creation and economic-stimulus programs and tax credits to discourage outsourcing abroad.

*Would cut the corporate tax rate by 5 percent.

*Vows to cut deficit in half by end of first term, letting federal spending rise no more than the inflation rate except for defense, domestic security and education.

*Supported North American and world trade agreements and elevated trade status with China. Would review trade agreements to assess local labor and environmental standards.

*Favors an increase in the minimum wage to $7 from $5.15 by 2007 and then indexing it to inflation.

EDUCATION
*Opposes private-school vouchers as a drain on public school resources. Supports the 2002 legislation but says the funding has been insufficient and proposes $27 billion fully fund the act and creation of a $200 billion education trust fund.

*Supports a $3.2 billion community service plan for high school students that would qualify them for the equivalent of their state's four-year public college tuition they perform two years of national service.

*Favors a tax credit for college tuition costs.

ENVIRONMENT
*Would not sign Kyoto Protocol to cut emissions but would invest in development of hydrogen, ethanol and other cleaner renewable fuels.

*Would steer $20 billion from oil and gas royalties to development of cleaner energy.

*Opposes drilling in Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. Wants 20 percent of electricity from renewable or alternative sources by 2020.

*Supported tougher fuel-efficiency standards for vehicles.

FOREIGN POLICY
*Supported a Congressional resolution letting Mr. Bush go to war in Iraq but now says he did so based on faulty intelligence and assuming the president would build a broad coalition and invade as a last resort.

*Voted against an $87 billion package for Iraq and Afghanistan (after voting for an earlier version that would have been paid for by repealing tax cuts for people who earn more than $200,000). Says he would begin troop withdrawal within six months and complete it within four years by enlisting more support from NATO allies.

*Voted to enlarge NATO to include Eastern Europe

*Sees the Bush administration's Middle East road map as an acceptable approach for reinvigorating peace efforts, but says there must be verifiable security benchmarks that the Palestinian Authority can reasonably achieve.

GAY RIGHTS
*Does not favor gay marriage, but opposes a constitutional amendment banning it and says individual states should decide. Supports right to civil unions for same-sex couples. Would ban job discrimination against homosexuals and extend hate-crime protections to gays.

*Would let gays serve openly in the military.

GUN CONTROL
*Opposes granting gun makers immunity from suits.

*Supports renewing the ban on assault-type weapons.

*Would require the same background checks at gun shows that are mandatory for other gun sales. Supports mandatory child safety locks.

HEALTH CARE
*Proposes expanding health insurance coverage so that all children and 95 percent of adults are covered, at a cost to the government of $895 billion over 10 years.

*Favors lowering costs of prescription drugs by allowing bulk purchasing by Medicare and easier importation of drugs from Canada.

*Criticized law signed by Mr. Bush giving the elderly prescription drug coverage under Medicare as insufficient, saying it fails to directly involve the government in lowering costs.

*Wants to expand the insurance system now available for federal employees to private citizens through tax credits and subsidies.

*Favors a 75 percent tax credit to help pay for insurance.

*Would give patients an independent review process to appeal coverage decisions.

*Would bar medical malpractice suits unless a specialist ruled the claim reasonable.

*Favors federal support to expand access to stateadministered health insurance for children.

HOMELAND SECURITY AND DEFENSE
*Voted for the Patriot Act, which gave the federal government broad new law enforcement powers; says he supports most of it, but believes it can be improved to enhance its effectiveness and prevent abuses.

*Opposes a national missile defense shield.

*Proposes to increase active-duty forces by 40,000 and double Army Special Forces. Would place National Guard under Homeland Security. Opposes a draft and says that reserve call-ups and orders that involuntarily extend tours of duty amount to a "backdoor draft."

SOCIAL SECURITY
*Opposes personal accounts under Social Security.

*Opposes raising retirement age or reducing payments.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 26, 2004
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section G; Column 1; Voter Guide 2004; THE VOTING; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1189 words

HEADLINE: All Those Promises: Do They Really Matter?

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER

 BODY:
LYNDON JOHNSON famously declared during the 1964 presidential campaign that he was ''not about to send American boys 9,000 or 10,000 miles away from home to do what Asian boys ought to be doing themselves.'' Woodrow Wilson campaigned for re-election in 1916, the year before the United States entered World War I, on a promise of peace and prosperity. And George W. Bush pledged in 2000 that he would have a ''humble'' foreign policy without nation-building.
 As more than 100 million Americans head to the polls next Tuesday to participate in the great democratic experience of a presidential election, history prompts some tough questions:
 Don't wars and terrorism overpower any president, offering what can feel like an inevitable course of action? Adding in the possibility that a president will inherit a recalcitrant Congress, or that he may even change his mind, does it really matter what the candidates say during the long months of a campaign? And if what they say about their positions doesn't matter, then is there some better way to judge how a candidate will perform in the Oval Office? 
 To tackle the first question first, the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, would seem to make the case that unforeseen events trump the ''great man'' theory of history, meaning that individual presidents matter far less than the times in which they govern. President Bush's supporters argue that his response to the attacks was more far-reaching than the attacks themselves, and that his leadership was more important than the circumstances. 
 Most historians say the man and the event both matter.
 ''Interpreting that is the dilemma that all historians face,'' said Robert A. Caro, who is working on the last book of a four-volume study of the life of President Johnson. ''Events and the individual interact. If you think of history as I do, as an equation with a lot of factors -- economic forces, political forces -- one factor is certainly the personality of the president. Sometimes it's a large factor, sometimes it's a small one, and sometimes it's quite a large factor, as in the case of the guy I'm writing about.''
 Consider whether Al Gore would have marched into Baghdad in March 2003. ''None of us believe we would be fighting in Iraq under a Gore presidency,'' said Fred I. Greenstein, a Princeton professor and the author of ''Personality and Politics.'' 
 ''Certainly we don't believe we'd have the same tax structure. Kerry and Bush will both face Iraq in a similar way, but they'll be night and day on other issues like stem cells.''
 Some historians argue that who is president now matters more than ever in an era of American global dominance and a White House that has steadily amassed power from Congress.
 ''You don't have to subscribe to the great man theory, because it's the 'great president' theory,'' said the historian Robert Dallek, the author of a recent biography of John F. Kennedy. While the 19th century was largely a period of weak presidents who ceded authority to Congress, the years since Theodore Roosevelt have produced increasingly powerful chief executives who have set the agendas at home and waged wars overseas. 
 President Bush's doctrine of pre-emption and the invasion of Iraq have taken those powers to new levels; a president can clearly determine events if his policy is not to wait until events force his hand.
 ''Look at Bush with the Iraq war,'' Mr. Dallek said. ''The Congress was so intimidated.''
 In 1940, said the historian David M. Kennedy, ''it made a whale of a difference that Franklin Roosevelt was president.'' Roosevelt spent years talking reluctant Americans into World War II, and had he not been president, scholars agree that history would have looked very different.
 ''That's a moment when the consequences of personality and the impact of an individual on historical events is really quite large,'' he said. ''But those moments are very rare.''
 Roosevelt, on the other hand, campaigned on a promise to balance the budget, an absurd pledge with the hindsight of World War II. Which brings up the second question: How much attention should voters give to what candidates say on the stump?
 ''Campaign rhetoric is crazy, and people in this country kind of know it,'' Mr. Dallek said. ''They're not stupid. When Kerry says Bush is going to have a draft and they're going to privatize Social Security, it's kind of who can out-flim-flam whom. It's all campaign nonsense.''
 Mr. Kennedy, a Kerry supporter, agrees. ''Frankly, this voter doesn't pay an awful lot of attention to the details of programs,'' he said. ''Which is why when John Kerry says 'I have a plan,' it drives me nuts. The best-laid plans of mice and men -- you know. But I do think the plan is a marker for the values and priorities of the candidates. The plan is an indication of where they would like to go.''
 Still, there is strong historical case to be made that campaign oratory, even of the distorted, hot-headed variety that Mr. Bush and Mr. Kerry have employed in the final days of the campaign, opens a window to what a candidate will actually do in the White House.
 In 2000, Mr. Bush campaigned on a promise of large tax cuts that are now law. Johnson produced the array of Great Society legislation he had campaigned on in 1964. In 1860, Abraham Lincoln promised that he would prevent the expansion of slavery to new states.
 ''We should pay attention to heated rhetoric because some of it is predictive of what people are going to do in office,'' Professor Greenstein said. ''And the way it comes out is revealing of character as well.''
 And character, historians say, is what voters should look for in a candidate as they engage in the act of casting their ballots for the nation's next president. ''I don't like people who lie to me,'' said the historian John Morton Blum, who was one of Mr. Bush's professors at Yale. ''But beyond character, there's the matter of adaptability. In a president who is going to offer programmatic and other forms of leadership, you must have the capacity to adapt, often to unforeseen contingencies.''
 Come next week, after all the debates and shouting and position papers, walking into the voting booth and drawing the curtain is ultimately an intimate act of faith and hope, a best, nervous guess for the future judged on what can be known of the past.
 ''This is a case where you have to trust the innate good judgment of the American voter,'' said Michael Beschloss, the presidential historian.
 ''Voters should ask themselves: 'Does his history predict what he's going to do as president? Does he agree with my values?' Oddly enough, when people say they vote on personality, personality is not that you like him because he seems like Johnny Carson. What it really means is 'Do I feel that he shares my values enough that when he makes a decision he'll do the right thing?' ''
 Mr. Beschloss said he would not presume to offer any advice to American voters, but he did have a last encouraging thought.
 ''If you look at American history, there have been rather few cases where the American people made a monumentally bad choice,'' he said. ''Usually, we chose pretty well.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: At the debates this year, George W. Bush and John Kerry described where they stood and how they would shape the next four years. Yet history teaches that a president's agenda is often driven by outside forces. (Photographs by Stephen Crowley/The New York Times) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS (92%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (92%); US PRESIDENTS (90%); US PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS (90%); US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2012 (90%); ELECTIONS (90%); HISTORY (89%); US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2008 (89%); HUMANITIES & SOCIAL SCIENCE (88%); POLITICS (77%); WORLD WAR I (77%); TERRORISM (74%); SEPTEMBER 11 ATTACK (74%); WRITERS (62%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (56%); TAXES & TAXATION (50%) Presidential Election of 2004; Debating

PERSON: GEORGE W BUSH (90%); JOHN KERRY (79%); AL GORE (58%) Elisabeth Bumiller; George W (Pres) Bush; John (Sen) Kerry

GEOGRAPHIC: BAGHDAD, IRAQ (51%) UNITED STATES (94%); IRAQ (92%)

SECTION: Section A; Column 5; National Desk; THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: THE ENVIRONMENT; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 819 words

HEADLINE: NASA Expert Criticizes Bush On Global Warming Policy

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN

 BODY:
A top NASA climate expert who twice briefed Vice President Dick Cheney on global warming plans to criticize the administration's approach to the issue in a lecture at the University of Iowa tonight and say that a senior administration official told him last year not to discuss dangerous consequences of rising temperatures.
 The expert, Dr. James E. Hansen, director of the NASA Goddard Institute for Space Studies in Manhattan, expects to say that the Bush administration has ignored growing evidence that sea levels could rise significantly unless prompt action is taken to reduce heat-trapping emissions from smokestacks and tailpipes. 
 Many academic scientists, including dozens of Nobel laureates, have been criticizing the administration over its handling of climate change and other complex scientific issues. But Dr. Hansen, first in an interview with The New York Times a week ago and again in his planned lecture today, is the only leading scientist to speak out so publicly while still in the employ of the government. 
 In the talk, Dr. Hansen, who describes himself as ''moderately conservative, middle-of-the-road'' and registered in Pennsylvania as an independent, plans to say that he will vote for Senator John Kerry, while also criticizing some of Mr. Kerry's positions, particularly his pledge to keep nuclear waste out of Nevada.
 He will acknowledge that one of the accolades he has received for his work on climate change is a $250,000 Heinz Award, given in 2001 by a foundation run by Teresa Heinz Kerry, Mr. Kerry's wife. The awards are given to people who advance causes promoted by Senator John Heinz, the Pennsylvania Republican who was Mrs. Heinz Kerry's first husband.
 But in an interview yesterday, Dr. Hansen said he was confident that the award had had ''no impact on my evaluation of the climate problem or on my political leanings.''
 In a draft of the talk, a copy of which Dr. Hansen provided to The Times yesterday, he wrote that President Bush's climate policy, which puts off consideration of binding cuts in such emissions until 2012, was likely to be too little too late.
 Actions to curtail greenhouse-gas emissions ''are not only feasible but make sense for other reasons, including our economic well-being and national security,'' Dr. Hansen wrote. ''Delay of another decade, I argue, is a colossal risk.''
 In the speech, Dr. Hansen also says that last year, after he gave a presentation on the dangers of human-caused, or anthropogenic, climate shifts to Sean O'Keefe, the NASA administrator, ''the administrator interrupted me; he told me that I should not talk about dangerous anthropogenic interference, because we do not know enough or have enough evidence for what would constitute dangerous anthropogenic interference.''
 After conferring with Mr. O'Keefe, Glenn Mahone, the administrator's spokesman, said Mr. O'Keefe had a completely different recollection of the meeting. ''To say the least, Sean is certain that he did not admonish or even suggest that there be a throttling back of research efforts'' by Dr. Hansen or his team, Mr. Mahone said.
 Dr. Franco Einaudi, director of the NASA Earth Sciences Directorate at the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., and Dr. Hansen's supervisor, said he was at the meeting between Dr. Hansen and Mr. O'Keefe. Dr. Einaudi confirmed that Mr. O'Keefe had interrupted the presentation to say that these were ''delicate issues'' and there was a lot of uncertainty about them. But, he added: ''Whether it is obvious to take that as an order or not is a question of judgment. Personally, I did not take it as an order.''
 Dr. John H. Marburger III, the science adviser to the president, said he was not privy to any exchanges between Dr. Hansen and the administrator of NASA. But he denied that the White House was playing down the risks posed by climate change. 
 ''President Bush has long recognized the serious implications of climate change, the role of human activity, and our responsibility to reduce emissions,'' Dr. Marburger said in an e-mailed statement. ''He has put forward a series of policy initiatives including a commitment to reduce the greenhouse gas intensity of our economy.''
 In the interview yesterday, Dr. Hansen stood by his assertions and said the administration risked disaster by discouraging scientists from discussing unwelcome findings.
 Dr. Hansen, 63, acknowledged that he imperiled his credibility and perhaps his job by criticizing Mr. Bush's policies in the final days of a tight presidential campaign. He said he decided to speak out after months of deliberation because he was convinced the country needed to change course on climate policy. 
 Dr. Hansen rose to prominence when, after testifying at a Senate hearing in the record-warm summer of 1988, he said, ''It is time to stop waffling so much and say the evidence is pretty strong that the greenhouse effect is here.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. James E. Hansen of the Goddard Institute for Space Studies. (Photo by Librado Romero/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Column 2; National Desk; THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRATIC NOMINEE; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1270 words

HEADLINE: Clinton Tries On His Long Coattails for Kerry

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 

 BODY:
He looked a little gaunt, his crisp navy suit hanging on a faded frame. He seemed slightly out of breath as he spoke and he tipped back a water bottle as soon as he left the lectern. But he nibbled his lip and bobbed his head with that familiar electricity in his eye, mouthing ''thank you'' to an enormous and adoring crowd that packed downtown streets here Monday at lunchtime. 
 ''From time to time, I have been called the Comeback Kid,'' former President Bill Clinton said, campaigning with Senator John Kerry and making his first public appearance since his quadruple bypass surgery seven weeks ago. ''In eight days, John Kerry's going to make America the Comeback Country.''
 Introduced as ''the last duly elected president of the United States,'' Mr. Clinton stared out at a sea of souls stretching 12 blocks and said, ''If this isn't good for my heart, I don't know what is.'' 
 It was a scene Democrats have been desperate for in the waning weeks of this fiercely fought campaign, but one that Mr. Kerry's predecessor as their presidential nominee, former Vice President Al Gore, had shunned four years ago for fear that outrage over the affair with an intern that led to Mr. Clinton's impeachment would alienate the sought-after swing voters.
 But Mr. Kerry enveloped Mr. Clinton in a bear hug here this afternoon. He and his aides see the former president as able equally to motivate the party's base and to telegraph to undecided voters what the campaign is posing as the essential question of the election: Are you better off now than when President Bush took over the Oval Office? 
 ''He led this nation to the strongest economy we've ever had,'' Mr. Kerry said. ''He expanded health care for millions of children in America. He helped bring our security and the security of the world to the level it ought to be, and he did this by always putting people first and fighting for the middle class.'' 
 Mr. Kerry said he asked Mr. Clinton backstage: '''Mr. President, can you tell me anything that you have in common with George W. Bush?' And he thought for a moment and he said, 'In eight days and 12 hours, we will both be former presidents.'''
 From Philadelphia, where the fire commissioner estimated the crowd topped 80,000, by far the largest for the campaign, Mr. Clinton headed to Florida for solo events Monday and Tuesday, with Nevada and New Mexico on the itinerary at the end of the week if his health holds.
 On the way home to New York on Sunday, Mr. Clinton plans to stop in his native Arkansas, a state President Bush won by more than 5 percentage points in 2000 and where a new poll shows the contest suddenly close. 
 Mr. Clinton's long-awaited return to the campaign trail came after the cancellation of at least 10 rallies over the past two months because of the surgery, but the delay only helped enhance the comeback effect. And if he was less energetic than usual and escaped after shaking just a few hands, at least that shortened the shadow he cast over the less-charismatic Mr. Kerry.
 Just a snippet of Mr. Clinton's perennial theme song, Fleetwood Mac's ''Don't Stop (Thinking About Tomorrow),'' seeped from the speakers as he took the microphone, and it hit the unfortunate lyric, ''Yesterday's gone, yesterday's gone.'' The crowd was covered in Kerry buttons, and screamed, ''We love you, John!'' more often than ''We love you, Bill!'' 
 As Mr. Kerry's anthem, ''No Surrender'' by Bruce Springsteen, blared, the two tall, thin figures whispered together, Mr. Clinton pointing out a person in the front row, Mr. Kerry gesturing to the fans hanging off the balconies of a 10-story apartment building. 
 ''I had quadruple surgery in 1989, I know what it's like what he's doing,'' said Jim Mangine, 59, a telephone technician who took three hours off work to attend the lunchtime rally. ''He looks fantastic. I didn't think he was that handsome -- he's a good-looking guy, and I'm a man. It'll definitely get people off the fence.''
 In Davenport, Iowa, where President Bush was campaigning, Karl Rove, the president's chief political adviser, said of the spectacle, ''They had to roll Clinton out of the hospital room and onto the campaign trail to help Senator Kerry with his core constituencies that are so weak.'' 
 After the rally, Mr. Clinton introduced Mr. Kerry on a conference call with 2,000 African-American ministers, telling them, ''I know Senator Kerry very well, I think I know his mind and his heart, I have spent both public time and private time with him. And I believe that he has the ability to be a very, very great president.'' 
 On the call, Mr. Kerry made a point of mentioning his opposition to gay marriage, amid concerns by many Democrats that the party was losing support among conservative black Christians over this and other cultural issues. ''So I ask you not to be sidetracked, diverted from the real focus of this race, which is lifting the lives of Americans,'' Mr. Kerry said, according to a transcript circulated by his campaign.
 Aides said the former president and the presidential hopeful shared a heart-healthy lunch of chicken and salad and then Mr. Clinton offered his consummately Clinton take on the state of the race. 
 ''He was clearly well versed in what's happening county by county in Arkansas,'' laughed Mike McCurry, the former Clinton White House press secretary who now works for Mr. Kerry and wore a green tie featuring images of saxophone players in honor of his ex-boss. ''He said a lot of people down there are working hard. He said he thinks they can surprise the other folks down there.''
 Mr. Clinton also gave Mr. Kerry pointers on how to mobilize specific swaths of voters, including Jews and blacks, and ran through electoral math with Gov. Edward G. Rendell of Pennsylvania. On stage, he joked, ''I've been home watching it'' and summed up the campaign by sharing ''one of Clinton's laws of politics.''
 ''If one candidate's trying to scare you and the other one's trying to get you to think,'' he said, ''if one candidate's appealing to your fears and the other one's appealing to your hopes, you better vote for the person who wants you to think and hope.''
 Mr. Clinton's remarks were broadcast live on CNN, which cut away after Mr. Kerry said, ''thank you.'' 
 Mr. Kerry sped through his standard stump speech, editing in references to Mr. Clinton, by name and not. 
 ''Are you ready for a president again who is a champion of the middle class?'' Mr. Kerry asked, adding the ''again'' to his opening line. Speaking about universal health care, he said, ''We are going to end the journey begun by Harry Truman, fought for by Bill Clinton,'' and he made an unusual mention of Mr. Clinton's work to improve labor standards in trade pacts with Jordan and Vietnam.
 Behind him, Mr. Clinton stood with hands clasped behind his back, then let them hang by his side, a bright, open-mouthed smile affixed to his face as he gazed intently at the speaker, then the crowd. He nodded along as they chanted the other man's name, ''Ker-ry, Ker-ry,'' American flags dangling from construction cranes overhead. Afterward, they thrust their fists in the air for the cameras, and Mr. Clinton made a quick exit, leaving Mr. Kerry to work the rope line.
 ''Awww,'' cried Anne DeSalvo, an actress visiting from Los Angeles, as Mr. Clinton disappeared from the viewfinder of her disposable camera before she could get close. 
 ''For me, he represents a time in America where someone really stuck his neck out for the people,'' Ms. DeSalvo explained. ''Some people said he didn't look so good. He lost a little weight, but he looked great. So vibrant. He's adorable!''


GRAPHIC: Photos: Senator John Kerry was joined yesterday by former President Bill Clinton at a rally that drew 80,000 people in Philadelphia. (Photo by Ting-Li Wang/The New York Times)(pg. A1)
 A sign of support for John Kerry at a rally in Philadelphia. (Photo by Stan Honda/Agence France-Presse -- Getty Images)(pg. A20)

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; National Desk; THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: ON THE TRAIL; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 1275 words

HEADLINE: Kerry's New Campaign Strategy Is Doing the Math

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER

DATELINE: WARREN, Mich., Oct. 25 

 BODY:
A year ago, Senator John Kerry's assault on President Bush and his policies was a machine-gun fusillade of adjectives: arrogant, bungling, cynical, ideological, inept, misleading, pathetic, reckless, shameful, stupid and above all, radically wrong.
 Today, it is a bombardment of numbers: health-care costs up 64 percent, college tuition up 35 percent, gas prices up 30 percent, Medicare premiums up 17 percent, prescription drug costs up 12 percent -- ''Wait, there's more,'' Mr. Kerry tells his by-now-restive crowds -- family incomes down $1,500, 1.6 million private-sector jobs lost, five million more Americans without health insurance, four million more in poverty, lost after-school programs for 500,000 children.
 In the homestretch of his presidential campaign, Mr. Kerry has pivoted from raising questions about Mr. Bush's character to trying to add up for voters, in attention-taxing arithmetic, the effects of the president's policies -- and say just how bad four more years of Mr. Bush would be for them. 
 Then he offers a brighter vision. Lifting from Bill Clinton, Barack Obama, and from the George W. Bush of four years ago, Mr. Kerry pleads with audiences in these final days to ''vote your hopes, not your fears,'' to vote for ''an America where we unite people again,'' where there are no red or blue states but only ''one America -- red, white and blue -- for everyone.''
 Mr. Kerry says he wants to put the American dream -- or at least the ability to make ends meet -- once again within reach of ''the great middle class, and the people who are struggling to get into it.''
 He wants, he says, to make health care affordable and to cover every child at birth. To ''make the workplace fair again'' and to stop encouraging companies to send jobs overseas, if not to end outsourcing altogether. To lead America to invent its way out of its oil dependency, to repair its relationships with its allies and to reclaim its position as the world's moral and scientific leader. 
 Ambitious, Mr. Kerry certainly is. But as he reaches out with what he calls ''plain, good old-fashioned common sense,'' he makes his goals sound well within reach. ''We can do this, folks,'' he says again and again, reminding crowds that theirs, after all, is the can-do country that was first in flight and first to the Moon. ''We know how to do this,'' he says of budget balancing and deficit reduction.
 ''This is not complicated,'' he said in Orlando, Fla., last week as he argued that the wealthy and the well-connected, with Mr. Bush's help, were preying on the middle class. ''It really isn't that complicated. The take-home pay of the average American family, as a share of all the national income, is the lowest it has been since 1929. And the take-home pay of the top one-tenth of 1 percent of income-earners is the highest it's been since 1928.''
 ''Something's wrong with that, my friends,'' he shouted, ''and we've got to make it right.''
 Mr. Kerry's speeches sometimes ring with the same outrage he had as a young antiwar protester. While he does not call Mr. Bush a liar (though his audiences do, and loudly), he does promise to ''tell the truth to the American people,'' as if doing so were a new idea.
 His speeches, of course, do not come in a vacuum but in the thick of a running battle with Mr. Bush. And much of what he says is intended to blunt Mr. Bush's attacks.
 While he has dropped most of his references to Vietnam, for example -- including how he knows ''what it's like to carry an M-16 and not know what's around the next corner'' -- he still notes that he ''defended this country as a young man'' and adds, a bit defensively, ''I'll defend it as president of the United States.''
 Mr. Kerry and Mr. Bush could not be more different on the stump. While Mr. Bush is still delivering many of the same punch lines he was months ago, Mr. Kerry's change by the hour. And while little changes from day to day in the president's speech except the names of the cities he compliments and the local officials he praises for ''filling the potholes,'' Mr. Kerry has never given his stump speech the same way twice.
 This is partly by design: he is a speechwriter's nightmare, adding needless words and phrases to a prepared text the way some catalog companies bury products in foam peanuts.
 Mr. Kerry works with building blocks, extended chunks of material that he constantly mixes and matches and remolds, as if he feels his listeners deserve not only his full attention but spontaneity to boot. And he is only too glad to provide it, as he did in Orlando, when the wind picked up his sheet of notes and blew it into the crowd. ''That's all right, let it fly,'' he said. ''I don't need it.''
 This is also by inclination: some of his funniest lines are improvised. A month ago, playfully mocking Mr. Bush's economic policy of ''tax relief,'' Mr. Kerry likened it to the kind of relief felt when someone ''breaks into your living room and relieves you of your TV set.'' The audience roared and a new riff was born, though it disappeared a few days later.
 At other times Mr. Kerry's winging it means he is left searching for his place, distracted by his own thoughts, trying to make sure he has covered every subject and said everything he can about each one.
 At this late date, despite the best efforts of his aides to cut his speeches in half, Mr. Kerry struggles to limit himself to 30 minutes; on Friday night, rallying a capacity crowd at a sports arena in Reno, Nev., he outlasted some audience members with a 50-minute stemwinder. He may feel that listeners who waited outside for hours deserve more than rote bullet points, but people still sometimes leave his events before he is done talking.
 Yet at a Democratic rally in Florida the night before the first presidential debate, when a spokesman, David Wade, bet a consultant, Bob Shrum, that Mr. Kerry could keep his remarks to less than 20 minutes, Mr. Wade won the $20 bet with 8 minutes to spare.
 It was very likely the shortest speech of Mr. Kerry's campaign. No footnotes, no long-winded paragraphs; it was as if he were reading just the table of contents of his normal speech. He left his wildly appreciative audience starved for more.
 Mr. Kerry adds and subtracts from his stump speech constantly, sometimes inexplicably. But some sure-fire applause lines show up whenever he holds a microphone: when he vows that ''never again will young Americans in uniform be held hostage to America's dependency on oil from the Middle East''; when he merely utters the words ''stem-cell research''; and when he winds up by telling the unverifiable story of a woman who went to one of his events in Ohio recently.
 Mr. Kerry frequently works into his speeches the names and stories of people he has met along the campaign trail. But this mystery woman had given no name; she had just passed along to a Kerry staff member a simple message for the candidate. ''Senator,'' it said, ''we've got your back.'' 
 If the story is true, it is just as well the woman did not give her name and say what issue or problem motivated her. Because now, as he closes out each speech with her words of encouragement, Mr. Kerry can turn it into a message to every voter.
 ''Here's the deal,'' he said in Orlando. ''You want to do the things we need to do to have clean air and clean water, and leave this earth in better shape to our children than we were given it by our parents? You want to lift this country up? Then give me the privilege on Nov. 2 of being able to stand up, and every day I go to that Oval Office I'll be able to look you in the eye, and I'll say to you, 'I've got your back.' '' 


GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator John Kerry, at a rally on Saturday in Pueblo, Colo., says the numbers add up to failed Bush policies. (Photo by Ting-Li Wang/The New York Times)
