Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section A; Column 3; Foreign Desk; Johannesburg Journal; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 1036 words

HEADLINE: Speaking of Fences, Street Crime and, Ultimately, Race

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 27 

 BODY:
As Nick Karvelas would be quick to point out, this is not a Robert Frost kind of town. 
 Mr. Frost, as an American schoolchild could testify, is the poet who once wrote that ''good fences make good neighbors.'' That should make Johannesburgers exceptional ones: in the last decade, they have erected fences and gates that block off 1,245 ostensibly public streets from the outside world. 
 In practice, of course, the barriers are the antithesis of neighborliness. Their purpose is to shield the people behind them -- mostly better-off whites -- from an epidemic of street crime, largely by lower-class blacks. 
 Which is why Mr. Karvelas is on a single-minded crusade to tear them down. The notion that whites can bar poor blacks from city streets, he insists, is not just illegal. It's a throwback to the days when millions of blacks were herded into homelands and townships, and barred from walking in white areas without a government pass. 
 ''I just firmly believe that people actually went from fencing the masses in to fencing the masses out,'' he said. ''I really believe that this is just another form of apartheid.'' 
 Mr. Karvelas, a white school principal and university lecturer when he is not tilting at fences, has formed a lobbying group and a Web site to promote his cause. He has pestered Johannesburg's government, hinted at a lawsuit testing the constitutionality of street barriers and, last month, argued his case before the national Human Rights Council. 
 In most big cities, he might be dismissed as that ubiquitous brand of civic gadfly that buzzes irritatingly around every council meeting. Indeed, in most big cities, the issue of street closings would be settled in soporific sessions of traffic-department subcommittees or neighborhood councils. 
 Not in Johannnesburg. Here, it resonates among rich and poor, black and white alike. The debate over street closings not only poses thorny questions about balancing a person's right to walk freely and a homeowner's right to be safe. It also challenges a notion that still binds this multiracial society together 10 years after apartheid's demise -- the concept of a miraculous rainbow nation, sprung fully formed from Nelson Mandela's tolerant brow. 
 Mr. Karvelas's stridency aside, however, this is not entirely a black-and-white issue, in more ways than one. 
 Street barriers (South Africans call them ''booms'') first sprang up in the city's wealthier northern suburbs after the 1994 transition to majority rule -- and the exodus of many white civil servants -- led to a dramatic decline in police protection and a rise in violent crime. 
 It is crime, not race, that is behind the boom in booms, their advocates say. 
 Johannesburg is widely touted as one of the world's most violent cities, a reputation the government says is itself a racist myth. Myth or not, crime is a headache: relying on 2001 police data, the highly regarded Center for the Study of Violence and Reconciliation concluded that one in 110 residents had been robbed at gunpoint that year, one in 605 had been carjacked and one in 1,332 murdered. 
 By comparison, the F.B.I. says that one in 2,431 Detroiters was murdered in 2001, and one in 134 was robbed. The comparable figures for New York City were one in 12,195 murdered and one in 284 robbed. Most of that crime was in poor areas. Whether most suburbanites are at real risk or just fearful may be debatable. What seems less disputable is that the barriers do cut crime for those behind them. 
 Alphen Park, a middle-class neighborhood just east of downtown Johannesburg, suffered scores of carjackings, robberies, car thefts and a murder before winning permission to boom its entrance street. ''In two and one-half years, there's been zero crime,'' George W. Botha, whose company oversees barriers and anticrime work in that and nearby neighborhoods, said in a telephone interview. ''No hijacks. No rapes. A clothing iron was taken out of a kitchen, I think.'' 
 A lobby for street barriers in about 40 neighborhoods, the Combined Chairpersons for Road Closures, makes its case bluntly. ''This place is somewhat different from your 'society norm,''' the group's leader, Pat Redford, wrote in an e-mail message. ''We have driveway robberies taking place all the time, hijackings constantly, armed robberies, all inflicted on all colors and economic categories of citizens who cannot rely on a competent police force.'' 
 Judith Stockhill, a council member for the boom-laden Sandhurst neighborhood, says she is annoyed by the argument that fences and gates exclude blacks to make whites feel safe. Most victims in her area, she said, are black workers commuting on foot between Sandhurst domestic and gardening jobs and the nearby poor township of Alexandra. 
 ''The victims of crime are predominantly black, because the population is predominantly black,'' she said. ''And because they have to travel on streets after dark or before dawn, they're vulnerable. They certainly benefit from secure streets.'' 
 ''Pseudoliberals,'' Mr. Karvelas responds. ''We've looked at booms. The guards don't treat white females the same way as white males, and they don't treat black males on foot the same way. As one guy said at the Human Rights Council hearings, if the guy's suspicious-looking, they stop him.'' 
 It is this debate that in part led the Human Rights Council to take up the issue of barriers. The council will issue a nonbinding opinion on the booms' usefulness next month. Mr. Karvelas said he intended to argue next to the national security ministry that the booms are constitutionally illegal -- a form of vigilantism not unlike the occasional takeover of major highways by mobs of poor people protesting the lack of municipal services in their neighborhoods. 
 But Mr. Karvelas likely has miles to go in this battle before he sleeps. While the Johannesburg city government discourages the barriers, it also has taken steps to legalize those that meet a set of guidelines, including having the backing of 80 percent of residents behind them. The city's mayor lives behind a gated street. And -- as President Thabo Mbeki noted in a recent essay on race and crime in his nation -- so do a growing number of wealthy blacks.


GRAPHIC: Photos: A security guard, Larsen Monashane, above, registers a car at a barrier in Benoni, a Johannesburg suburb. George W. Botha, with Mr. Monashane at left, works for a company that oversees barriers and other efforts to stem a tide of carjackings, robberies, car thefts and killings. (Photographs by Lori Waselchuk for The New York Times)Map of South Africa highlighting Johannesburg: Some Johannesburg areas are fighting crime with street barriers.

SECTION: Section C; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 586 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

DreamWorks Animation Raises $812 Million
DreamWorks SKG has priced shares of its animation unit above the level expected, raising $812 million in an initial public offering.
 Heavy demand from investors for Dreamworks Animation SKG pushed the sale of 29 million shares to $28 a share, from an initial estimate of $23 to $25. Shares of Dreamworks Animation SKG will begin trading today under the symbol DWA on the New York Stock Exchange. Market Place. [Page C4.]

Ex-Macy's Chief to Head Penney
Myron E. Ullman III, left, a longtime retail executive who headed Macy's during its bankruptcy and recently led the luxury conglomerate LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, will replace Allen I. Questrom as chief executive of J.C. Penney. His appointment leaves Vanessa Castagna, who had been the top internal candidate and who has been credited with leading many of the recent changes at Penney, without a clearly defined future. [C4.]

A Promising Therapy From Pfizer
Sildenafil citrate, the ingredient in Viagra, Pfizer's impotence pill, has proven effective in a clinical trial as a treatment for pulmonary arterial hypertension -- high pressure in the artery carrying blood to the lungs. [C8.]

Need for Oil Investment Cited
As high prices raise concerns about future supplies of oil, the International Energy Agency stressed the need for oil-producing countries and oil companies to increase their investments in finding and pumping oil. [C9.]

Systems for Auto Stability Helpful
A study by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety found that the stability systems available in some cars and trucks can reduce the risk of getting in an accident. [C4.]

A Takeover Bid for Drug Company
The private equity unit of J.P. Morgan and the DLJ merchant banking group of Credit Suisse First Boston offered to acquire the Irish pharmaceutical company Warner Chilcott for $:1.62 billion ($3 billion). [C8.]

Earnings Soar 54% at Oil Company
ConocoPhillips reported a 54 percent increase in third-quarter profit as margins widened on diesel and other fuels and oil prices surged. Sales climbed 31 percent. The company expanded in countries with growing oil production, including Vietnam, Russia and Venezuela, as output declined from older fields in the United States and the North Sea. [C4.]

Profit rose 14 percent at Procter & Gamble on strong sales in all regions. [C2.]

Robust demand for military equipment and technology led Boeing and Northrop Grumman to post higher earnings. [C4.]

Comcast and Cox Communications reported strong profit and revenue growth because of growing demand for their digital video services and high-speed Internet connections. [C6.]

Kroll Offices in Brazil Raided
Police seized documents and arrested five people in a raid on the Brazilian offices of Kroll and a local private equity firm. [C8.]

Stocks Rally as Oil Prices Drop
Stocks rose sharply as investors expressed relief over a drop in oil prices. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 113.55 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,002.03. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 14.31 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,125.40; and the Nasdaq composite index jumped 41.20 points, or 2.1 percent, to 1,969.99. [C9.]

Moving Ideas Off Campus
In a financial bonanza for many universities, an increasing number of entrepreneurial students are helping commercialize technologies developed in their schools' laboratories. [C6.]

Where Are the Economists?
In the push for greater regulation after the corporate scandals, economists are notably absent. Jeff Madrick: Economic Scene. [C2.]

Correction Appended 
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section C; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 503 words

HEADLINE: Economy Grew Faster Than Expected, Helped by Home Sales

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Orders for durable goods rose in September for the third time in four months and sales of new homes unexpectedly increased, signs that manufacturers and builders helped the economy accelerate, two reports released yesterday indicated. 
 Another report said that corporate spending and a rebound in consumer purchases helped the economy grow at an annual rate of 4.3 percent last quarter, a percentage point higher than the previous three months. 
 Orders for durable goods, which are items made to last at least three years, increased 0.2 percent, to $195.7 billion, driven by demand for military hardware and business equipment, the Commerce Department said. 
 When transportation equipment was excluded, orders for durable goods rose 1.7 percent, after a 2.8 percent increase in August. A measure of business equipment orders rose the most since March, the department reported. 
 Economists had forecast a 0.5 percent rise in orders for durable goods, to $196.4 billion, based on the median of forecasts from 70 economists in a Bloomberg News survey. Orders, excluding transportation equipment, were expected to increase 0.3 percent, according to the survey. 
 New home sales rose 3.5 percent, to an annual rate of 1.2 million, the third fastest on record. Analysts had expected home sales to decline to an annual rate of 1.15 million. Growth was constrained in September and early October as oil costs, which remained more than 75 percent above levels from a year earlier, held back consumer and business spending and lifted prices for some goods and services, the Federal Reserve said in a survey of regional economic conditions known as the beige book. 
 ''The likelihood is that demand is going to soften again, given the high energy prices,'' said Peter Kretzmer, a senior economist at Banc of America Securities. ''The economy will slow late in the fourth quarter and into early 2005.'' 
 The Fed is expected to raise the overnight bank lending rate at its Nov. 10 meeting, based on the median forecast in another Bloomberg survey, which would be the fourth increase since June. 
 The Fed is trying to balance prospects for continued growth against the possibility that energy costs will trigger faster inflation. Crude oil for December delivery reached a record $55.67 a barrel in futures trading in New York this week before dropping. 
 New home purchases rose in every region but the West last month, fueled by 30-year mortgage rates that remained below 6 percent. Sales of new homes this year will reach 1.16 million, surpassing last year's record 1.08 million, according to the latest forecast by the National Association of Home Builders. 
 The median selling price dropped 8.4 percent in September, to $197,700 from $215,900 the previous month, the biggest percentage decline since 1981. Prices were still up 3 percent from a year earlier. The drop in September prices was influenced by purchases of starter homes costing less than $150,000, which accounted for a greater percentage of the total.


CORRECTION-DATE: October 29, 2004

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a 0.2 percent increase in orders for durable goods in September misattributed a forecast for economic growth. The forecast, which said that government data due to be released today were likely to report economic growth of 4.3 percent in the third quarter, appeared in a survey of economists by Bloomberg News, not in a government report.

LENGTH: 1214 words

HEADLINE: Forever Green

BYLINE: By ANNE RAVER

 BODY:
FIVE years ago a priceless collection of 150 rare ornamental conifers at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx was so tangled up in weed trees and Japanese bittersweet that most visitors did not know it was there.
 But since then the jungle has been cleared, and 200 new conifers, many of them dwarfs suitable for small gardens, have been added. When the area opens on Saturday as the Benenson Ornamental Conifers, visitors will be able to walk -- or ride an open-air shuttle -- through 15 acres of some of the world's most coveted ornamental trees.
 At the top of a rocky ridge they will see a grove of 11 giant dawn redwoods, whose fluted trunks rise 85 feet to the sky. This prehistoric conifer was thought to be extinct until 1941, when a Chinese forester, T. Kan, found it growing in a remote valley in central China. Those in the conifer collection were planted in 1950, from seeds collected in 1947. 
 Visitors will also be able to admire a weeping blue atlas cedar, leaning 20 feet across a rocky outcropping, and a Rheingold arborvitae nearby, artfully placed 60 years ago to catch the light of the setting sun.
 ''We literally discovered these glorious plants as we peeled away the rogues' gallery of things that had gone to seed,'' said Todd Forrest, the associate vice president of horticulture and living collections at the Botanical Garden.
 The specimen trees are among 200 conifers given to the garden in the late 1940's by Robert H. Montgomery, a wealthy accountant, who traveled across this country and Europe seeking choice plants to grow at his home, Wild Acres, near Cos Cob, Conn. He loved dwarf varieties and anything weeping or blue, and he had an eye for the quirky plants gardeners might want for yards smaller than his own 100-acre country estate. 
 One find, a dwarf Colorado spruce with dense powder-blue needles and a pyramid shape, was named after him in 1949: Picea pungens R. H. Montgomery, now one of the most widely planted conifers in America.
 ''Every Montgomery blue spruce is a descendant of this tree,'' Mr. Forrest said one overcast day last week, standing by a 15-footer that was planted in 1949 and has steadily grown at the rate of less than three inches a year.
 Mr. Montgomery gave away his conifers when he retired to Florida, where he grew interested in palms and with David Fairchild, the plant explorer, founded the Fairchild Tropical Botanic Garden in Miami. 
 The New York Botanical Garden commissioned Marion Cruger Coffin, who designed the Winterthur gardens in Delaware for Henry F. du Pont, to design a landscape for the conifers in 1947. ''And she did a wonderful job, placing these unusual-looking trees among the rocks and native oaks,'' Mr. Forrest said.
 But the collection fell into neglect with the budget cuts of the 1970's, and it was not until 1999 that a garden board member, James Benenson Jr., and his wife, Sharen, helped underwrite a $5 million restoration and expansion, adding 200 new specimens well suited to the home garden.
 Patrick Chasse, a landscape designer specializing in historic restorations, worked with Shavaun Towers, a landscape architect, to rebuild the area, without destroying the grace of Coffin's original design. They added an irrigation system, widened the original path for the shuttle and added stone and cedar pavilions based on one that Coffin drew but that was not built. Then Mr. Forrest scoured nurseries from Oregon to Connecticut for new cultivars and selections.
 Most conifers, like pines, firs, cedars and spruces, are evergreen, and their dark green or blue needles form the perfect backdrop for other plants. A few, like the bald-cypress, larch and dawn redwood, turn gold, amber or orange before dropping their needles in the fall.
 Mr. Forrest stopped to admire a cluster of weeping giant sequoias, which hover like 12-foot Dr. Seuss characters at the entrance of the new garden. ''These weeping sequoias aren't considered hardy to our climate, but they've survived two hard winters,'' said Mr. Forrest, who likes to test the limits of hardiness zones.
 Descendants of a seedling of the giant sequoias native to California, these beanpoles will be lucky to reach 30 feet in this climate, and they get no wider than a few feet. They were leaning companionably close to a dozen old Sargent weeping hemlocks -- more Montgomery favorites -- some of which span 30 feet.
 ''Most people would be lucky to have one of these,'' Mr. Forrest said. ''We have a whole army of them.''
 Down the path he paid his respects to a 50-foot snake branch spruce, Picea abies Virgata, whose horizontal branches are hung with long pendulous branchlets looking like eight-foot snakes. It took 100 years for the spruce to look like this.
 ''You would never plant this tree if you saw it in a nursery, because the young ones look like broom handles,'' Mr. Forrest said. 
 But you might be inspired to plant a monkey puzzle tree, also called Chilean pine, Araucaria araucana, whose whorls of stiff triangular needles need protection from the sun and wind.
 ''It's marginally hardy here at best,'' Mr. Forrest said, gingerly stroking the sharp needles of the tree he planted on the south side of a rock outcropping. ''But it's protected here from the northeast winds, and it's shaded by the snake branch spruce.''
 Adventurous gardeners can take their cues from Mr. Forrest's experimental placement of new conifers (while listening to an audiotape on the collection's highlights) or pore over demonstration beds of dwarf varieties that thrive in sun or shade.
 Sea Urchin, a miniature white pine looking more like a sheep than a sea creature, snuggles against a boulder in a demonstration bed among other sun-loving dwarf pines, spruces, firs and Japanese umbrella pines. 
 In a bed for shade-tolerant conifers an unusual silver fir, Abies alba Green Spiral, angles up out of the middle like a corkscrew with cascading branches.
 And then, just for a little sense of history, visitors might wander over to the LuEsther T. Mertz Library, to browse through ''Cultured Conifers,'' an exhibition of rare 18th-century books, copper etchings and lithographs that trace the economic uses of these ancient trees, from making charcoal and gin to curing cancer.
 The Benenson Ornamental Conifers are the cultivated side of this world of ancient cone-bearers. A look at the wild side may be had by simply walking through the older collection around the garden's conservancy. Its pines, spruces and firs were planted more than 100 years ago, and some have vanished in their native habitat.

Miniature Forests
 GARDENS too small for a 30-foot weeping giant sequoia may be just right for a white pine called Pinus strobus Sea Urchin, a blue-green mound that grows about 18 inches tall and 2.5 feet wide in 20 years. It was cultivated by Dr. Sidney Waxman, who will explain some of his techniques at the Botanical Garden on Saturday. (Information on this and other events is at www.nybg.org.) The urchin needs full sun, and so do other dwarf pines, spruces, firs and Japanese umbrella pines. Dwarf yews, plum-yews and hemlocks flourish in full shade, and Hinoki cypresses are good candidates for partial shade. The garden's shop offers more than two dozen stars of its new conifers collection, from $30 to $300, and many are sold by nurseries.

top right, dawn redwoods
center, a miniature white pine called Sea Urchin and a monkey puzzle tree (on right)

SECTION: Section D; Column 1; Sports Desk; BASEBALL; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 1137 words

HEADLINE: Again, There's No Joy in the Smaller Markets

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25 

 BODY:
Hi-Tops, a sports bar across from PNC Park, the handsome new stadium where the Pittsburgh Pirates play, is a regular hangout for baseball fans. But as the World Series got under way this weekend, and the Boston Red Sox and the St. Louis Cardinals appeared, almost larger than life, on a number of oversize screens, a full complement of waiters and bartenders presided over an almost empty barroom.
 ''We've totally lost baseball,'' said one Pirate fan, Rob Greenleaf, 37. ''I mean, you could throw a baseball to PNC Park from here, and there's no one here for the World Series?'' 
 This is a difficult time of year in most baseball-loving American cities. But it feels especially gloomy in places like Kansas City, Milwaukee, Cincinnati and Pittsburgh, small-market cities with substantial baseball traditions but where the modern economics of sport mitigate against success. The Yankees' payroll is $183 million; they pay Derek Jeter and Mike Mussina alone more than the Pirates -- whose payroll is $32 million -- pay their entire roster. It is now possible to argue that some franchises, like the Pirates, have been consigned to perpetual mediocrity. 
 ''We love the Pirates, we're good fans, we're passionate,'' Greenleaf, a basketball coach at a local college, said. ''But there's nothing we can do.''
 How all this affects fans is curious and complicated. Pulled in contradictory directions by loyalty and resentment, by partisan passion and pure love of the game, they don't know whether to express anguish or pride, for example, that there are seven former Pirates currently playing in the World Series. They can't decide if the glass is half-full or half-empty. 
 ''I don't like the way the game is now; we might be able to compete once in a blue moon,'' said Dan Honan, 39, a police officer who goes to 25 games a year. ''But would you rather live in Columbus, where you get nothing?'' 
 Many are still passionate, but they are also chagrined at having, as one fan put it, to find ''other things of value'' besides winning. 
 It is, in any case, a breed of fan born out necessity, and one that may not have existed before now. ''The fact that we're not going to compete for the World Series doesn't mean you can't enjoy being a fan,'' said John McKibben, 39, a former automobile salesman who is now in the restaurant business and has been a Pirates season-ticket holder for three years. ''On an August night if they're 20 games out, I can still go out to see Oliver Perez every five nights.''
 Many fans mentioned their delight in Perez, a promising young pitcher; Jason Bay, a young outfielder who may be the National League's rookie of the year; and Jack Wilson, a shortstop who had 200 hits this year. But they also acknowledged that the satisfaction is incomplete.
 ''I hate it when they lose; it ticks me off,'' said Rich Vareha, 42, a manufacturing executive whose family has held season tickets to the Pirates since the 1930's, and who goes to 20 or 30 games a year. ''But I can't get upset about something that I already know is going to happen. I'll be honest. My favorite games are in April or May, because we're still in it.'' There is, acknowledged Dave Littlefield, the general manager of the Pirates, ''a lot of frustration.'' 
 The Pirates, who participated in the first World Series in 1903 (they lost), won three championships between 1960 and 1979, but they have not been in the postseason or even won more games than they lost since 1992.
 Littlefield, 44, arrived midway through 2001, the team's first season in PNC Park and has spent his tenure largely trying to dig the club out of the hole that had been created by the signing of ineffective players to long-term contracts. Even now, the club is saddled with paying catcher Jason Kendall $8.5 million, more than a quarter of its entire payroll, something Littlefield said ''is not a good formula.''
 What the Pirates had planned to do, Littlefield said, was use the formula established by the Cleveland Indians, who in the 1990's parlayed a new downtown ballpark into renewed excitement over the team. The difference, he said, is that when Jacobs Field opened in 1994, the Indians had a core of young players prepared to win, unlike the Pirates of 2001, who lost 100 games.
 That year, excitement over the new park brought in a franchise high attendance of 2.4 million, but by this year, when the team was 72-89, it had sunk to 1.6 million. Season ticket-holders have also dwindled, from a high of 17,000 in 2001 to under 10,000 today, according to the team. 
 Knowledgeable fans are entirely cued in to the economic realities of baseball; they approve, generally, of Littlefield's tenure, which they say is moving the team in a positive direction, along the model of smaller-market clubs in Minnesota, Florida and Oakland, which have achieved success by focusing on the development of young players and signing the occasional free-agent star to boost them when the time is right. They know, for example, that small-market teams do not have the revenue streams from local radio and television that big-market teams do. 
 They know that the so-called luxury tax, which teams are compelled to pay when their payrolls exceed a certain figure ($120.5 million in 2004), has done little to address the disparity. And they know that the players union, which has evolved since the 1970's into a powerful negotiating force, has made it possible for players to become free agents, able to sell their services to the highest bidder just a few years into their careers. It is now nearly impossible for less affluent teams to keep the stars they have or purchase ones they don't. Given these realities, being a small-market baseball fan these days also involves rooting for a team to stay in business. 
 ''I know why Kris Benson and Aramis Ramirez left,'' said Michelle Maloskey, 26, a statistical analyst who attends up to 60 games a year, referring to two promising players recently with the Pirates. ''I can forgive the management. We need revenue-sharing, or a whole lot of luck.''
 The good nature of these fans occasionally erupts into bitterness; ''It's your fault,'' a New Yorker, obviously a stand-in for Yankees owner George Steinbrenner, was told last weekend.
 ''If things don't happen in the next three or four years with the Pirates,'' Vareha said, ''I'll probably think we don't ever have a prayer.''
 For now, the prevailing attitude is philosophical resignation.
 ''I do have times every year where I throw up my hands and swear to become a Yankees fan,'' Maloskey said. But she acknowledged, as Woody Allen once said, ''the heart wants what it wants.''
 ''The Pirates could probably go 0-162, and I'd still be a fan,'' she said. ''Of course, we never think it's going to happen this year. We look down the road a few years and think it's going to happen.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: Jason Verikas, a Pittsburgh bartender, found little customer interest in the World Series. (Photo by Jeff Swenson for The New York Times)
 The Pirates' young pitcher Oliver Perez has become a favorite of the PNC Park fans. (Photo by Gene J. Puskar/Associated Press)

SECTION: Section E; Column 3; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 734 words

HEADLINE: With Election Waning, It's Film Business as Usual 

BYLINE: By NEAL KOCH

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 27 

 BODY:
Politics, and political filmmaking, were the talk of Hollywood this summer, a buzz fueled by the bitterness of the presidential campaign and unexpected box-office success of ''Fahrenheit 9/11.'' But on the eve of the election -- and, more relevantly, as the holidays approach -- studio offerings are reverting to form.
 Universal Pictures' ''Ray,'' expected to appear in about 2,000 theaters, is a musical biography of Ray Charles constructed around dilemmas far more human than political, including his long struggle with drug addiction. ''Birth,'' from New Line Cinema's Fine Line art film unit, is a psychological thriller about a woman, played by Nicole Kidman, wrestling with the notion that a child is her dead husband reincarnate. 
 ''Saw,'' meanwhile, adds a dose of pre-Halloween horror from Lions Gate Entertainment, one of the companies that created a stir by releasing Michael Moore's anti-Bush polemic ''Fahrenheit 9/11.'' 
 ''Escapism is the No. 1 thing people are looking for,'' John Hegeman, Lions Gate's president of worldwide marketing, said in describing the current mood of the national audience. 
 Despite a boom in politically flavored documentaries this year, Mr. Hegeman said his company had none on its schedule for future release. The combined grosses of documentaries released in the first 10 months of 2004 accounted for nearly half the money taken in at the box office by documentaries since 1982, according to boxofficemojo.com. That's a seismic shift, even if the figures are adjusted for inflation. 
 ''You have two choices when there's fear and the unknown'' in society, Mr. Hegeman said. ''You can look to escape or you can look to gain knowledge.''
 Despite much hoopla and considerable media attention, politically oriented films like Paramount's ''Team America: World Police,'' which has taken in only about $23 million so far, and ''The Manchurian Candidate'' (also a Paramount release), with about $66 million in ticket sales, have been disappointments at the box office.
 By contrast, ''Fahrenheit,'' the year's highest-grossing political movie, rose to 12th place in the box-office rankings, setting a record for feature-length documentaries. Yet, the film's $119 million gross remains a small fraction of the dollars taken in by fantasies like DreamWorks' ''Shrek 2,'' which ranks No. 1 to date with $440 million in ticket sales in the United States, or Sony Pictures' ''Spider-Man 2,'' which has taken in $373 million.
 People go to the movies seeking ''mythic solace for reality,'' said Leo Braudy, a professor of American literature and cinema at the University of Southern California. They want, he said, diverting displacements for their anxieties, soothing allegories for their fears.
 Though fierce discussion swirled around issues in ''The Passion of the Christ,'' which so far ranks No. 3 for the year with $370 million in ticket sales, and ''The Day After Tomorrow,'' the global warming disaster movie, with $187 million, neither supports an argument that the public was hungry for political filmmaking.
 And the audience appetite for the year's many documentaries critiquing corporate behavior and the war in Iraq was minuscule, though larger than it has been in the past, pointing to a continuing preference for standard fare. After ''Fahrenheit,'' the next highest grossing documentary, in 106th place according to a boxofficemojo.com ranking, was ''Super Size Me,'' about the fast-food industry and its effects on Americans' health.
 ''Watching someone eat himself to death on hamburgers isn't the biggest audience draw,'' said Peter Biskind, the author of ''Down and Dirty Pictures: Miramax, Sundance and the Rise of Independent Film.''
 Other documentaries that attracted critical attention this year, like ''The Corporation'' and ''The Control Room,'' remained relatively marginal at the box office, as did the director John Sayles's politically driven though fictional ''Silver City,'' which took in only about $1 million in ticket sales. 
 Still, many mainstream Hollywood filmmakers see the latest wave of documentary movies as an encouraging development. 
 ''We may see a marketplace that exists beside narrative moviemaking,'' said Marc Shmuger, vice chairman of Universal Pictures. ''That would be a great thing. I take my kids. To have a generation that can grow up with documentaries as well as with popcorn movies is something that I look forward to.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Larenz Tate, left, and Jamie Foxx, center, in ''Ray,'' which opens on Friday. Based on the life of Ray Charles, the film is more personal than political. (Photo by Nicola Goode/Universal Studios)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SECTION: Section C; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; SMALL BUSINESS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 1395 words

HEADLINE: Moving Ideas Off Campus

BYLINE: By SHIRA BOSS-BICAK

 BODY:
It was the University of Arizona business school's annual Fame or Flame day, and faculty members were rating business ideas pitched by students in an entrepreneurship program as either first rate or feeble.
 To the disappointment of Sara Conrad and Daniel Berger, who were both juniors in the McGuire Entrepreneurship Program three autumns ago, the rating on their idea to develop customer-service kiosks in retail stores was flame. The judges said the project was unfeasible because it would be too easy to copy and would have a low return on investment. ''We had to start all over again,'' Ms. Conrad said.
 To help them, a professor gave them a catalog compiled by the university's Office of Technology Transfer that described dozens of technologies developed in the university's physics, engineering and other scientific laboratories with the potential for being used commercially. 
 The invention that grabbed their interest involved two professors in the medical school who had designed a portable device able to peer into children's eyes and photograph the retinas to detect shaken-baby syndrome. The two students reached an agreement with the researchers to develop a business plan to sell the product. 
 The two students conducted focus groups, analyzed competing products, determined a target price and estimated the market size. The doctors had envisioned selling the device to ophthalmologists; the students added pediatricians, hospitals and emergency rooms as potential customers. 
 ''They had a device that was outstanding,'' Ms. Conrad said. ''Dan and I took what they had and built it a little more to take it to a market they hadn't thought of, and built a financial plan they hadn't thought of.''
 They proposed a price of $5,500, a third of what the least-expensive competing product was selling for. They incorporated the company as Optica Inc. and laid out an exit strategy with details of how the ownership would be divided among the founders if the company was acquired. 
 After Mr. Berger and Ms. Conrad graduated the following year, the doctors sold the prototype and business plan to a local business group in return for shares in the company for themselves as well as Mr. Berger and Ms. Conrad. The company, now called Optica Technologies Inc., expects to have the Prism1 retinal camera instrument on sale within six months.
 ''With the University of Arizona being such a center of research, there are all of these wonderful ideas there,'' Ms. Conrad said. ''We were able to celebrate what we were learning with a real, tangible device to work on. It was just waiting there.''
 Since Congress passed the Bayh-Dole technology-transfer law of 1980, universities have enjoyed the ownership of research breakthroughs that were developed on their campuses with the help of federal financing and have been scrambling to turn them into commercial ventures.
 This transfer of technology from the campus to the capitalist marketplace has been a financial windfall for many schools. The top earners in the 2002 fiscal year, the most recent with figures available from the Association of University Technology Managers in Northbrook, Ill., were Columbia University ($156 million), the University of California system ($82 million) and New York University ($63 million). For all universities, the revenue generated from their researchers' inventions has nearly doubled, to $1.3 billion in 2002 from $699 million five years earlier.
 With the number of patents issued to universities rising to more than 3,600 in 2002 from fewer than 250 before the Bayh-Dole law was passed, the offices of technology transfer at universities are becoming overwhelmed with discoveries to assess and market. And increasingly, they are turning to a previously underused resource to investigate their potential: students in the entrepreneurship departments of their business schools. 
 ''We all want to increase productivity,'' said Ken Smith, interim dean of the Eller College of Management at the University of Arizona. ''We do that by improving the relationship between the scientist and the business entrepreneur.''
 The idea of teaming up with university researchers caught on slowly at first at university entrepreneurial programs, where students were more inclined to pursue their own ideas for companies. But having witnessed young entrepreneurs take a quick route to business success in the Internet boom of the 1990's, some have come to believe that working with ready-made technology is the best way to emulate them in the post-dot-com era, according to Jon Soderstrom, vice president for public policy at the technology managers' group. At the University of Arizona, for example, 12 of the 20 teams currently in the McGuire program are now working on business plans based on technology transfer.
 Universities themselves have started taking equity positions in start-ups or joint ventures founded on university-developed research, instead of charging royalties or licensing fees that young companies often cannot afford. (The state Constitution prohibits the University of Arizona from taking such an ownership stake, but there is a proposal on the November ballot to end the ban.)
 It is not just the financial bonanza that motivates a university to promote its researchers' inventions. These universities are also under pressure to create businesses that generate jobs for the local economy, Mr. Soderstrom said. From 1980 to 2002, more than 4,300 companies were formed based on academic discoveries, according to his group, resulting in the creation of tens of thousands of jobs. Yale University, for example, has spun off 18 bioscience companies in Connecticut. The companies employ more than 880 people and have raised $1.1 billion in public and private financing in the last five years, according to Connecticut United for Research Excellence, a nonprofit organization that promotes the bioscience industry.
 ''This is being multiplied all over the country,'' Mr. Soderstrom said. ''It's not only the Stanfords and the M.I.T.'s anymore.''
 The McGuire program is increasingly working with the university's technology-transfer office to link inventors with students who will develop business plans. Scientists welcome the collaboration, says Jim Jindrick, an entrepreneurship professor at the University of Arizona, because they recognize they lack business and marketing expertise. 
 The university formally recognizes a business plan as proprietary intellectual property, and student teams working with researchers are required to draw up a ''memo of understanding,'' which recognizes each party's stake in the project.
 Cooperation between students and researchers on commercial products is extending beyond the university. This summer, the University of Arizona sent several entrepreneurship students to work at research institutes in Mexico to evaluate technologies developed there. One team of six students ended up scrapping the two business ideas they had come up with and adopting a new technology for detecting oil leaks that was developed at an institute in Ensenada.
 ''We said, 'Hey, why don't we try this idea?''' said Sandy Chen, an M.B.A. student on the team, who is now writing a business plan for a company called Leak Hound that will develop leak-detection equipment. The students are spending the next several months exploring additional applications of the technology, identifying possible markets, and building financial models. 
 It is not just research institutions that are benefiting from working with business schools. Companies, which have long sponsored research by faculty members, are tapping into the brains of business students by sponsoring business-plan competitions. Honeywell started such a competition last year, with an award of $150,000 to the winning team and its school. It gives student teams technologies that are being used in the company's aerospace division and asks them to come up with other possible applications.
 ''We were looking at how we can increase the number of business plans we have to look at,'' said Wayland Adams, a product line manager and chairman of the committee that runs the Honeywell Growth Challenge. Last year's competition generated 14 business plans, each of them being evaluated by Honeywell. ''We might miss things that the students might see,'' Mr. Adams said.


GRAPHIC: Photo: As a student at the University of Arizona, Sara Conrad helped develop a business plan for a medical device invented by researchers. (Photo by David Kadlubowski/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Shares Rally a Second Day, Pushing Dow Past 10,000

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stocks rose sharply yesterday, extending their rally for a second session as investors expressed relief over plummeting oil prices after a government report showed higher inventories of crude oil.
 The Dow Jones industrial average had its second consecutive triple-digit gain, pushing back above the 10,000 level.
 Investors welcomed the government's weekly supply report, although it showed a slide in distillate products. The resulting plunge in crude futures helped equities bounce back from a lackluster open. The question for stock investors, however, is whether oil prices will continue to fall. 
 ''The move in crude doesn't seem to be much on the surface other than pulling back to the lower end of a range on the way up,'' said Todd Clark, head of listed equity trading at Wells Fargo Securities. ''If it were to prove to be a true break, then certainly it's a much better backdrop for equities. I don't know if that's the case, but two strong back-to-back days on the market suggest two things: One, people are underinvested in equities, and two, a lot of people are short the market.''
 Wall Street has grown increasingly anxious about how soaring energy costs might dent consumer spending ahead of what is expected to be a winter that is chillier than normal. 
 With oil prices hovering around $52 a barrel, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries urged the Bush administration to release more oil from the nation's strategic reserve to calm the market. But after the release of the inventory data, light crude for December delivery fell $2.71, to $52.46, in New York.
 The Dow Jones industrial average gained 113.55 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,002.03, after a 138-point rise Tuesday. It was the first time since May 9 and May 12, 2003, that the blue chips have gained more than 100 points in two consecutive sessions. The rise put the index above 10,000 for the first time in two weeks.
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 14.31 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,125.40. The Nasdaq composite index surged 41.20 points, or 2.1 percent, to 1,969.99.
 Analysts welcomed the two-day pop in share prices, saying it was partly the product of oversold conditions. Anxiety over lofty oil prices, rising interest rates, decelerating corporate earnings and the presidential election have weighed heavily on the markets in recent weeks.
 Among Dow components reporting results, Boeing was up 12 cents, to $50.10, after the company beat Wall Street expectations with a 78 percent increase in third-quarter earnings. Boeing, the aerospace giant, was lifted by a strong military business. It also raised its estimate for full-year profits, citing lower-than-anticipated tax expenses.
 Procter & Gamble lost $1.43, or 2.7 percent, to $51.78, despite reporting a 14 percent rise in profits led by growth in developing markets and improved sales in its beauty care and fabric and home care divisions. The company, which makes Tide detergent and Pampers diapers, beat per-share earnings estimates by a penny.
 ATA Holdings, the parent company of the nation's 10th-largest air carrier, was up 27 cents, or 29 percent, to $1.20, after filing for bankruptcy protection and selling off airport slots and other assets to AirTran Airways for $87.6 million. AirTran was up $1.39, or 13.6 percent, at $11.64.
 Treasury prices fell with the 10-year Treasury note down 23/32, to a price of 101 9/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, jumped to 4.09 percent from 4 percent on Tuesday.
 Following are the results of the auction of two-year notes:

The two-year notes mature Oct. 31, 2006.

HEADLINE: Trade With Democracies

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 Re ''Nourishing the Muslim World'' (editorial, Oct. 25):
 You're right that the Bush administration's Middle East policy lacks even the smallest carrot to go with its big stick. But economic cooperation with Pakistan is no place to begin.
 ''The more dependent Pakistanis become on American companies for their livelihood, the less likely they are to join anti-American insurgencies,'' you say. ''Washington can help by encouraging American companies, through import duty relief, to remain in Pakistan.'' 
 Far smarter and more humane than helping another Pakistani autocrat would be a uniform policy of favorable rules for trade with democracies.
 Your argument that trade begets peace is at best a shaky proposition. From Saudi Arabia to Uzbekistan, trade is doing precious little to ameliorate anti-American public opinion.
 Democracy and free expression, on the other hand, are sure-fire harbingers of peaceful coexistence. If all countries knew that trade with the United States were contingent on functioning democracies at home, they would have a political and economic incentive to hold elections. And we would truly be a force for freedom.

James K. Lowden
New York, Oct. 25, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Letter

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
ROSEN, LINCOLN

 BODY:
 ROSEN--Lincoln, 89, died October 20, in Maplewood, NJ. Married for 61 years to his late beloved wife Dorothy, he leaves his children, Bob, Nan and Edward, his grandchildren Jonathan, Melissa, Claire, Lillie, Charlotte and Camille, and his great-grandchildren, Cameron and Spencer. 
He was graduated from Harvard College Class of '35 with high honors and served overseas during W.W. II as a Captain in the U.S. Army, Office of the Adjutant General. A man of high ethical standards and a keen interest in history, economics and international relations, he pursued successful careers in both law and business. A memorial service in celebration of his life will be held in December. Contributions in his memory may be made to the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64 St., New York, NY 10023.

HEADLINE: Boeing and Northrop Say Profits Jumped in Quarter

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Robust demand for military equipment and technology led two arms makers to post higher quarterly profit yesterday, with Boeing reporting a 78 percent jump in earnings despite a decline in commercial airplane revenue. Northrop Grumman also posted higher profit for the third quarter. The companies benefited from increased government military spending on national priorities like homeland security and the war in Iraq. 
 ''It's consistent with the overall outlook in the industry -- strong defense spending,'' said Craig Fraser, an analyst with the debt ratings service Fitch Ratings. 
 ''Appropriations have been passed by Congress, and it's blowing into the actual outlays,'' he said. 
 Mr. Fraser added, however, that strong growth in revenue witnessed in the last few years will probably start to taper off in the next 18 to 24 months. 
 Earnings for Boeing, which makes both commercial and military jets, rose to $456 million, or 56 cents a share, from $256 million, or 32 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue rose 8 percent, to $13.15 billion.
 The company, which is based in Chicago, raised its commercial plane delivery forecast for 2005 and said it still expected 200 firm orders for its newest jetliner, the 7E7, despite higher oil prices that have reduced airline profit globally. 
 ''Boeing's quarter was solid over all, with the excellent performance in defense and a strong number,'' said a Banc of America Securities analyst, Nick Fothergill. Still, he noted, the company did not raise its 2005 profit forecasts, which could ''hint at headwinds'' including pension expenses or possible commercial aircraft deferrals. 
 Boeing's commercial airplanes unit revenue fell 8 percent, to $4.6 billion, as deliveries rose but included more smaller planes. 
 Shares of Boeing gained 12 cents, to $50.10.
 Northrop Grumman, the maker of warships and the Global Hawk spy plane, reported a net profit of $278 million, or 76 cents a share, compared with $184 million, or 50 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. The company, which is based in Los Angeles, noted an 11 percent increase in sales, to $7.41 billion, on strength in its mission systems, integrated systems, ships and space-technology businesses. 
 Shares of Northrop Grumman rose $1.04, or 2.1 percent, to $51.75.

LENGTH: 435 words

HEADLINE: A List of Topics Aimed Squarely at the Middle Class

BYLINE: By JIM RUTENBERG

 BODY:

Senator John Kerry began running this spot in roughly 12 swing states this week. It is to run until Tuesday.

PRODUCER -- Shrum, Devine & Donilon.

THE SCRIPT -- Mr. Kerry says: ''Here's what I've heard from families all across America: You need someone to fight for you. I believe it's the middle class that needs a tax cut. I believe in creating opportunity, so I'll end tax breaks for companies that ship jobs overseas. I'll lower the cost of prescription drugs. And with a strong military and strong alliances, we will defeat terror. I believe our future belongs to freedom, not to fear. I'm John Kerry and I approve this message.''

ON THE SCREEN -- The spot switches between Mr. Kerry's speaking into the camera in front of a flag and an array of images -- a couple holding their baby outdoors, a man raising a flag, a mother pushing her son on a bicycle, a couple helping their toddler read on the living-room couch, hard hats leaving work, a pilot taking off in a fighter jet, a little girl on a swing and, finally, Mr. Kerry and his running mate, Senator John Edwards, clasping hands and holding them up.

ACCURACY -- Mr. Kerry has pledged to lower taxes for the middle class, primarily through tax credits for health care and college tuition, while eliminating President Bush's cuts for the very wealthy. Mr. Bush's campaign has said there is no way that Mr. Kerry can offer middle-class tax relief while staying true to his promise of cutting the deficit in half and offering his ambitious health care plan. Mr. Kerry has proposed closing a loophole that allows companies to defer paying taxes on profits earned overseas, although economists give mixed assessments of how much that would reducing the flow of work to other countries. He has proposed lowering prescription drug costs, in part, by lifting restrictions on imports from Canada and by encouraging more competition from manufacturers of generic drugs.

SCORECARD -- This advertisement represents Mr. Kerry's closing argument to voters. It reprises the themes he has hit all year since the primaries. Voters have heard this appeal, a lot. It makes so many points it could be Exhibit A for critics who say Mr. Kerry's campaign has failed to find one consistent overarching theme. Mr. Kerry is decidedly presidential as he speaks into the camera. And this spot may stand out for its sharp production values and positive theme, rare indeed on television in swing states. Then again, its tone may be negated by Mr. Kerry's other spots -- which are not so positive -- not to mention the wolf pack prowling the airwaves on behalf of Mr. Bush. JIM RUTENBERG

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 28, 2004
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section A; Column 6; National Desk; THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: THE ISSUES; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1294 words

HEADLINE: BUSH HITS BACK AT KERRY CHARGE OVER EXPLOSIVES

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER and JODI WILGOREN; Elisabeth Bumiller reported from Michigan for this article and Jodi Wilgoren from Cedar Rapids, Iowa. David E. Sanger contributed reporting from Washington.

DATELINE: PONTIAC, Mich., Oct. 27 

 BODY:
President Bush broke his silence on Wednesday on the disappearance of 380 tons of explosives in Iraq, accusing Senator John Kerry of making ''wild charges'' about the missing explosives and of ''denigrating the actions'' of troops in the field. 
 Mr. Kerry quickly responded that while ''our troops are doing a heroic job, the president, the commander in chief, is not doing his job.''
 The president's comments, his first on the missing explosives since Mr. Kerry began accusing him on Monday of incompetence in failing to secure Iraq after the American-led invasion, reflected concern in the Bush campaign that the issue could be hurting the president only six days before what is expected to be an extraordinarily close election. 
 The missing explosives were first reported Monday by The New York Times and CBS News, and since then the issue and the possibility that American troops in Iraq let the explosives slip into terrorist hands have dominated the presidential campaign.
 ''Our military is now investigating a number of possible scenarios, including that the explosives may have been moved before our troops even arrived at the site,'' Mr. Bush told thousands of Republicans at an airport rally in Lancaster County, Pa., his first stop of a day that took him through three states. 
 ''This investigation is important and it's ongoing,'' he said, ''and a political candidate who jumps to conclusions without knowing the facts is not a person you want as your commander in chief.''
 The exact timing of the disappearance of the explosives is critical to the political arguments of each campaign. Mr. Kerry's contention that the administration did not adequately secure the country and was unprepared for the war's aftermath presumes that the explosives disappeared after the fall of Saddam Hussein on April 9, 2003, as officials of the interim Iraqi government say.
 If the explosives disappeared before Mr. Hussein fell, as Mr. Bush now says is possible, that would undercut Mr. Kerry's argument and bolster Mr. Bush's contention that his opponent is making charges without all the facts.
 White House officials say Condoleezza Rice, Mr. Bush's national security adviser, was told around Oct. 15 that the explosives had vanished. White House officials say she also informed the president.
 Mr. Kerry, who has accused Mr. Bush of keeping Americans in the dark about the realities of Iraq, spent his day asserting that Mr. Bush had put American troops at enormous risk.
 ''Mr. President, you don't honor our troops or protect them better by putting them in greater danger than they ought to be,'' Mr. Kerry declared to 7,500 people packed in a basketball arena in Rochester, Minn. ''The bottom line is your administration was warned, you were put on notice, but you didn't put these explosives on a priority list.''
 He added: ''Mr. President, for the sake of our brave men and women in uniform, for the sake of those troops that are in danger because of your wrong decisions, you owe America real answers about what happened, not just political attacks.''
 But Mr. Bush, who had let his vice president and aides speak for him on the issue for two days, sharply criticized Mr. Kerry and did not let up at a single campaign stop. The president repeatedly said the senator would say ''almost anything to get elected.'' 
 ''Now, the senator is making wild charges about missing explosives,'' Mr. Bush said time and again in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Michigan.
 He then seized on a remark by Richard C. Holbrooke, a Kerry adviser, who said in an appearance on Fox News on Tuesday that all of the facts about the explosives were not known. 
 ''One of his top foreign policy advisors admits he doesn't know the facts,'' Mr. Bush said. ''He said, 'I don't know the truth.' End quote. Well, think about that. The senator is denigrating the actions of our troops and commanders in the field without knowing the facts.''
 Mr. Bush also criticized Mr. Kerry as ''throwing out the wild claim'' that the American military passed up the chance to capture Osama bin Laden in the caves of Tora Bora, Afghanistan, in fall 2001. 
 ''You might remember that -- he kept repeating that in the debates,'' Mr. Bush said at the Hancock County Fairgrounds in Findlay, Ohio. ''Well, this is unjustified criticism of our military commanders in the field. This is the kind of, worst kind of Monday-morning quarterbacking.'' 
 Mr. bin Laden dropped out of sight in December 2001 during the American-led assault on the Tora Bora region and is still believed to be somewhere along the Pakistani-Afghan border. 
 Mr. Bush asserted that Mr. Kerry had changed his views on Tora Bora with the political winds, and said that in the fall of 2001 the senator said that ''I think we've been doing this pretty effectively, and we should continue to do it that way.''
 Mr. Kerry made the missing explosives his dominant message for the third day running, filling the first half of a 40-minute speech nominally about the economy with an expanding discourse on Iraq. He called the story ''a growing scandal'' and said the public deserved ''a full and honest explanation of how it happened and what the president is going to do about it.'' 
 ''What we're seeing is a White House that is dodging and bobbing and weaving in their usual efforts to avoid responsibility -- just as they've done every step of the way in our involvement in Iraq,'' he said.
 Mr. Kerry and his aides are seeking to use the missing explosives as Exhibit A for their argument that Mr. Bush has shown ''incompetence'' as commander in chief and been unwilling to change course.
 ''Three hundred and eighty tons of explosives that could be in the hands of terrorists and he'd do everything exactly the same way?'' he asked in a high school gym packed with perhaps 2,000 enthusiastic supporters in Sioux City. 
 ''On Iraq, the president doesn't see it, he doesn't see it, so he can't fix it,'' Mr. Kerry said. ''I do see it, and I will fix it.''
 But he softened the assertion he made the day before that the explosives had already been used in attacks against American troops, saying instead that they ''could very likely be in the hands of terrorists and insurgents, who are actually attacking our forces now 80 times a day on average.''
 Mr. Kerry's campaign also released a new advertisement, which aides said would begin running Thursday on national cable stations. It shows images of American flags waving as a narrator intones: ''As we see the deepening crisis and chaos in Iraq, as we choose a new commander in chief and a fresh start, we will always support and honor those who serve.''
 The last time that international inspectors saw the explosives was in early March 2003, days before the American-led invasion. It is possible, inspectors with the International Atomic Energy Agency say, that Saddam Hussein's forces may have tried to move the material out of the 10 huge bunkers at the Al Qaqaa facility where it was stored to save it if the facility was bombed. 
 If so, that would partly support Mr. Bush's contention that the Iraqis could have moved 380 tons of material very far without being detected.
 But Mr. Bush on Thursday did not address a critical issue raised by the discovery of the missed explosives: why American forces were not alerted to the existence of a huge cache of explosives, even though the atomic energy agency and American officials had publicly discussed the threat it posed, and knew its exact location. 
 The commander of the troops that went into the Al Qaqaa facility on the way to Baghdad in early April, Col. Joseph Anderson, of the Second Brigade of the Army's 101st Airborne Division, has said he was never told the site was considered sensitive, or that international inspectors had visited it before the war began.


GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush addressing supporters yesterday at a rally in an airport hangar in Vienna, Ohio. (Photo by Doug Mills/The New York Times)(pg. A26)

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; National Desk; THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: MICHIGAN; Pg. 24

LENGTH: 1059 words

HEADLINE: A Clouding of the Crystal Ball Draws the Candidates Back

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 27 

 BODY:
Two weeks ago, Gov. Jennifer M. Granholm, a Democrat, told a visitor that ''unless something big happens,'' she did not expect John Kerry to return to Michigan before Election Day.
 On Monday night, she stood beside Mr. Kerry in Warren, north of Detroit, in the heartland of the Reagan Democrats two decades ago. At his first event in Michigan since Sept. 15, Mr. Kerry told about 10,000 enthusiastic people who filled the Sports and Expo Center of Macomb County Community College that ''George Bush has failed in the essential task of commander in chief.'' 
 Mr. Kerry is scheduled to appear in Detroit on Saturday. 
 President Bush, who had not been courting Michigan very assiduously either, visited the state on Oct. 6. He was in Pontiac, also near Detroit, on Wednesday and is scheduled to visit Saginaw on Thursday. Very late in the game, Michigan finds itself back in play.
 So what happened? Bill Ballenger, who edits Inside Michigan Politics, a popular newsletter, traces the change to a tracking poll by Steve Mitchell of East Lansing for The Detroit News, which showed Mr. Bush ahead by five percentage points as of last weekend, when other polls showed Mr. Kerry holding a solid lead.
 ''I think Mitchell changed their minds,'' Mr. Ballenger said. ''He worried the Kerry people and he encouraged the Bush people. If Steve hadn't come out with those numbers, the candidates wouldn't have invested any more time in Michigan.''
 Governor Granholm offered a different interpretation. She conceded that she, too, had been surprised, but she said the president was ''hoping to do something here that would make up for his difficulties in other states and to divert Kerry from other states where he needs to campaign.'' 
 It would not work, the governor insisted. Mr. Kerry will win Michigan comfortably, she said, though ''it's no time to take it for granted.''
 Republicans dispute that, contending that Mr. Kerry is hostile to the interests of the auto industry and thus to the state's working men and women. They look for a tight finish, although some concede that in a state where the Democrats have prevailed in the last three presidential elections (Al Gore won by more than five percentage points), Mr. Kerry is probably the favorite.
 ''It's amazing to us that the Kerry campaign has finally discovered Michigan,'' said John Truscott, the chief spokesman for the Bush campaign in the state.
 Without question, most of the news developments in recent days would seem to favor Mr. Kerry, including the loss of 15,000 payroll jobs here in September alone, while some states were picking up jobs. Between January 2001, when Mr. Bush took office, and June 2004, Michigan's unemployment rate rose 2.4 percentage points, more than in any other swing state.
 On Sunday, in an editorial under the headline ''For President: None of the Above,'' the powerful Detroit News, a self-described voice of conservatism that has never backed a Democrat for president, withheld its endorsement from Mr. Bush, a near-seismic event in terms of Michigan politics.
 One positive sign for Mr. Bush has been the recent finding in national polls that as many as 18 percent of black voters might back him, compared with 9 percent four years ago. Blacks are a crucial part of the Democratic coalition in Detroit and other major Michigan cities. But the president appears to have lost ground significantly among Michigan Muslims, concentrated in Detroit and Dearborn, many of whom say their civil liberties have been eroded in the war on terror. 
 David Rohde, a professor of political science at Michigan State University, said he had ''seen nothing and heard nothing'' to explain why Michigan should suddenly ''lurch.'' But the candidates' own internal polls, he added, ''must show the race tightening in the last days, or they wouldn't be coming here.''
 What Professor Rohde called ''the growing problems with sampling that we are experiencing nationwide'' might well have skewed Mr. Mitchell's results, he suggested.
 But Mr. Mitchell, who has a strong track record in Michigan, said, ''I don't have any particular explanation for why our results differ.'' He alone among local pollsters forecast Mr. Gore's victory here almost exactly, and he projected Ms. Granholm as the victor in 2002 when several others did not.
 In polling completed on Oct 21, Epic-MRA, Mr. Mitchell's main rival among Michigan pollsters, showed Mr. Kerry ahead by six percentage points, 49 to 43. In polling completed two days later, a Republican pollster, Scott Rasmussen, gave Mr. Kerry a lead of five points, 51 to 46. And in polling through Tuesday, still another pollster, John Zogby, made the Kerry lead five percentage points, 49 to 44.
 Ed Sarpolus, one of the principals in Epic-MRA, said he had seen ''no sign at all of a Bush lead in any of the Congressional district polls he had access to, although he, too, described the race as ''tightening, in the usual pattern.'' He said he had been disturbed by ''the fact that Steve's younger voters were overwhelmingly pro-Bush,'' while most samplings, here and elsewhere, have found them strongly pro-Kerry.
 The first report on Mr. Mitchell's survey, published in The News last Tuesday, reflected interviews with 400 likely voters and gave Mr. Bush the lead, 46.9 percent to 42.7 percent -- a lead of 4.2 percentage points, well within the margin of sampling error. Mr. Mitchell himself told the paper he was surprised by the result, because it differed so sharply from other polls' findings. Still, by Sunday, The News was reporting a Bush lead of five points, with 200 more voters in the sample.
 In its editions on Wednesday, The News reported a lead of 45 percent to 44 percent for Mr. Kerry, not Mr. Bush, based on a rolling sample of 600 voters interviewed on Wednesday, Thursday and Monday nights: a statistical dead heat.
 Why the turnaround? As is usual with tracking polls, the oldest data, from Monday, Oct. 18, which was a high-scoring night for Mr. Bush, were discarded, and new results, from last Monday, when Mr. Kerry had ''an unusually strong night'' following his widely publicized rally in Warren, were added, Mr. Mitchell explained.
 If, in fact, the campaigns based strategic decisions on the initial Detroit News numbers, this may prove a seminal case of the perils of relying on polls, especially the earliest results of tracking polls.

SECTION: Section C; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; Economic Scene; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 1093 words

HEADLINE: Where economists stand, or don't stand, on the issue of corporate scandals.

BYLINE: By Jeff Madrick. 
Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine, and he teaches at Cooper Union and New School University. His most recent book is ''Why Economies Grow'' (Basic Books/Century Foundation). E-mail: challenge@mesharpe.com.

 BODY:
WHEN you think about the economic issues facing the next president, you have to wonder why either candidate wants the job. There are the outsize budget deficits, high levels of private debt, a soaring trade deficit, growing numbers of Americans without health insurance, a possible bust in the housing bubble and an expansion that is not creating enough jobs and is probably already tapering to a crawl.
 But at least these issues have come up in the campaign. One issue that has not is the corporate scandals that rocked the nation two years ago. Now Eliot Spitzer, New York's attorney general, has uncovered another dark hole of apparent corporate wrongdoing among the nation's largest, most respected insurance companies. 
 It is fair to ask where the federal government has been. But it is also fair to ask where the economists are. 
 ''The economists are leaving this mostly to the law schools,'' said the Yale economist Robert J. Shiller, author of ''Irrational Exuberance,'' the best seller about the overvalued stock market. ''They are not comfortable with issues concerning human behavior.''
 To be a little more precise, there is a lot of economic research in the field, but it often reduces behavior to a set of predictable possibilities. ''They see the organization as merely a nexus of individual contracts,'' complains Rakesh Khurana, an assistant professor of organizational behavior at the Harvard Business School and author of ''Searching for a Corporate Savior'' (Princeton University Press, 2002). ''This is a highly unrealistic description and has no support in any social science other than economics.'' 
 Of course, knowing economists, that might make them proud. But the result is that many economists lean against financial regulation in general and have been in favor of only modest reforms in the wake of the scandals. 
 The general argument they make is that free markets check corrupt behavior more than is realized, the courts can handle other disputes, and government regulations often serve business interests anyway.
 To David A. Skeel, a University of Pennsylvania law professor, however, reforms are badly needed to correct conflicts of interest and abuses in executive compensation. And the opportunity to adopt them does not come around often.
 Interest in any serious reform almost fizzled, in fact, after the Enron scandal in late 2001, and was revived only with revelations that WorldCom misstated profits by roughly $11 billion. 
 ''After WorldCom, President Bush made a speech saying it was just a few bad apples,'' Mr. Skeel says. ''But that didn't go over well in the financial community any longer. They wanted firmer action. Finally, he supported the Sarbanes-Oxley bill.'' 
 Mr. Skeel and others say Sarbanes-Oxley, the principal reform measure to come out of the scandals, is inadequate. It largely calls for new disclosure requirements and more independent auditors. In a new book, ''Icarus in the Boardroom'' (Oxford University Press), Mr. Skeel proposes a number of new reforms, including more stringent demands for independent auditing. He would require auditors to be assigned by the stock exchanges themselves. 
 The true measure of the lame regulatory environment, however, has been the lack of action, either by the accounting standards organization or the government, to restrain the stock options so generously given to top executives. 
 Academic research strongly supported aligning executives' incentives with rising stock prices. But when options gave them the right to buy shares in the future at a given price, executive income soared. 
 In 1991, the average chief executive of a large company earned 140 times the pay of an average worker. By 2003, it was 500 times. 
 Lucian A. Bebchuk, professor of law, economics and finance at Harvard Law School, and Yaniv Grinstein of Cornell Business School find that a proper calculation of the total compensation of the top five executives of all companies, including salaries, stock options and pensions, came to a stunning $260 billion over the last 10 years. 
 This might be justifiable if there were ample evidence it was based on market performance or corporate earnings. But Mr. Bebchuk and Mr. Grinstein find that since the early 1990's pay has risen about twice as fast as the market value of stocks and much faster than corporate income. Total compensation was 5.7 percent of total corporate income in the early 1990's; it is now under 10 percent. 
 Mr. Bebchuk concludes that, contrary to arguments made by many economists, compensation agreements between boards and high-level executives are not done at arm's length; managers have a great deal of influence over what they get paid. Moreover, the options so widely advocated by these economists can often induce misbehavior as executives misstate earnings and liabilities, and take on dubious projects, to pump up stock prices in the short run. 
 In a new book, ''Pay Without Performance'' (Harvard University Press), Mr. Bebchuk, along with another law professor, Jesse M. Fried of the University of California, Berkeley, propose reforms to link compensation and performance more closely. Like many other observers, they want options listed on financial statements to make compensation transparent. 
 But they also say directors' compensation should be tied to stock prices. Most important, they argue, making directors more independent, as the New York Stock Exchange now requires, is not enough. They want shareholders to have far more power to vote for new directors, and thereby make directors more accountable. Now, access to the corporate ballot is limited. 
 In the meantime, it is Mr. Spitzer, not Washington, who keeps up the most pressure on corporations. Mr. Spitzer got investment banks to agree to separate stock analysis from corporate underwriting. Analysts were producing misleading research to win investment banking business for their firms. And while the Securities and Exchange Commission is issuing some new requirements, Frank Partnoy, a law professor at the University of San Diego, says corporate whistle-blowers now tend to go to New York, not Washington. 
 The next president may be able to generate the enthusiasm needed for serious reform. But given the near silence during the campaign, only another major round of scandals may accomplish that. 
 At least there are cracks in the economists' armor. Some, usually at the law and business schools, are making economically sound cases for new rules and regulations. Whoever is president in the next four years can use some fresh advice.
