PUB-DATE: October 30, 2004
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section B; Column 3; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 1391 words

HEADLINE: Giving Flamenco Song a Global Accent

BYLINE: By ERIC MARX

DATELINE: BARCELONA 

 BODY:
In the late hours of a cool August evening, Ojos de Brujo (Wizard Eyes) takes the stage overlooking the cordoned-off streets of this city's Gracia district. Playing in front of its hometown fans, this eight-member group blasts a spirited mix of highly syncopated flamenco rhythms, hip-hop backbeats, Afro-Cuban rumba and turntable scratches that speak to Barcelona's multiethnic culture of new ideas and new sounds.
 Like the wailing flamenco music from which the band draws its core inspiration, Ojos's lyrics bleed with outrage at an uncaring world riddled with injustice. 
 ''The backpack we carry is loaded full of rocks, it comes from the abyss, this bad condition,'' the lead singer Marina Abad, known as La Canillas (''the shins''), raps in ''Ventilator R-80,'' only to break into a euphoric call to rejoice in rumba and the traditional flamenco rhythm buleria.
 While flamenco fusion has existed for more than 20 years -- melding salsa, jazz, reggae and rock-- few bands have tried to incorporate as many competing rhythms onto a single soundstage. Ojos de Brujo fuses everything from North African and Indian drumbeats to punk, heavy metal and funk, arguing through expert musicianship for a new flamenco hybrid, heedless of categories. 
 The crowd erupts in dance and precision hand-clapping, the music reflecting the cultural fusion in their lives, the words giving voice to their frustration. It's a giant party, another huge turnout, and yet this benefit for the city's squatters offers hardly any remuneration for the band, which Xavi Turull, its founding percussionist and manager, said had to cut its own path through an inhospitable marketplace and a flamenco establishment fearful of marginalization.
 ''We don't mind if music loses its identity because we believe, in reality, music has never had a real identity but has always been evolving,'' Mr. Turull said. He likened flamenco's evolution to that of American blues and its flowering into rhythm and blues, rock 'n' roll and soul.
 Ojos de Brujo also has its share of American fans. Since the release of the band's latest album, ''Bari'' (World Village), in May, it has managed to sell 20,000 CD's in the United States. The album was briefly in the Top 10 on Billboard's World Music Chart, and remained in the top 15 through mid-August on the C.M.J. (College Music Journal) World Music Chart. This success is a result of college radio stations' playing Ojos's music and the band's performances at a few well-chosen American concerts: over the summer it played at Central Park SummerStage in New York, and it recently made several appearances in Los Angeles. It will return to California for a performance at a music awards ceremony at Vault 350 in Long Beach on Nov. 24 and a concert at the Brava Theater Center in San Francisco on Nov. 28. 
 Mr. Turell says that traditional music, roots music, can maintain its essence through fusion if the resulting hybrid is the work of musicians who understand and live the music from which they borrow.
 ''We're using flamenco, but together with other music, making it more rich,'' he said, ''and through evolution you probably lose a little bit, but on the other side, you always keep the feeling or, what some would say, the rhythm.''
 Mr. Turull is an important figure on the flamenco scene, having fused flamenco with Indian music and Latin rhythms in Amalgama, a groundbreaking fusion band of the 1980's. Ms. Abad hails from a feminist-inspired performance art background but grew up in Valencia, jamming with flamenquillos (flamenco lovers), who taught her the rhythms. DJ Panko, another band member, was a bass player in a group that mixed pop with flamenco. And the guitarist Ramon Gimenez, the only Gypsy in the band, has discovered everything from hip-hop to funk and soul but says his roots lie with the more traditional flamenco that he grew up playing with his family.
 Still, for flamenco purists, the music is defined by the performer's ethnic origin -- Andalucian Gypsy -- and is fixed in its styles, only mutating with the inclusion of new instruments, and only when they are introduced by Gypsies. 
 The problem, says Rafael Manjavacas Lara, publisher of the respected flamenco Web site deflamenco.com, is that to the uninitiated, Ojos's music is flamenco. 
 ''Good fusion/bad fusion is too subjective a topic to pronounce upon, except to say it can be judged as any other music,'' he said. ''This is unlike flamenco, which cannot be judged simply as 'music,' since it values certain qualities above others: rhythm over voice, feeling over technique. To do flamenco, you must live it and have the background, either learned or acquired at home. Fusion simply requires being a good musician. This is why so many foreign musicians embrace and enjoy fusion, but foreigners don't really do flamenco, except in rare cases.''
 A positive outcome of fusion is the attraction of new people to traditional flamenco music, but that just isn't happening, Mr. Manjavacas Lara added. 
 ''This is the bankrupt logic of the fusion people,'' he said. ''In 40 years' experience, I have never seen anyone pass from fusion or other derivatives to flamenco, always the reverse, and almost always for economic as opposed to artistic reasons.''
 Indeed, while more new music is being created today, most traditional forms are disappearing, said Timothy D. Taylor, the ethnomusicologist and author of ''Global Pop: World Music, World Markets.'' But that doesn't fundamentally debilitate flamenco as a meaningful cultural form, he said, even if vast numbers of consumers think of it as world music.
 ''Some artists have sought to keep their music 'pure,' but whatever the 'pure' is thought to be is always changing,'' Mr. Taylor explained. ''It's an endless process, endlessly discussed and argued with by musicians. Some countries are establishing Western-style music conservatories to preserve traditional musics, which I think is generally a mistake, since it freezes music instead of letting it continue to change, as all traditional musics have always done.''
 What is new, he argued, is the intensity and pace of that evolution and the degree to which ''commodification,'' as he calls it, separates the sound from the maker -- repackaging it in the form of pop and dance samples, television advertising music or film soundtracks.
 Still, world music is thriving, said Ian Anderson, editor of fRoots magazine (formerly Folk Roots), pointing to bands like Ojos. Their tendency to sell out major concert halls puts them in the same league as any major English-speaking band on an independent label, he said.
 ''The most exciting music around these days is made by people who understand their own roots but are experimenting in pushing their music onward, adding bits that work, or finding out that some things don't work and disregarding them,'' Mr. Anderson said. For those bands, he added, there's a huge, diverse audience waiting to be tapped.
 Mr. Turull said it was possible to engage the music industry and not compromise your principles. He said that Ojos had declined alcoholic beverage and cigarette endorsement deals that would have resulted in its music's being played at bull fights and soccer stadiums and that it had refused to perform at Barcelona's yearlong Forum 2004 cultural exchange conference because the band members objected to corporate real estate developers' efforts to use the event as a pretext for gentrification. 
 Consequently, Ojos finds itself still struggling to pay back the investors that helped the band produce and market ''Bari,'' even though the album has sold more than 150,000 copies -- a phenomenal accomplishment for a band without a major- or independent-label contract.
 Touring with an eight-piece band is expensive, Mr. Turull explained; when the videographer, flamenco dancers, backup singers and road crew are all counted, the operation is hardly a money-making enterprise.
 Sure, it would be easier to accept sponsors, he said, but then the band would not be keeping its commitment to the music and its fans.
 ''It's not so easy to be independent and alternative,'' grumbled Mr. Turull, who, with the other members in the band, performed at the August benefit because of the group's affiliation with the city's squatters.
 But it is possible to create your own pathway, he said. It just might take a little longer.


GRAPHIC: Photo: Marina Abad leading Ojos de Brujo (Wizard Eyes), from Barcelona, at Central Park SummerStage in July. (Photo by Jack Vartoogian/Frontrowphotos) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 1309 words

HEADLINE: A Museum In Chicago Is Closing Its Doors

BYLINE: By DAVID BERNSTEIN

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 30 

 BODY:
The Terra Museum of American Art will close permanently on Halloween, leaving only the ghosts of Edward Hopper and Winslow Homer, among others, to haunt one of this city's most ambitious if underappreciated art institutions. 
 Last year, the trustees of the Terra Foundation for the Arts, which runs the museum (and another in Giverny, France), decided to close its foundering institution here and place its entire collection of 350 works on paper, plus 50 of its most important paintings by American masters, with the Art Institute of Chicago on 15-year loan. 
 The Art Institute will show the Terra holdings, including treasures like ''Gallery of the Louvre'' by Samuel F.B. Morse and George Caleb Bingham's ''Jolly Flatboatmen,'' beginning in April. 
 The Terra Museum's failure to draw crowds even after effectively eliminating its admission charge a few years ago led to the decision to close. But in its final days, throngs of 11th-hour art lovers have descended upon the narrow building in the Magnificent Mile shopping district on Michigan Avenue to say good-bye to the art collection, which was assembled over 50 years by Daniel J. Terra, a chemicals magnate, who died in 1996. 
 Uri Toch, 46, a librarian from Skokie, Ill., and his wife, Susan Kaplan-Toch, 45, also a librarian, took time off from work the other day to visit the trove of Whistlers, Cassatts and Copleys displayed in one of its farewell exhibitions, ''A Narrative of American Art.'' As regular visitors, the couple lamented the loss of the small institution. 
 ''This museum has meant a lot to us,'' Mr. Toch said, somberly. ''We had to come this week.'' Ms. Kaplan-Toch added: ''I'm heartbroken, I'm really sad. Daniel Terra would be turning in his grave. This is really scandalous.'' 
 But most Chicagoans, including members of the city's art establishment, have greeted the closing with a collective shrug, even though it leaves the city with only two major art museums: the Art Institute and the Museum of Contemporary Art. 
 ''We're all more or less guilty for not supporting it,'' said Thomas McCormick, a Chicago-based art dealer. ''But by next week, will anybody really notice that it's gone?''
 Marshall Field V, chairman and president of the Terra Foundation for the Arts, acknowledged that public indifference had made the trustees' decision last year an easier one. The sprawling, encyclopedic Art Institute attracts more than 1.3 million visitors each year. By comparison, the Terra Museum, located within a mile of the Art Institute, draws only about 85,000. 
 ''I didn't feel that the vast majority of Chicago really gave a damn one way or another,'' he said. ''What Dan chose to collect -- and actually, I do, too -- was in a field that didn't particularly resonate with people.''
 Mr. Terra, a son of Italian immigrants who made a fortune in printing inks and photographic chemicals, at first collected Impressionist landscapes by European artists. But he soon turned his attention to American art, concentrating on American Impressionism and the Hudson River School. 
 He amassed a collection of some 700 paintings, prints, drawings, sculptures and photographs estimated to be worth $175 million today, though not all were regarded as first rate, and founded the museum in 1980 in a former flower shop in Evanston, Ill. He grabbed the attention of the art world in 1982 when he bought Morse's ''Gallery of the Louvre'' for $3.25 million, at the time a record for an American painting.
 Five years later he relocated the museum to an office building on Michigan Avenue, awkwardly set between a shoe store and a specialty popcorn shop. With only 8,000 square feet available for galleries, the museum lacked the space needed to become a major presence. There was no auditorium, restaurant or cafe, and no parking lot. Its small storefront gift shop, which doubled as the main entrance, confusing passersby. 
 In 1992, Mr. Terra opened the Musee d'Art Americain in Giverny, France, the colorful village to which budding American Impressionists made pilgrimages to commune with Claude Monet, as throngs do today to see the Monet home and gardens. 
 Before his death, at 85, the collector had discussed placing his collection at the Art Institute, Mr. Field said. But he added that Mr. Terra ''wanted his own name on Michigan Avenue,'' and ''he didn't care what it cost or what the economics were.'' 
 A few years ago, the Terra Museum was shaken by a lengthy legal battle after two former trustees sued to keep the museum and its foundation, which has an endowment of $220 million, in Chicago. They asserted that Judith Terra, Mr. Terra's second wife, planned to move the collection to Washington, where she lives.
 A settlement reached in 2001 required the foundation to remain in the state for 50 years and the art collection to stay in the Chicago area, though it allowed the museum to move from its current location. Another provision of the agreement called for replacing all of the foundation's board members, including Ms. Terra. 
 ''The museum fund simply didn't have enough money to support two museums -- and maybe not even one,'' Mr. Field said. ''We were just eating ourselves alive, so within six or seven years, if we had gone the way we were going, we'd have been out of business and there'd be nothing.'' 
 Soon the foundation's entire collection will be available on a new Web site (www.terraamericanart.org), said Elizabeth Glassman, director of the museum, who will remain with the foundation, along with nine other museum employees. 
 More important, she said, closing the struggling museum will free up about $4 million a year from foundation's assets, enabling it to expand its research, educational and fellowship programs in Chicago and internationally. The foundation has already announced a joint exhibition next year in Paris, at the Louvre, and additional programs for its museum in Giverny. 
 The move, Mr. Field said, will ensure greater visibility for the collection, which the foundation could never achieve on its own. ''Unless you've got the Mona Lisa and that's your painting in your small museum, it just doesn't make it in the great competition for people's time,'' he said.
 Ms. Glassman acknowledged that the decision to close offered tangible losses as well as significant gains. 
 ''There's sadness that a museum is closing,'' she said. ''But the mistake that some people make is that they think, 'O.K., now the museum's closing and the collection is going to be on loan at the Art Institute and that's the end of the story.' But, no, we look at this as a transition, a new beginning, not the ending.'' 
 She read aloud a portion of the foundation's mission statement that was posted on her office wall: '''Dedicated to fostering exploration, understanding and enjoyment of the visual arts in the United States.'' 
 ''Our mission doesn't say, 'Run a stand-alone museum,''' she said. 
 But for Chicagoans mourning the loss of a hometown cultural gem, this comes as small consolation. 
 ''It's not a good thing to centralize culture,'' said Edward Lifson, host of ''Hello Beautiful!,'' an arts series on WBEZ, Chicago Public Radio. ''Having everything under the roof of the Art Institute is not a good thing.'' 
 James Yood, a Chicago-based art critic, agrees: ''When it comes to art museums, you never get addition by subtraction,'' he said.
 ''To me this is a huge blow to the ego of the city,'' Mr. Lifson said. ''If Chicago can't support a museum for American art, that's embarrassing. What are we saying about ourselves?'' 
 Paradoxically, another of the Terra Museum's farewell exhibitions, ''Chicago Modern, 1893-1945: Pursuit of the New,'' was one of its most critically acclaimed and well-attended shows. The show is a tribute to the artistic achievements of Chicagoans and to the city itself, which, as it happened, never truly embraced the museum.


GRAPHIC: Photo: The Terra Museum of American Art in Chicago is closing tomorrow because of lack of attendance. (Photo by Peter Thompson for The New York Times)(pg. B12)

HEADLINE: Health Care and the Free Market

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 About six years ago I went over the economic feasibility of a universal Medicare program with three distinguished economists using a system that limited the total cost of the program to 14 percent of gross national product, slightly lower than the figure for current spending. 
 This would save billions of dollars, eliminate the insurance company middleman, allow people to choose their doctors and slightly lower the annual income of the highest-paid doctors. It would be a boon to small business and middle-income earners and could be put into place quickly. 
 We could all be much more confident of the quality of our care, and the United States would finally be a ''developed'' nation in terms of health care.

Charles M. Plotz, M.D.
Brooklyn, Oct. 29, 2004

The writer is professor of medicine, State University of New York at Brooklyn.

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: In Atlanta, Relief That the Hometown Airline Remains Aloft

BYLINE: By ARIEL HART

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Oct. 29 

 BODY:
Nita Bertsche, who lives a few miles north of Atlanta and has been flying on Delta Air Lines for 20 years, was relieved this week to hear that the airline had, for now at least, managed to avoid bankruptcy.
 ''For people in Atlanta, it's sort of the airline of choice,'' she said. But then asked what she would do if she no longer had the option of flying Delta, she quickly replied: ''I'll keep flying. I'll find something else.'' 
 Across Atlanta, which has grown along with its hometown airline for more than half a century, Delta's travails -- and its decision late Wednesday not to file for bankruptcy protection -- are being met with a similar mix of support and realism about the airline industry's struggles. In fact, it is not new news that a low-fare airline, AirTran, has been eating into Delta's long dominance. 
 Jose Gonzalez, 43, who works for Delta helping answer passenger questions, said he was laid off for a brief period several years ago. ''I'm not worried,'' he said. ''When I came here, I was looking for a job, and I can look for a job again.''
 The airline is the Atlanta region's largest private employer, providing about 30,000 jobs directly and supporting perhaps twice that indirectly, said Mark Vitner, a Wachovia economist who tracks the region, and who spoke on his way to a Delta flight at the Atlanta airport. It is the dominant carrier at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, which is the world's busiest airport, with 79 million passengers last year. It is, as Mr. Vitner said, ''probably the single most important economic development engine in Atlanta.'' 
 But the airport's very success has become a challenge for Delta, as other carriers stand waiting to pick up any business. ''One of Delta's problems,'' Mr. Vitner added, ''is that their No.1 hub is seeing significant competition from just about every carrier in existence.''
 The city is now the air hub of the South, just as its status as a rail hub in the Civil War made its destruction a must on Sherman's march to the sea. The airline, which started out in the South with crop-dusting planes to fight the boll weevils attacking the cotton in the Mississippi Delta, moved its headquarters to Atlanta in 1941.
 Mayor Shirley Franklin said Atlanta and Delta have a symbiotic relationship. ''If you believe as I do that the airport has been an engine, a generator, a catalyst for economic growth, Delta Airlines has played an integral role in the development of Atlanta, Ga., and the region,'' she said.
 ''Atlanta's economic success is tied to Delta's economic success,'' she added. ''We care very much how they come through this.''
 Her comments were echoed by economists. ''On one level, you think about a company like Delta in terms of what do they mean for employment,'' said Dr. Roger Tutterow, chairman of the economics department at Kennesaw State University, just north of Atlanta.
 ''But I also think it would be hard to overstate what it has meant for Atlanta's growth to have one of the three largest international airlines based here in Atlanta. Not only in terms of visibility, but also the availability of flights has made it a much more attractive destination for corporate relocations.''
 Regionally, Dr. Tutterow said, ''it has been a pillar for economic development throughout the South.'' 
 Still, bargain carriers have chipped away at Delta. AirTran has made its major operations base here, and recently opened a $17 million maintenance hangar at the airport. It will welcome the opportunity to expand into Delta's markets, Dr. Tutterow said. 
 That others might pick up the slack in travel has been no immediate comfort for places like Fayette County, south of Atlanta near the airport and home to more than 3,500 Delta employees with an average salary of $93,000.
 ''They're 7 percent of our work force,'' said Brian Cardoza, president and chief executive of the county's development authority. The psychological impact of a Delta bankruptcy would be huge, he said.
 But for today, he said, ''Yeah, there's relief.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Delta's problems have raised concerns in Atlanta, where the airline has its headquarters and is the region's largest private employer. (Photo by John Bazemore/Associated Press) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Growth Rate Of Economy Edged Higher Over Summer

BYLINE: By EDUARDO PORTER

 BODY:
The economy picked up a little more speed during the summer quarter from July through September, expanding at a 3.7 percent annual rate, the government reported yesterday. 
 The growth in the nation's output of goods and services, according to the Commerce Department's initial estimate, exceeded the 3.3 percent rate registered in the second quarter -- when the economy was held back by a surge in energy prices, which took a big bite out of the budgets of American households and dented consumer spending. 
 But despite the third-quarter improvement, some analysts and business executives expressed worries over the economy's vulnerabilities. Growth could be crimped by everything from continued high oil prices and lackluster income gains to the deepening trade and balance of payments deficits. 
 ''The numbers are good,'' said William Zadrozny, chief executive of Siemens Financial Services. ''But there is a lot of uncertainty weighing down on the economy.''
 Coming out just days before the election, the report set off a final political skirmish between supporters of both presidential candidates over economic figures.
 The Bush administration hailed the figures as validation of its tax-cutting strategy. ''G.D.P. continues to grow above the average of the 1970's, 80's and 90's,'' Treasury Secretary John W. Snow said, ''while the unemployment rate remains below the average for those decades.''
 Advocates for Senator John Kerry, however, argued that Mr. Bush's economic track record was disappointing. ''It's not the kind of growth that's getting us jobs,'' said Representative Pete Stark of California, the senior Democrat on the Congressional Joint Economic Committee. ''We've got slow growth and giving tax cuts to the rich is not the way to solve it.''
 Beyond the political sparring, the latest economic evidence actually depicts a decidedly mixed picture. Concern over high energy prices and tepid job growth led to a fall in the University of Michigan's index of consumer sentiment in October, the third monthly decline. But the Chicago Purchasing Managers Index, a measure of manufacturing strength, rose in the month.
 The data released by the Commerce Department showed an economy at a crossroads -- still healthy but propped up by some factors that are expected to diminish. 
 ''We are far from the robust pace that we had a year or two ago,'' said Rich Yamarone, director of economic research at Argus Research. ''But basically the economy is running at a comfortable pace. I suspect we will still lose some growth.''
 The report underscored the importance of consumer borrowing and spending in keeping the economy moving. 
 Nearly nine-tenths of the economic expansion in the third quarter was accounted for by growth in personal consumption expenditures. Purchases of durable goods sped ahead by 16.8 percent, the fastest pace in over a year. Car sales alone, spurred by auto industry incentives aimed at clearing out dealer lots of 2004 models, made up more than a quarter of the growth recorded by the economy.
 ''The American consumer is the spender of last resort for the world economy,'' said Richard B. Hoey, chief economist and chief investment strategist of the Dreyfus Corporation.
 Business investment remained robust, growing by nearly 12 percent, a little less than in the second quarter. But inventories declined -- a potential sign of business concern over the strength of future demand.
 And international trade continued to exert a drag on the economy, as exports grew substantially less than imports.
 Any economic deceleration could be relatively smooth, though. Richard D. Rippe, chief economist of the Prudential Equity Group, expected that in coming quarters the economy could settle in at a rate of growth from 3 percent to 3.5 percent -- a pace considered close to the nation's long-term potential.
 This benign outlook is supported by moderate inflation. The index of personal consumption expenditures minus food and energy increased at a mere 0.7 percent annual rate, its lowest quarterly increase in over four decades. That strengthened expectations that the Federal Reserve will stay on a path of moderate and gradual interest rate increases.
 The biggest risk to this outlook, analysts said, is the question mark over energy costs. ''What oil prices do going forward is critical,'' Mr. Rippe said.
 But other sources of uncertainty remain as well. Employment growth is still lackluster. Business investment could also slow next year as the corporate tax break that allowed faster depreciation -- a big incentive to bring planned investment forward -- phases out at the end of 2004.
 The widening trade gap and its financial twin, the budget deficit, are also adding to a sense of unease in many corporate suites. ''Businesses are still concerned that there could be a shock to the system,'' Mr. Zadrozny of Siemens Financial said. 
 In another sign of economic stress, The Wall Street Journal reported that big auto dealers have been putting pressure on auto companies like Ford and General Motors to cut back further on car production.
 Perhaps most importantly, consumers may have squeezed themselves into an excessively tight spot. Even as the spending accelerated in the third quarter, income growth slowed, leading to a fall in the personal savings rate to 0.4 percent of disposable income. That is the lowest ever.

HEADLINE: Marriage Between Gays Becomes Issue In Campaigns

BYLINE: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

 BODY:
The debate over same-sex marriage is reverberating through a handful of swing states and at least five Congressional races where campaign advertisements are attacking Democratic candidates for supporting for gay rights.
 In one vivid example, Mike Liffrig, a Republican candidate for Senate in North Dakota, has paid for television advertisements implying that Senator Byron L. Dorgan may support polygamy. The commercial displays a series of brides and grooms kissing at an altar being replaced by two men, and then by two men and a woman. 
 ''With Senator Dorgan now supporting gay marriages -- or whatever -- you can kiss our North Dakota values goodbye,'' the narration says. 
 Barry Piatt, a spokesman for Mr. Dorgan, said the advertisements were inaccurate and ''beyond the pale,'' arguing that they ultimately hurt the challenger's campaign.
 Although Mr. Dorgan opposes amending the United States Constitution to block same-sex marriage, he voted for the Defense of Marriage Act, which permits states to refuse to recognize such marriages performed in other states, and he also supports a ballot measure for an amendment to the state's Constitution blocking same-sex marriage. 
 Americans United to Preserve Marriage, an independent campaign organization set up by the Christian conservative Gary Bauer, has run commercials in Ohio, Michigan and Pennsylvania and on the Fox News Channel criticizing Senator John Kerry, the Democratic presidential candidate, for opposing the proposed federal amendment and voting against the Defense of Marriage Act. (Mr. Kerry has said he opposes same-sex marriage, but considers both the act and the proposed constitutional amendment needlessly divisive.)
 Mr. Bauer's group has also run advertisements in an Oklahoma Congressional race. The National Republican Congressional Committee has paid to run advertisements accusing Democratic representatives of supporting same-sex unions in Texas, Indiana, and Georgia, where the Representative Max Burns, a Republican, paid for one against his Democratic opponent, John Barrow as well.
 ''It's an issue that plays in some districts and it's a valid issue to discuss,'' said Carl Forti, a spokesman for the Republican committee.
 Roman Levit, Mr. Barrow's campaign manager, said the advertisements were ''purposefully distorting the issues,'' saying Mr. Barrow also supported the House version of the proposed marriage amendment.
 Cheryl Jacques, executive director of the Human Rights Campaign, a gay rights group, called the prevalence of commercials ''the worst we have ever seen,'' saying candidates were using the debate over same-sex marriage to ''divide and distract'' instead of discussing the economy, the Iraq war and other issues.
 ''This is the highest level of intensity and aggression ever,'' Ms. Jacques said. ''This is being used at every level and on every race.''
 In some cases, Ms. Jacques said, the accusations were applied to candidates who her own group did not support. In Oklahoma, she said, an advertisement by Mr. Bauer's group attacking Representative Brad Carson, a Democrat, quoted an editorial in a gay newspaper suggesting that he might someday be open to gay rights arguments. But Mr. Carson publicly supported the proposed amendment, and Ms. Jacques said he did not have a record of supporting gay rights. 
 Kristofer Eisenla, a spokesman for Mr. Carson, called the advertisements ''blatant lies about the congressman's conservative record.''
 In response to the accusation that the advertisements were a divisive distraction, Kristy Hamrick, a spokeswoman for Mr. Bauer, said gay groups started the fight by filing suits seeking the right to marry. 
 ''It is a conversation that Americans need to have,'' Ms. Hamerick said. ''Elections are a great time to have that conversation.'' 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

LENGTH: 427 words

HEADLINE: Joseph J. Jacobs, 88, Engineering and Construction Executive

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 29 

 BODY:
Joseph J. Jacobs, the chairman and founder of the Jacobs Engineering Group, one of the world's largest engineering and construction companies, died on Oct. 23. He was 88.
 The company announced his death on Monday. 
 A native of Brooklyn, Mr. Jacobs moved to California and founded his company as a one-man business in 1947, serving as a chemical engineering consultant and manufacturers' representative for large-scale equipment.
 The company, now public and based in Pasadena, designs, builds and operates plants in the oil, pharmaceutical, chemical and biotechnology industries. It had $4.6 billion in revenue last year and has more than 35,000 employees worldwide.
 Born in 1916, Mr. Jacobs was the son of a peddler who immigrated from Lebanon. The Jacobs family became wealthy during World War I by selling straight razors. But after the safety razor was invented, the family's fortune plummeted.
 Mr. Jacobs earned a bachelor's degree in chemical engineering from the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn and taught college while he earned his master's degree and doctorate in that field.
 In later years, he served on the university's board of trustees and was on the board of trustees of Harvey Mudd College in Claremont, Calif., where he helped pay for the Jacobs Science Center.
 In 1983, President Ronald Reagan presented Jacobs with the Hoover Medal, recognizing his contributions in engineering, education and humanitarian efforts.
 The 1991 autobiography of Mr. Jacobs, ''The Anatomy of an Entrepreneur: Family, Culture and Ethics,'' detailed his philosophy of cultural and moral values for the business world. Four years later, he wrote ''The Compassionate Conservative: Assuming Responsibility and Respecting Human Dignity,'' which outlined his strategy for helping others within the context of his conservative political and economic bent.
 Mr. Jacobs was chief executive of his engineering company until 1992, when he left to found two venture capital firms and devote more time to charity work. He remained chairman of the Jacobs board.
 Mr. Jacobs, through the Jacobs Family Foundation, funneled $32 million into grants to nonprofit organizations over 16 years.
 Eight years ago, he established the Jacobs Center for Neighborhood Innovation in San Diego, which helps communities turn their economic fortunes around through economic aid, technical assistance and training.
 He is survived by his wife, Violet; three daughters, Dr. Linda Jacobs, Margaret Jacobs and Valerie Jacobs Hapke; and two grandchildren. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Obituary (Obit); Biography

HEADLINE: Taking Bush At His Word

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF. 
E-mail: nicholas@nytimes.com

 BODY:
I often criticize statements by President Bush, so today let me praise some of his real wisdom:
 Oct. 11, 2000: ''If we're an arrogant nation, [foreigners] will resent us. If we're a humble nation but strong, they'll welcome us. We've got to be humble.'' 
 It's a good thing Mr. Bush tried to be humble, or the U.S. would have an approval rating even lower than 5 percent in Jordan, and Osama bin Laden's approval rating in Pakistan would be higher than 65 percent.
 Feb. 27, 2001: ''I hope you will join me to pay down $2 trillion in debt during the next 10 years. We should approach our nation's budget as any prudent family would.''
 But Mr. Bush, with the help of a weak economy, has transformed the Clinton budget surpluses into huge deficits. Since Mr. Bush took office, the federal debt has increased by $2.1 trillion, or 40 percent.
 Sept. 25, 2000: ''It is clear our nation is reliant upon big foreign oil. More and more of our imports come from overseas.''
 Hmm. And many of our exports go abroad. Meanwhile, despite the lackluster economy, oil imports are 1.3 million barrels per day higher than in Mr. Clinton's last year in office.
 June 11, 2001: ''My administration is committed to a leadership role on the issue of climate change.''
 Great! Because America's carbon dioxide emissions, associated with global warming, have risen 1.7 percent since then.
 June 26, 2003: ''Notorious human rights abusers, including, among others, Burma, Cuba, North Korea, Iran and Zimbabwe, have long sought to shield their abuses from the eyes of the world by staging elaborate deceptions and denying access to international human rights monitors.''
 It takes a big man to admit mistakes, like his administration's practice of hiding certain Arab prisoners from Red Cross and other inspectors.
 Nov. 5, 2003: ''In the debate about the rights of the unborn, we are asked to broaden the circle of our moral concern. We're asked by our convictions and tradition and compassion to build a culture of life, and make this a more just and welcoming society.''
 Abortions declined in the U.S. in the Clinton years; the abortion rate dropped by 22 percent in the 1990's. But while data are incomplete, abortions appear to have increased sharply since Mr. Bush took office. Glen H. Stassen, a Christian pro-life theologian, estimates that 52,000 more abortions occurred in 2002 than would have been expected based on the previous trend. Professor Stassen attributes the rise in abortions in part to the troubled economy and concerns among pregnant women that they cannot afford to have babies.
 May 25, 2004: ''One of the challenges we face is to make sure the health care system responds to the needs of the citizens.''
 But five million more Americans don't have health insurance, compared with when Mr. Bush took office.
 Sept. 9, 2003: ''We must focus early to make sure every child can read and write and add and subtract.''
 But Mr. Bush's budget guidelines translate into inflation-adjusted reductions in 2006 alone of more than $900 million for Head Start and childhood education.
 May 24, 2003: ''We will not tolerate nuclear weapons in North Korea.''
 On Mr. Bush's watch, North Korea is generally believed to have gone from two nuclear weapons to about eight. 
 2001: ''Not on my watch.''
 Scrawled note by Mr. Bush on a report to him about the 1994 genocide in Rwanda that had occurred under President Clinton.
 That's reassuring to the 100,000 or more people in Darfur who have died in a spasm of murder and rape that Mr. Bush acknowledges as genocide. 
 Sept. 30, 2004: ''The biggest threat facing this country is weapons of mass destruction in the hands of a terrorist network.''
 But the single most important step to reducing the risk that a nuclear weapon will destroy New York is to secure loose nukes abroad, and Mr. Bush has been lackadaisical about that. Only 135 out of 600 metric tons of Russian nuclear materials have been given comprehensive upgrades, and Mr. Bush initially proposed cutting funds for that program.
 Sept. 2, 1999: ''Effective reform requires accountability. It is a sad story. High hopes, low achievement. Grand plans, unmet goals. My administration will do things differently.''
 Oh?

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section A; Column 5; National Desk; THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: THE ELECTORATE; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1354 words

HEADLINE: 4 Years Later, Some Voters Switch Sides

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 

 BODY:
For all the talk about a politically polarized nation, there are defectors out there among the electorate, a relatively small but distinct subset who voted for the presidential nominee of one party four years ago and now are prepared to vote for that of the other on Tuesday.
 Both sides say they have been reaching out to these voters in seeking every possible advantage on Election Day. 
 Many of them cite concern about the war in Iraq as the reason that prompted their switch. And that concern has brought defections not only in the direction of Senator John Kerry, the Democratic nominee.
 ''Any switch in office now would create turmoil,'' said John Pal, a 57-year-old interior designer in Houston who voted for Al Gore in 2000 and now supports President Bush. Turning the president out of office, he said, ''would give the terrorists a sign that we are weak, and would be very costly for us.'' 
 Mr. Pal is not alone. The most recent New York Times/CBS News poll, conducted Oct. 14-17, found that while 11 percent of people who voted for Mr. Bush in 2000 said they were voting this time for Mr. Kerry, 7 percent of those who voted for Mr. Gore said they would vote this year for Mr. Bush. The difference was within the margin of sampling error.
 In follow-up interviews, many of those who voted Democratic in 2000 but are voting for Mr. Bush now said they were reluctant to change commanders in chief while the war continued. On the other hand, voters who supported Mr. Bush in 2000 but oppose him now said they were deeply pessimistic about the president's handling of Iraq.
 Richard Linn, a registered Republican who lives in Columbus, Ind., voted for Mr. Bush in 2000 because he perceived him as a fellow hawk on defense.
 But Mr. Linn, a retired air traffic controller, says the president has so botched the war and America's standing in the world that he is switching to Mr. Kerry.
 ''I've simply become disgruntled with the man,'' Mr. Linn said of Mr. Bush. ''I believe very little of what he says anymore.''
 Many of those interviewed said the process of deciding had occurred over time and been arduous. They described themselves as based more or less in the political center and, though most are registered with one party or another, saw themselves not as party loyalists but as independent thinkers.
 They also said that in 2000, they saw little difference between the candidates and little import in the election. Now, almost all said, the war in Iraq, even more than the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, has given them a sense of urgency.
 ''I didn't see a great deal of difference between Bush and Gore, but President Bush has really shifted a great deal since then,'' said Larry Howell, 57, a software engineer in Columbus, Ohio, who voted for Mr. Bush in 2000 and is now voting for Mr. Kerry.
 Mr. Howell, who told of having been ''downsized'' in 2001, said his concern about the economy was intertwined with concerns about Iraq.
 ''I have a lot of misgivings over Bush's reasons for going into Iraq, and now we have to siphon off hundreds of billions of dollars to pay for a war like that,'' he said. ''Bush is on a railroad track toward a very unpleasant future at this point, and it can only get worse.''
 Mark Mellman, a Democratic pollster working for Mr. Kerry, said people's memories of how they voted four years earlier tended to be unreliable. 
 ''If you ask people today who they voted for in 2000, Bush would have had a six-point lead,'' he said, whereas in fact he lost the popular vote to Mr. Gore by a half-million. The difference is attributable to what pollsters call ''the halo effect,'' a desire to associate with the winner.
 Still, Mr. Mellman said, polling shows that ''there are many more people who are moving from Bush to Kerry than are moving from Gore to Bush.''
 ''The real swing is among independents,'' he said, ''and they have swung to us.'' 
 He said that the votes of these people would be decisive.
 But Matthew Dowd, a senior strategist with the Bush campaign, said that party affiliation was a more reliable indicator in the battle for defectors and that by this measure, Mr. Bush was doing better than Mr. Kerry.
 ''We get 93 percent of Republicans, and he gets 87 percent of Democrats,'' Mr. Dowd said. The Times/CBS poll showed a similar result.
 Many of the switching voters had difficulty making their decision. Andrew Kohut, president of the independent Pew Research Center, said his polling on Oct. 20 found that 61 percent of those who were now voting for Mr. Kerry described the choice as hard, while 38 percent who had settled on Mr. Bush said the same. Mr. Kohut said this reflected concern about changing horses in midstream.
 Mr. Linn, the Indiana Republican, who served in the Air Force during the Korean War, said he had supported Mr. Bush up through the invasion of Iraq but had now soured on him.
 ''We haven't found any weapons, and our boys are just getting killed over there,'' he said. He added that despite having voted for Mr. Bush four years ago, he was so angry at him today that ''the earth will have to cave in for me to vote for him now.''
 Others are less certain. Terry Hammer, 44, a registered nurse in Springfield, Mo., voted for Mr. Bush in 2000 and is now a fence sitter, though leaning to Mr. Kerry.
 ''The invasion of Iraq was ill advised,'' Mr. Hammer said. ''But we can't go back in time and undo it, and there's something to be said for staying the course and not flinching. I feel it might be a break in the continuity to switch right now.''
 He is nonetheless leaning toward Mr. Kerry, he said, in part because he does not like Mr. Bush's support for changing the Constitution to ban gay marriage and because he is worried about ''that explosives cache that went missing.''
 ''That reinforces my belief that the Iraq war didn't make the world safer but more dangerous,'' he said.
 Craig Boehnen, 36, a meat cutter who lives outside Fort Worth, said he supported Mr. Gore in 2000 but was now supporting Mr. Bush for fear that Mr. Kerry was too weak.
 ''My main thing about Kerry is, How is he going to react to the terrorism?'' Mr. Boehnen said. ''The way I look at it is, if someone came to my house and did damage to my family, I'm thinking revenge. I don't think Kerry would be as strong as Bush. I think he might cut the military budget and cut the C.I.A.''
 Mr. Pal, the Houston designer, said he had similar concerns. He said that he escaped from Romania in 1980 and that he fully supported what he saw as Mr. Bush's determination to spread freedom around the world.
 ''This is my country, and I will defend it,'' he declared. He said he was teaching his three sons ''the values of freedom and that sometimes you need to fight for it.''
 Myrtle Dettman, 81, of Evergreen, Ala., said she was switching to Mr. Bush because he ''has a little more experience since he's already in the office.'' She also said she knew little about Mr. Kerry and perceived Mr. Bush as ''a good, moral, Christian man.''
 Of the former Bush supporters, few had anything positive to say about Mr. Kerry. As Mr. Howell put it, ''I'm turning away from Bush; I'm not drawn by Kerry.'' Any pro-Kerry sentiment was secondary to dissatisfaction with the war.
 One independent, Rick Snyder, 47, a pharmacist in Northampton, Pa., who voted for Mr. Bush in 2000, said that he had a friend with Parkinson's disease and that he favored Mr. Kerry because the senator would promote stem cell research. But his main reason for abandoning Mr. Bush, he said, is that ''I'm very disappointed with the Iraq war.''
 Similarly, Joan Deane, 78, of Scarborough, Me., a registered Republican who is fond of the Bush family, said that she found Mr. Kerry ''Lincolnesque'' but that it was her sentiment against the incumbent that was motivating her now to vote for the senator.
 ''George W. is not as smart as other people,'' she said. ''He has about 10 phrases that he uses over and over again. He's a little arrogant when he walks. And he was so foolish to go over to Iraq. Go back and look at the Bible, honey. They've been fighting over that dreadful piece of land forever.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard Linn says he voted for George W. Bush but won't again. (Photo by Tom Strattman for The New York Times)(pg. A13)

SECTION: Section A; Column 3; National Desk; APPLE'S ALMANAC; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 1118 words

HEADLINE: This Time Around, the World Is Watching, Nervously

BYLINE: By R.W. Apple Jr.

DATELINE: WALLOON LAKE, Mich. 

 BODY:
Nothing shakes up an old political reporter quite like living in another country while the spellbinding drama of a presidential election unfolds back home.
 Spellbinding, that is, for Americans and for the few foreigners who take a special interest in America and things American. There aren't too many people overseas like a professor I met in West Germany in 1984, who told me how depressing he found it that no vote he ever cast would have half as much impact on his two sons' lives as the votes that Americans cast. Most people abroad, most years, could not care less. 
 In 1980, I was working in the Soviet Union -- gone now, like West Germany -- as the contest between Ronald Reagan and Jimmy Carter reached a climax. For me that November, the can't-miss spectacle was the annual parade in Red Square marking the anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution, not the television debates in the States. For me, that November, the pressing question was not who would occupy the White House for the next four years, but how the Soviet venture in Afghanistan would pan out, and whether the Soviet tanks reportedly poised on the border would invade Poland.
 In November 1984, I was in London. Britons were concerned with a national coal strike, then in its eighth month; the assassination of Indira Gandhi and the growing threat of terrorism. Some things never change. I wrote about their concerns and also, as I find in scrolling through The Times's electronic archive, about the struggle to preserve real British cheeses. Some people never change, either. I find no evidence that I (or my British hosts) paid very much attention to Mr. Reagan's re-election bid.
 This year is different. The University of Bologna and Italian television are staging a mock election between President Bush and John Kerry in La California, a tiny village on the Tuscan coast. Meantime, The Guardian, a liberal British daily, has urged its readers to write to citizens of Clark County, Ohio, a swing county in a swing state that Al Gore carried by 324 votes in 2000, in an effort to influence their balloting.
 As it happens, I know Clark County, which is in the southwest part of the state. My staunchly Republican parents met there while attending Wittenberg College, a small Lutheran institution in Springfield, the county seat. They certainly wouldn't have liked the letter from Neil Evans, who wrote from Kent to Thelma Arnold, urging her to vote for Mr. Kerry ''to preserve your once-great name internationally.'' Neither did Beverly Coale, Mrs. Arnold's daughter, a Kerry backer, who called it propaganda.
 All of which is a rather lengthy introduction to a report on an experience I had here in Hemingway country a week or so back, when the autumn leaves were at their most vivid, the colors so bright that they almost hurt your eyes (what would Monet or Kandinsky have made of them?).
 This year's crop of Knight-Wallace Fellows at the University of Michigan, all journalists in midcareer, were spending a weekend Up North, as Michiganders call this part of their state, and Charles Eisendrath, who runs the program, invited me to quiz the foreigners among them about their initial impressions of the current campaign. I did so, and some of the answers -- all their private opinions, not necessarily reflecting their employers' positions -- demonstrated how very different this election is.
 Like news reports from abroad, and like my own reporting on recent trips outside this country, they disclosed a decidedly one-dimensional view of things.
 Matthias Schepp, 40, a longtime foreign correspondent for Stern, a widely read German magazine, said it had taken a poll that showed that 81 percent of people in Germany preferred Mr. Kerry, with many of the remaining 19 percent responding that they would choose ''neither of the above'' if they were given that option.
 ''It's not just the traditional anti-American fringe,'' he said. ''People who have always been grateful for the help of the United States after the war and later in reunifying our country are upset, too, mainly because of the Iraq war. We said it would turn out badly, and it has, but Bush is seen as telling us, 'My way or the highway.'
 ''It is very well noted that our chancellor put his job on the line by sending German troops to Afghanistan, against our tradition and history, and for his courage he has gotten very little in return.''
 Mr. Schepp's wife, Mariam, a Russian and a concert pianist, put the problem into a broader framework. Because of the problems in Chechnya, she said, she sympathized with Mr. Bush's fight against terrorism. But she added: ''He wants to plant American-style democracy around the globe. It won't work, because every country is unique, with its own history, its own culture.''
 Mr. Kerry, she said, struck her as ''better-educated, more sophisticated and less rustic'' than Mr. Bush. Because of his service in Vietnam, she suggested, he has ''a better understanding of what war is like'' and might change American policies.
 Sergio Danishewsky, 39, of the newspaper Clarin in Buenos Aires, said he, too, hoped for a change in American policies, ''but I'm much more skeptical.''
 Argentina, he said, had suffered under the presidency of Carlos Saul Menem, partly because ''he wanted to be like George Bush's father, the other President Bush.'' But the biggest reason Argentines ''have a negative image of the United States as a government and a policy, though not as a people,'' as he put it, is that unlike European countries, the United States ''does not work with us to solve our economic difficulties.''
 Mi-Seok Koh, 44, an assistant editor at Dong-A Ilbo, one of the leading papers in Seoul, South Korea, said she had watched all three presidential debates on television and concluded that in at least one respect President Bush was exactly like the South Korean president, Roh Moo Hyun, because ''he blames everything on the media.''
 Describing Mr. Bush as ''a rude cowboy,'' Ms. Koh continued: ''The American people don't really care what he says. Most of them think that he looks like a strong leader, which is what they want.''
 Although she argued that most people in South Korea would rather see Mr. Kerry as president, Ms. Koh said she believed Mr. Bush would win a second term.
 Why? Long pause. ''Because I'm a pessimist,'' she finally replied.
 There was more in the same vein from other fellows, each of whom described the American election at least in part from the perspective of their own country's interests and difficulties. But what was striking was that not a single one of them failed in some way to report that Mr. Bush's policies had cost the United States friends. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (91%); US PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS (90%); ELECTIONS (90%); PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS (89%); VOTERS & VOTING (89%); US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2008 (89%); US PRESIDENTS (78%); COUNTIES (78%); US REPUBLICAN PARTY (77%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (73%); POLITICAL DEBATES (73%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (71%); PARADES & MARCHES (68%); ANNIVERSARIES (53%); CHEESE (50%); TERRORISM (50%) Presidential Election of 2004; Public Opinion; News and News Media; Election Issues; Presidential Election of 2004

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; National Desk; THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: THE WEST; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 1903 words

HEADLINE: An Evolving Identity Helps to Leave Five States in Search of a President

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN

DATELINE: ACOMA, N.M., Oct. 29 

 BODY:
As the sun sets over the land on Election Day, the American West could become the landscape of victory for the man who will be president in the next four years.
 For all the attention that the parties are paying to Sioux City, Iowa, or Dayton, Ohio, the election may well be decided in places like Lake Havasu City, Ariz., where the London Bridge was transplanted to the sands of the Mojave Desert, or here at Acoma, an Indian pueblo that claims to be the oldest continuously inhabited city in the nation. 
 Heavily urban despite its open spaces, and soon to be more Hispanic, the West is also an unpredictable region in search of a new political identity. The war, terror, climbing health insurance premiums all matter here as elsewhere, but people are more likely to be independents. 
 As the electoral map dried up in the South for Democrats, they turned to the long-forgotten interior West. But both campaigns have discovered that political brand loyalty is a hard thing to find here. 
 ''I'm a Democrat who voted for George Bush last time, and I'm voting John Kerry this time just because things don't feel right and maybe change is the only way out,'' said Amanda Mordem, a nurse's assistant in Bullhead City, Ariz., a sprawling town at the edge of a county that takes in part of the Grand Canyon and Indian reservations.
 Five states -- Oregon, Nevada, Arizona, Colorado and New Mexico, with a total of 36 electoral votes -- are still within reach of either candidate, according to most recent polls.
 A tour through these five states this week, when millions of people were well into the thick of early voting, found a big land pulsing with the harsh intimacy of battle in the campaign's closing days. 
 ''You can't keep it down this year -- people are just off the charts for this election,'' said Elizabeth Boyd, who works at the Face to Face Spa in Bend, Ore., where politics has elbowed aside talk of wonder exfoliants and earth-friendly facials.
 Former President Bill Clinton plans to be in New Mexico Saturday and Sunday, pitching for its five electoral votes as President Bush's father did on Thursday. 
 ''I've never seen the kind of churning we're seeing right now in the West,'' said Ron Judd, the Western region director for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. ''There is this undercurrent like we had in 1994 when the Congress changed hands, like we're on the verge of something big.''

Oregon's Culture Clash
 In Oregon, a state where doctors can prescribe drugs for the terminally ill to kill themselves but drivers cannot pump their own gas, people have been voting for more than a week in the all-mail-in ballot. 
 Oregon looked like a tossup for much of this year, with an island of Democrats in the Portland metropolitan area surrounded by Republican counties. Some Oregonians believe the state is trending more like Colorado did in the 1990's, full of Republican California exiles. But Democrats are still optimistic. Al Gore eked out a 7,000-vote victory in 2000, but he was hurt by Ralph Nader, who drew 5 percent of the vote. This year Mr. Nader is not on the ballot. 
 The red and the blue clash in Deschutes County, on the other side of the mountains from Portland. It grew by 54 percent in the 1990's, drawing people who live for cutthroat trout that rise in streams that dance through the high desert.
 Clay and Julia Johnston, a pilot and his wife, formerly of Portland, were sipping coffee while filling out their mail-in ballot on a chilly morning. They predicted a victory for President Bush -- at least in this county where the two political cultures of the state collide.
 ''Wherever there is money, there are Republicans,'' said Mr. Johnston. ''And there is a lot of money here.''

Nevada's Wild Cards
 South, in Nevada, money was on the air nonstop, and on the ground, as the campaigns bused people to mobile voting centers. 
 ''Who wants to vote -- this way to the bus,'' said a Bush campaign operative on Tuesday outside the giant Victory Christian Center in a strip mall in Henderson, for much of the last decade the nation's fastest-growing city. 
 Nevada has only five electoral votes, but they have been fought over as if they were the last undeveloped real estate on the Las Vegas Strip. 
 A few blocks away, union supporters were getting their talking points and neighborhood maps for a day of ground-pounding. They were told to remind stay-at-home moms of the nuclear waste site planned at Yucca Mountain -- an issue Senator Kerry has been raising.
 Paul Sanchez, one of many out-of-state union leaders doing political work in the desert, had a telephone number scrawled on the back of his hand. ''I go into the poor neighborhoods, knock on doors and just tell people to call this number -- someone will come get them and take them to the polls,'' said Mr. Sanchez.
 Though Republicans are thought to have a slight edge in Nevada, the wild cards are state ballot measures, in particular a popular one that would raise the minimum wage. 
 Pocketbook issues are the big concern for Debra Pinkerton, an undecided voter who lives in Searchlight, a wind-raked town at the southern tip of Clark County. 
 ''One of my children works in Vegas, and he makes $11 an hour but has to pay $70 a week for health insurance, which he needs because he and his wife just had a baby,'' said Ms. Pinkerton, who qualifies as pioneer stock in Nevada, with grandparents who moved to the state in the 1930's, when Nevada had barely 90,000 people.
 With a booming economy, jobs are not an issue in Nevada. The bare bones of new homes stretch to the desert's edge.
 Democrats are counting on a live-and-let-live cultural attitude to counter Republicans like Mary Bolinger, who has already voted, and was walking around Henderson with a button that read: ''I'm a Republican and a Christian. You got a problem with that?''
 The problem for Republicans may be that Nevada, like Oregon, is near the bottom in the ranking of states by percentage of churchgoers.

Colorado's Democratic Fling
 By contrast, in Colorado the big churches may give Republicans enough of an edge to hold the state after a surprising fling with indecision. The center for Christian conservatives is Colorado Springs, a metropolitan area of nearly a half-million people that exudes a youthful, prosperous, Rocky Mountain optimism. The New Life Church, whose impressive glass-and-concrete compound can be seen for miles, rises at the edge of town.
 The electoral math, for Republicans, comes from the big new homes along the Front Range.
 ''We call them the California middle class,'' said Rob Brendle, associate pastor at New Life, pointing to an expanse of McMansions. ''These neighborhoods are full of evangelicals who came here for a new life.''
 Inside the New Life compound, workers were finishing a new church that will seat 7,500 people and people wore buttons that said, ''I voted.'' The headquarters office features pictures of the head pastor, Ted Haggard, with President Bush and Mel Gibson. 
 Mr. Haggard -- or Pastor Ted, as everyone in the church calls him -- is president of the National Association of Evangelicals, which says it represents 30 million people. He has been to the Oval Office twice since Mr. Bush has been president. 
 ''We've been in regular contact with Karl Rove,'' said Mr. Brendle, referring to the president's chief political adviser. Though the church is officially nonpartisan, opposition to gay marriage and abortion have put it strongly in the Republican camp. To win this election, Mr. Rove has said, Republicans will need to turn out roughly four million evangelicals who did not vote in 2000. Mr. Brendle predicted an enormous Christian right turnout -- at least 75 percent among the 11,000 members of the New Life Church.
 ''Our people don't need to be bused to the polls and given a sandwich,'' he said.
 Democrats say Colorado is changing as the number of Republican-leaning California exiles levels off and Hispanics, who make up 17 percent of the population, gain ground. Also, the older suburbs around Denver have been promising new ground for Democrats.
 The burgeoning Hispanic population may be why Mr. Kerry chose Pueblo, in a county in southern Colorado that is nearly 40 percent Hispanic, as the site of his last visit a few days ago. He appeared with the state's Hispanic superstar, Attorney General Ken Salazar, who is in a close race with the Republican candidate, Pete Coors, for the open Senate seat.

Arizona's Hispanic Force
 Hispanics could also hold the key to what happens in Arizona, another formerly safe Republican state, which was rated close enough to be competitive in a recent poll by The Arizona Republic; other surveys give Mr. Bush a slight edge. The state is 25 percent Hispanic and has gained 470,000 new registered voters -- and two electoral votes -- since the 2000 campaign. 
 Though Republicans have a margin of about 100,000 votes in party registration, more than one in five voters in Arizona are independent, a political position where many in the New West park themselves. 
 The Latino vote is complicated: more conservative on social issues, not prone to high turnout. But no one denies its growing influence. There are 3.6 million Hispanics, or nearly one in four residents, in Arizona, New Mexico, Colorado and Nevada.
 The other big vote in Arizona is the elderly, and they are more reliable voters than any other group. In Bullhead City, a fast-growing retirement and recreation community in the middle of the Mojave Desert on the banks of the Colorado River, older people were angry this week over the lack of sufficient flu shots. But they were not holding Mr. Bush responsible.
 ''I wasn't able to get my flu shot, and I really need it because I've got the emphysema,'' said Barbara Martinez, a retiree in Bullhead City, eating lunch in a medical facility cafeteria. ''But I don't see how you can blame President Bush for that.''

New Mexico's Indian Issues
 New Mexico, where Spanish-surnamed families trace their roots back centuries and Indians in Acoma have a direct link to the ancient Anasazi, may be the hardest state for the campaigns to figure out.
 Hispanics make up 42 percent of the population -- the highest of any state in the 2000 census -- while non-Hispanic whites are 48 percent. Compared with the national average, New Mexico is poor, and young, and it is growing -- by 20 percent in the last census. 
 American Indians, who make up 9 percent of the population, are only now being courted. Over the last week, John Kerry's sister was here at Acoma, as was Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton.
 Atop the Sky City of Acoma, where people live without electricity on a stone summit nearly 7,000 feet above sea level, some natives said they would not vote, that it meant nothing to them who ran the government in Washington.
 But tribal leaders said they wished the campaigns would pay as much attention to their issues as they do to interest groups like dairy farmers in Wisconsin. Marva Toya said she was worried about the possible closing of an Indian hospital an hour away, in Albuquerque.
 Darrell Felipe, the Acoma tribal operations manager, said: ''If one candidate would just bring up a single Native American issue, they could get the native vote. But they don't talk about us.''
 This year, in the closing hours of the race, the people who live in a town that most historians agree is twice as old as Boston may actually get their wish.


GRAPHIC: Photos: The presidential campaigns may not have addressed issues of concern to New Mexico Indians like Marva Toya, shown at the pueblo of Acoma. (Photo by Rick Scibelli Jr. for The New York Times)
Debra Pinkerton, an undecided voter in Searchlight, Nev., said pocketbook issues were a big concern. (Photo by Jim Wilson/The New York Times)
 ''These neighborhoods are full of evangelicals,'' said Rob Brendle, an assistant pastor of the New Life Church in Colorado Springs. (Photo by Kevin Moloney for The New York Times)

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section C; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk; INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 852 words

HEADLINE: Asia Markets React Calmly To Beijing's Rate Increase

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Oct. 29 

 BODY:
Mainland Chinese stock markets dropped less than 2 percent on Friday, while most Asian financial markets reacted with surprising calm to the Chinese central bank's announcement late Thursday of its first increase in interest rates in nine years.
 The People's Bank of China acted on Thursday to slow economic growth and try to curtail inflation, and its slight increase in rates, and the possibility of further moves, are likely to start trimming growth in China's imports. 
 Asian economies have become heavily reliant on trade with China for growth, economists and analysts say. Yet in the first day of trading after the Chinese rate increase, stocks dropped by less than half of a percent in Hong Kong, on the mainland's doorstep, and by three-quarters of a percent in Japan, while rising modestly in South Korea, Malaysia, Australia, Taiwan and the Philippines, five big trading partners of China. 
 The mild response had several roots, experts said. Some kind of rate increase had been expected for many months, though the timing of the decision was a surprise. 
 China began tightening economic policy last spring when it imposed stringent administrative controls on the volume of bank loans and the issuance of zoning and environmental impact approvals. That package of measures caused Chinese stock markets to lose a quarter of their value last April and hurt commodity prices around the world on an expectation of slowing Chinese demand.
 But recently, those measures seemed to have lost some of their effectiveness. Instead of being an additional tightening move, Thursday's rate increase may in effect partly replace the April measures. 
 ''This is a switch of tactics, but it is not the start of a tightening cycle the way a Fed increase marks the start of a tightening cycle in the United States,'' said Donald Hanna, the chief Asian economist at Citigroup.
 As it increased rates Thursday, the People's Bank of China also removed the ceiling it had long imposed on the interest rates that banks may charge. That caused the handful of Chinese bank stocks -- most of the industry is state-owned -- to rise on Friday, and fostered hopes among investors that Beijing is deepening its commitment to a free-market economy, which could help growth and stocks alike in the long term. 
 One immediate benefit from the rate increase was a drop in world commodity prices, from oil to copper. But after falling $1.54 on Thursday in response to the Chinese decision, oil retraced a little over half its lossed on Friday, rising 84 cents, to $51.76. Higher inventories in the United States were also helping hold oil below its high of the week. Oil, in particular, has been a big worry for stock market investors across East Asia, where most countries have scant reserves of their own.
 Many macroeconomic models suggest that when a country becomes the biggest buyer of a commodity, a position that China now holds in goods from cement to steel, its domestic economic policies, including taxes and interest rates, can be used to push prices up or down, to its own benefit or detriment.
 China's low interest rates and breakneck growth have caused it to buy so much of so many commodities lately that it has driven their prices steeply higher, forcing Chinese companies to pay top dollar to their own detriment and to the benefit of exporters elsewhere. Thursday's rate increase could wind up indirectly saving money at companies across Asia that are now bearing the burden of high prices for imported raw materials.
 Another reason for the mild market reaction, economists said, was that the Chinese bank only raised borrowing and lending rates by a little over a quarter of a percentage point. That is too little to have much immediate effect, although further increases are expected. 
 ''It's the Alan Greenspan style -- you increase a quarter point, but maybe you have more to come,'' said Li Kui-wai, the coordinator of an Asian studies center at the City University of Hong Kong. By moving slowly, Beijing may actually set off one last burst of feverish economic activity by causing real estate developers and others to take out more loans and try to finish existing projects before interest rates go even higher, Mr. Li said. 
 The real estate sector's response may be the biggest question mark associated with the central bank's new willingness to use interest rates to slow the economy. Frenzied deal making has pushed apartment prices in big Chinese cities to the equivalent of 10 or more years' income for a typical white-collar worker, compared with less than 4 years' income in many American cities.
 Adjustable-rate mortgages have financed much of the double-digit annual appreciation in Chinese housing prices, and those borrowers will have to start paying more for the roofs over their heads as rates rise.
 ''The heart of China's investment boom is a massive and nationwide property bubble,'' said Andy Xie, an economist with Morgan Stanley, in a research report on Friday afternoon. ''China is experiencing mass speculation in property for the first time in its history.''

INTERNATIONAL A3-9

Body of Japanese Hostage Believed Found in Iraq
A body believed to be that of Shosei Koda, 24, a Japanese traveler in Iraq who had been seized by militants, was found near Tikrit. He had been held by a group that had threatened to behead him if Japan did not start withdrawing forces. A9

The Pentagon ordered 6,500 soldiers in Iraq to extend their tours. A8

Yasir Arafat Treated in France
The ailing Palestinian leader arrived in France as the guest of the French government and was immediately taken to a military hospital for treatment of a mysterious ailment. A6

Osama bin Laden, in Tape, Warns American Citizens

The tape jolted the presidential campaign, bringing reactions from President Bush, who vowed that Americans ''will not be intimidated or influenced,'' and Senator John Kerry, who said Americans ''are absolutely united in our determination to hunt down and destroy'' terrorists. A1
