SECTION: Section 14; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2378 words

HEADLINE: Take My Life, Please

BYLINE: By JAY DIXIT. 
Jay Dixit writes for Rolling Stone, The Washington Post and The Village Voice.

 BODY:
IT'S comedy night at the Parkside Lounge, a dark dive on the Lower East Side, but nobody is laughing.
 The first person to stand up is a dark-haired man wearing a beleaguered expression. He talks about his time in prison and his struggles with manic-depressive illness. ''Depression is so horrible, I only have one word for it: Kevorkian,'' he says. ''Depression is so bad it makes you appreciate pain.''
 A woman with a cherubic face and tight red curls takes her turn. ''I had a bad year last year,'' she says. ''I was totally suicidal, and the worst thing was, I had nobody to address the note to. I was like, 'Dear Everybody Who Hates Me: You win, I'm dead.''' 
 Then a pretty African-American woman stands in front of the group. ''I just got out of an abusive relationship last week,'' she says. ''They said I was fat, worthless, hated my guts, and wanted me to leave. And I was like: 'Look, Mom, I'm 23. You can't abort me now.'''
 It's an open-mike night for stand-up comedians, but it might as well be group therapy or an A.A. meeting. It's the aptly named Tuesday Night Train Wreck at the Parkside Lounge, where aspiring comics show up every week, and, for $7, get to drop their names into an empty beer pitcher. The two M.C.'s draw names, and, one by one, the comics get up on the tiny stage in a dimly lit back room for their hard-won five minutes of stand-up. Most are honing their act or trying out new material. But some are just here for catharsis.
 New York is the world capital of stand-up comedy. Most of the country's top comedians started here, and people still flock from all over the country hoping that comedy will catapult them into sitcom and movie stardom. That makes the city the natural choice for next week's New York Comedy Festival, starting Nov. 9 and featuring comedic heavyweights like Roseanne Barr, Denis Leary and Drew Carey. 
 But of course most aspiring comics don't make it. Many get stuck on the open-mike circuit and never graduate into paid gigs. On some level, comedians know their chances for success are slim. ''They talk about their aspirations, getting a sitcom and making it in show business,'' said Joey Gay, a co-host of the five-year-old Train Wreck. ''But they know it will never come to fruition. They talk about it like they might talk about heaven.''
 The sense of personal failure is rubbed in by the financial structure of an open mike, the funhouse-mirror version of a real comedy club: comedians pay for the privilege of performing while audience members watch without charge. No wonder, then, that New York comedy hinges on self-deprecation, especially at open mikes like these. Many of the comics here talk about race, poverty and porn; almost all talk about drugs, sex and dysfunctional relationships with parents. 
 Comedians often say their jokes come from putting a wisecracking veneer atop tragedy. As Mark Twain observed: ''The secret source of humor itself is not joy but sorrow. There is no humor in heaven.'' But this? This is sorrow without the veneer.

Tuesdays With Maury
 It was almost 8 p.m. when Maury Fogel showed up at Yello, a sleek bar deep in Chinatown that attracts would-be comics from across the city every Tuesday night when it converts its karaoke basement into an open mike.
 The regular M.C. was on vacation, and by 8:30, only five comics were waiting to take their place on a portable wooden stage hauled out of a supply closet. As usual, there was no audience, and the energy level in the room was low. One comedian had just quit his job as a host at Applebee's on Staten Island. The substitute M.C. worked at an office in New Jersey. Another comedian was a student at New York University; this was only his second open mike ever. As they ordered drinks, the comics wondered whether more people would show up. ''What do you think, Maury, should we start?'' one asked.
 The M.C. got up and did a set. Then another comic went up. Mr. Fogel ordered a tea. Finally, he bounded onto the stage. Dressed in black cargo pants, sneakers and a rust-colored fleece, Mr. Fogel looked like an overgrown kid, an effect his salt-and-pepper hair did little to counteract. 
 ''I'm just Maury, that's all I am,'' he began. Then, with a burst of energy, he went on: ''So are you having a good time? Are you happy? Yeah, you're happy, because you're not me!''
 In a New York accent that suggests the nice Jewish boy from Queens that he is, he described the pathos of his life with a strange mix of misery and energy. ''I try to relate to people my age,'' he said. ''They have a house with a mortgage? I have a house with a mother.''
 The punch line was greeted by silence. Mr. Fogel plowed on, undaunted. ''I try to fit in with the kids these days. But I just can't. I try to be hip-hop, but I'm more IHOP.'' He patted his ample paunch. More silence.
 Shuffling back and forth on the four-foot-square stage, he shifted his gaze from person to person. ''I try to be like Puff Daddy, but I'm more like puff pastry.'' Still no response from the crowd. Mr. Fogel was bombing.
 ''O.K., I'll be here all week; try the duck,'' he said miserably, hoping to win sympathy by acknowledging that the crowd was not responding. But the crowd gave him nothing in return.
 ''I just don't fit in,'' he continued. ''I went to a wedding. Somebody thought I was the best man. I told him, I'm not the best man, I'm the worst man. My name is Maury, I'm 43 years old, I live with my mother, I don't have a job, I'm 30 pounds overweight, I'm lactose-intolerant, and I haven't had sex in five years.''
 This was his big climax, his signature line, but it got barely any response.
 Finally, Mr. Fogel plunged into a routine about deciding to throw himself into a volcano because living with his mother was driving him crazy. But by this point he was just going through the motions. His speech became garbled, and he began skipping words. Finally he gave up. 
 ''Oh-kee,'' he sighed, turning to the M.C. ''Come up here and get me out of this.''

'Be Happy You're Not Me'
 As it turns out, Mr. Fogel is just as down on himself in person as he is in his act. His puppy-dog earnestness and his habit of putting himself down suggest that his stage persona is simply an extension of low self-esteem in general.
 He has been doing comedy for 16 years. It's the only thing he does, aside from looking for a day job. Besides traditional open mikes, he has performed at coffee shops, pizza joints, private apartments and rock concerts. Whenever he can afford to, he attends classes at the Comics Studio. Like his open-mike brethren, he nurses the hope of one day becoming a full-time working comedian.
 The material for Mr. Fogel's routines consists entirely of his personal failures. The refrain he repeats between every bit: ''Be happy you're not me, folks.'' 
 Rather than practicing the knowing, ironic comedy made popular by David Letterman and carried on today by the likes of Jon Stewart and Conan O'Brien, Mr. Fogel fuses the borscht-belt sensibility of Henny Youngman with the I-don't-get-no-respect shtick of the late Rodney Dangerfield. ''My act is I make fun of myself,'' he explained one recent afternoon, as he waited in the cold to be let into an open mike in the West Village. ''I came to it because I figured, everybody makes fun of me, I might as well make fun of myself and cut out the middleman.''
 Almost all of what Mr. Fogel says in his act is true. He really doesn't have a job. He really does live with his mother. He really is 30 pounds overweight. He really is lactose-intolerant.
 It's also true that he hasn't had sex in five years. ''I'm not Mr. G.Q.,'' he said. ''I want to get my own place, be my own person, have a girlfriend. But I can't do that now; girls won't go out with me. Besides, I can't bring anyone home with my mom in the next room.''
 Mr. Fogel is a true New Yorker. Aside from summer camp and vacations, he has always lived at home. After John Bowne High School, he went to the DeVry Technical Institute in Woodbridge, N.J., and trained to become an electronics technician. After failing the same three classes twice in a row, he flunked out. He eventually landed a job as a telex operator at Bear Stearns, where he worked for 10 years. But as fax machines and e-mail replaced telexes, there was less and less for him to do. Two years ago, he was laid off, and since then, he has been unemployed.

Their So-Called Lives
 New York is unique for the dozens of comedy classes and open-mike shows available to those willing to pay for them. Most cities have one or two clubs that actually book traveling comedians, but in New York, aspiring comedians can easily do several open-mike shows a night.
 The open-mike circuit is a grind. There's a lot of standing, walking and waiting around. Mr. Fogel goes to open mikes six hours a day, four days a week, spending about $40 a week to make his appearances. He spends two hours a day commuting to and from his home in Flushing, getting to the first club as early as 2:30 p.m. to sign up, and staying out as late as 10. That is in addition to the time he spends writing, practicing his material in front of a mirror, taking classes, and doing speech exercises to improve his diction.
 It's a regimen that occupies as many hours as a full-time job, and one that means giving up any semblance of a normal social life. Aspiring comedians can't go out in the evenings because that's when they're performing. If they work day jobs, they have very little free time. ''I've had no social life, and I forgo tons of money to get on stage for 10 minutes,'' said Deke Haylon, an aspiring stand-up who works part time as a chef for Donald Trump's brother. ''You go over to your friends' house for dinner, and you're like: 'Oh, my God! They have matching glasses!'''
 Taking pain and alchemizing it into something amusing lies at the very heart of comedy. For some comics, it seems as if the worse their lives get, the richer the material becomes.
 ''If I'm happy, and work is going well, and things are going well with my family, then I think, what am I going to talk about?'' said Susan Prekel, a university fund-raiser from Murray Hill who is a regular at the Tuesday Night Train Wreck. ''But that never lasts very long. Things always fall apart soon enough.''
 But sometimes when a comic gets on stage, a curious thing happens. After a spell of tossing out one-liners about drugs or bad breakups, he slips almost unconsciously into a sort of confessional mode.
 That's when the open mike becomes a group therapy session, and the purpose of standing up in front of the group is no longer to practice your material but to share your pain. ''Sometimes you see horribly emotionally wounded people get up and do stuff that does not even resemble stand-up,'' said Mr. Gay of the Train Wreck. ''Some open mikes are like support groups for the black sheep of every family. It's like the Island of the Misfit Toys. Everybody's got something wrong with them, so that becomes their second family.''
 That same therapeutic aspect can get in the way of the putative goal of an open mike: to practice comedy and eventually move on. ''I've seen some pretty fantastic stuff at open mikes,'' Mr. Gay said. ''I once saw a guy go up on stage and put a loaded gun to his head.''
 One woman at the Train Wreck talked about her three-year battle with cocaine addiction without making a single joke. A man handed out pages from his diary. A psychotherapist got on stage and complained at length about how much she hated listening to other people's complaining.

Where Everybody Knows His Name
 Sometimes, Mr. Fogel sets a whole room smiling.
 Twice a month, he is the host of a comedy show that takes place in an unlikely setting -- Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He started the program 11 years ago after a friend encouraged him to sign up for a self-improvement course called ''Self-Expression and Leadership,'' hoping it would help him become more positive about life. The final assignment was to do a project for the community. Mr. Fogel decided to organize a show at a hospital. Sloan-Kettering was the first place he called.
 High on the 15th floor overlooking the Upper East Side, the hospital's recreation room is clean, bright and well appointed, with paintings, a pool table and a foosball table as well as an arts and crafts area, comfortable chairs and plants everywhere.
 Mr. Fogel is looking sharp tonight, dressed up in a gray shirt, a colorful tie, a blazer, pleated pants and black leather sneakers. Also present are five other comedians -- aspiring stand-ups he has met through the open-mike circuit or in classes -- whom he has booked for this event. The stage is just an open area on the green carpet in front of a grand piano, but there's a spotlight and a real microphone.
 ''Hi, folks,'' Mr. Fogel says by way of introduction. ''I want to let you know about a few rules for the comedy show. There's no cover charge, but there's a two-I.V. minimum.''
 The crowd laughs.
 It's a sparse gathering: two middle-aged women in the front row, a pretty young volunteer, a bearded man in a hospital robe in a wheelchair who is here with his wife, and a woman in a gown who is hooked up to an actual I.V.
 ''We're going to make you happy, make you forget about the place,'' Mr. Fogel says. Then he turns the stage over to his colleagues. 
 A comedian named Mark Hertzberg does a routine in which he reveals that his head of hair is a toupee and then makes the toupee talk like a puppet. Then he and Mr. Fogel do a routine in which Mr. Hertzberg sings questions and Mr. Fogel answers in a falsetto. The patients love it.
 After a few more comedians take their turns, Mr. Fogel closes the show by singing a song to the tune of ''That's Amore.'' 
 ''When the girls say no to you, like they always do, that's a-Maury.
 ''When you live with your mother and you're feeling smothered, that's a-Maury.''
 As the patients trickle out, they express their appreciation. ''That was awesome; it really was,'' a patient's husband says. A recreation therapist chimes in: ''The patients really like it. If they're laughing, it really changes them physiologically, and it can have a lasting effect.''
 ''That's why we have this guy,'' Mr. Hertzberg says. ''So the patients can say, I may be really sick, but at least I'm not Maury.''

SECTION: Section 1; Column 2; Foreign Desk; THE REACH OF WAR: OUTLOOK; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1836 words

HEADLINE: In Iraq, U.S. Officials Cite Obstacles to Victory

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 

 BODY:
Senior American military commanders and civilian officials in Iraq are speaking more candidly about the hurdles that could jeopardize their plans to defeat an adaptive and tenacious insurgency and hold elections in January. 
 Outwardly, they give an upbeat assessment that the counterinsurgency is winnable. But in interviews with 15 of the top American generals, admirals and embassy officials conducted in Iraq in late October, many described risks that could worsen the security situation and derail the political process that they are counting on to help quell the insurgency. 
 Commanders voiced fears that many of Iraq's expanding security forces, soon to be led by largely untested generals, have been penetrated by spies for the insurgents. Reconstruction aid is finally flowing into formerly rebel-held cities like Samarra and other areas, but some officers fear that bureaucratic delays could undermine the aid's calming effects. They also spoke of new American intelligence assessments that show that the insurgents have significantly more fighters -- 8,000 to 12,000 hard-core militants -- and far greater financial resources than previously estimated. 
 Perhaps most disturbing, they said, is the militants' campaign of intimidation to silence thousands of Iraqis and undermine the government through assassinations, kidnappings, beheadings and car bombings. New gangs specializing in hostage-taking are entering Iraq, intelligence reports indicate. 
 ''If we can't stop the intimidation factor, we can't win,'' said Lt. Gen. John F. Sattler, the commander of nearly 40,000 marines and soldiers in western and south-central Iraq, who is drawing up battle plans for a possible showdown with more than 3,000 guerrillas in Falluja and Ramadi, with the hope of destroying the leadership of the national insurgency.
 In some cases, senior officers say, their goals could inadvertently act at cross purposes. For example, Iraq cannot hold meaningful national elections if militants still control major Sunni cities like Falluja. Negotiations there have broken down and many officers predict a military offensive. But hard-line Sunni clerics say they will call for an election boycott if American troops use force to put down the insurrection. 
 ''Getting Sunnis involved in the political process to me is the biggest thing that has to happen to help the security situation,'' said one senior commander. ''If a good portion of Sunnis don't participate, then that may give life to a larger Sunni insurgency. That's worrisome.'' 
 Some pivotal political decisions, including those shaping the election process and setting a time to attack militants in Falluja, rest with Prime Minister Ayad Allawi and his government, leaving American officials in the position, at best, of just trying to influence their outcome. Despite these obstacles, these officers and officials still express optimism that their detailed campaign plan and its military, political and economic elements have provided the blueprint for retaking rebel-held cities and navigating a tumultuous period when violence will undoubtedly intensify as insurgents seek to delay or scuttle the elections. That plan, adopted in August, is refined every two weeks by top American and Iraqi generals.
 ''I'm guardedly optimistic,'' said Brig. Gen. John DeFreitas III, the military's chief intelligence officer in Iraq. ''If you look at Najaf, Tal Afar and Samarra, I think we are having good effects.'' 
 For the first time, military officers also disclosed that the United States could begin withdrawing its 138,000 troops from Iraq in July, if Iraqi security forces have established control and the threats plaguing Iraq now have lessened. ''It's a mark on the wall,'' said one senior officer. 

The Military Answer
 But when pressed in interviews and informal conversations -- mostly not for attribution, because of fear that their more candid remarks could be used as campaign fodder back home -- senior commanders and civilian officials voiced misgivings about how their plans could go awry, reflecting the unpredictability of events in Iraq.
 ''It's a very complex country, and there are many things to worry about,'' said one senior officer. ''But we're trying to work through all the unforeseen results of an insurgency that becomes more robust.'' 
 Senior military officers say they are under no illusion that military might alone will resolve Iraq's problems. At best, using force to retake rebel-held cities will help establish an environment secure enough to allow political and economic programs that will ultimately defeat the insurgency, they say. 
 Gen. George W. Casey Jr., the top American commander in Iraq, compares the priorities in Iraq to two giant locomotive engines, one generating new Iraqi security forces, the other producing reconstruction gains, aides say. The two are intended to generate ''irreversible momentum'' that demonstrates to Iraqis and to the American public that steady progress, even if sometimes halting is being made. 
 Each morning General Casey's command briefing includes a slide called ''Drumbeat,'' a detailed compilation of progress made in security, governance and the economy. No accomplishment is too minor for mention, from the opening of a new hospital to the signing of contracts for water projects. General Casey presses his commanders to show that reconstruction projects are under way and ''turning dirt,'' and not just on the books. Right now there are about 700 such projects, with 1,800 scheduled to be under way by year's end, officers said. 
 Lt. Gen. David H. Petraeus, the head of training and equipping Iraqi security forces, has a more colorful analogy. Succeeding in Iraq, he says, is like a cattle drive from Texas to Wyoming in the Old West: the cattle are the myriad tasks that need to be done in Iraq, and American and Iraqi trail bosses are battling insurgent rustlers, treacherous conditions and daunting logistical problems to keep the herd moving. ''I don't think it's too late to succeed, but it's not going to be easy,'' he said. ''The bottom line is, you just have to keep it going.'' 
 The broader context, senior officers and embassy officials say, is for the United States to stay the course and be patient, with the aim of restoring local control to Iraqis and helping to rebuild the security forces and the economy.
 ''We can't lose this one,'' said Maj. Gen. Henry W. Stratman, who as deputy chief of staff for political, military and economic affairs is the military's main liaison with the United States Embassy and Iraqi ministries.

Confronting Intimidation
 The military is measuring its progress against a 43-page document, prosaically titled ''Multinational Force Iraq Campaign Plan: Operation Iraqi Freedom.'' Under this plan, the military uses up to 215 measurements to gauge progress in 15 pivotal cities and 7 smaller towns that must be brought under control before nationwide elections can be held. 
 The measurements are reviewed weekly by senior officials, including 25 military planners nicknamed the Brainiacs, who are responsible for anticipating worst-case situations and proposing possible solutions. Every other week, General Casey and his top aides adjust the measurements to reflect changing dynamics on the ground. 
 ''I see indications to believe the security environment will be sufficient for Iraq to have legitimate elections in January,'' said Maj. Gen. Stephen T. Sargeant, the plan's main author. 
 Officials say General Casey and John D. Negroponte, the United States ambassador in Baghdad, have a close and cordial working relationship, unlike that of their predecessors, Lt. Gen. Ricardo S. Sanchez and L. Paul Bremer III. ''It's like night and day,'' one senior officer said.
 But senior officers also say there are formidable hurdles ahead. 
 The recent massacre of 49 newly trained Iraqi soldiers in eastern Iraq illustrates the lengths that the insurgents, including former Baathist security forces and followers of the Jordanian militant Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, will go to terrorize Iraqis who work with the Americans or take part in the new government. 
 Military intelligence in recent weeks has reported the discovery of numerous suicide-bomber vests bound for Baghdad and new kidnapping gangs crossing the border into Iraq. Since the start of the holy month of Ramadan two weeks ago, daily attacks have increased by 30 percent. 
 A job-training program conducted by Navy Seabees near Falluja to teach construction skills to young Iraqis shut down earlier this month when the 30 students stopped coming to work, fearing retaliation. 
 Another casualty of the intimidation campaign is the flow of information from ordinary Iraqis to the military about the location of militants and their arms, including roadside bombs. As rebel-held cities are retaken, commanders say, tips from residents have picked up, but more information is needed. ''Intelligence is still a weakness,'' a senior embassy official said.

The Economic Issues
 Despite the bombings aimed at Iraqi security forces, American commanders say, there is no shortage of fresh recruits, a reflection of the desperate economic straits most Iraqis face. There are now about 100,000 Iraqi security forces trained and equipped, with 45,000 more scheduled to report by the end of the year. 
 Some Iraqi units have performed well in recent fighting, especially some elite Iraqi commando units. Earlier this month, 2,000 Iraqi troops helped American forces retake Samarra. But one Iraqi battalion reported that 300 of its 750 soldiers abandoned the unit before the offensive began Oct. 1.
 American commanders fear that many Iraqi units are penetrated by informants. They are also grappling with cultural differences. With no formal national banking system in place, recruits and other troops need to bring their paychecks home to their families. ''If you have four infantry companies, one is always on leave,'' a senior American officer said. 
 The Americans have ambitious goals. ''By next July, I hope enough of the Iraqi security forces will be trained and equipped that they'll be able to conduct independent counterinsurgency operations, with some support,'' one senior commander said. ''There will still be an insurgency; it's not going to go away. But we're trying to get it down to a lower level, where the Iraqi security forces can deal with it.'' 
 Once militants are driven out of their enclaves, the aim is to rush in economic aid, in large part to win over the civilian population. ''We need to take Iraqis off the streets and give them meaningful jobs so they're holding shovels and hammers, not AK-47's,'' said Charles Hess, director of the Army's Iraq Project and Contracting Office, which oversees $12.6 billion in reconstruction programs. 
 In Samarra, Maj. Gen. John R. Batiste, commander of the Army's First Infantry Division, had a blunt warning for his superiors recently: ''We've got to get these unemployed folks back to work. We have a very small window of opportunity to make this work.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: Cadets training at the Baghdad Police Academy. Despite intimidation by insurgents, Iraqis are enlisting. (Photo by Shawn Baldwin for The New York Times)
Gen. George W. Casey Jr., above, and Lt. Gen. David H. Petraeus say security and reconstruction must proceed hand in hand to allow elections in January. (Photo by Christopher Berkey/Associated Press)
 (Pool photo by Nikola Solic)(pg. 11) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: REBELLIONS & INSURGENCIES (94%); WAR & CONFLICT (90%); TERRORISM (90%); BOMBS & EXPLOSIVE DEVICES (90%); ELECTIONS (90%); ASSASSINATION (90%); MILITARY WEAPONS (90%); ARMED FORCES (89%); POLITICS (89%); MUSLIMS & ISLAM (89%); KIDNAPPING & ABDUCTION (87%); CIVIL WAR (78%); BOMBINGS (78%); PRIME MINISTERS (77%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (77%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (77%); INTERVIEWS (77%); BOYCOTTS (76%); TERRORIST ATTACKS (74%); HOSTAGE TAKING (74%); EMBASSIES & CONSULATES (71%); INTELLIGENCE SERVICES (71%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (69%) United States International Relations; United States Armament and Defense; Elections; Bombs and Explosives; Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations; Terrorism; Kidnapping; Civil War and Guerrilla Warfare

PERSON: DAVID PETRAEUS (58%) Eric Schmitt

GEOGRAPHIC: BAGHDAD, IRAQ (79%) UNITED STATES (98%); IRAQ (94%) Iraq; Iraq

LOAD-DATE: October 31, 2004

Copyright 2004 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 31, 2004
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2204 words

HEADLINE: Want to Invest? Join the Club.

BYLINE: By VIVIAN MARINO

 BODY:
AS a mortgage broker, Richard Banach helped many investors finance real estate deals over the years, but when it came to his own money, he stayed mostly with stocks, a strategy he has grown to regret. ''I've seen people with marginal credit and modest means making big money in real estate,'' he said, while he has watched his technology-heavy portfolio swell, then shrivel. 
 Now ''totally out of stocks,'' Mr. Banach, 46, who lives in Glen Head, N.Y., said he will focus on real estate. While he has the advantage of knowing something about buying property, he realizes that finding good deals won't be easy in a still-rising market crammed with other stock market refugees. So last year he joined the Long Island Investors Group, a club that serves both as an informal repository of information about properties for sale and as a support group. 
 The nonprofit club offers him the chance to network with other members at social events or at the monthly meetings at the Marriott Hotel in Melville, attend workshops on ''ugly houses,'' or even go on field trips. The group doesn't invest collectively, as stock investment clubs do, though it does encourage independent partnerships. 
 Already, he has made some valuable connections. ''I have a couple of possibilities in the pipeline,'' said Mr. Banach, who is looking to use his professional expertise to buy individual homes and finance larger residential projects. 
 Real estate groups have been around in one form or another for years, though interest in them has shot up recently, in response to the volatility on Wall Street as well as the rising home prices on Main Street. There are at least a dozen clubs in the tristate region alone, and many of them, like the Garden State Real Estate Investors Association, the Greater Westchester Real Estate Investors Association and the Connecticut Real Estate Investors Association, were created in just the last three years. 
 By contrast, stock investment club membership has dwindled, with the number of clubs declining 43 percent since 1998, a peak year, according to the National Association of Investors Corporation in Madison Heights, Mich.
 ''People are looking for another way to invest, and real estate remains a hot topic,'' said Rebecca McLean, the executive director of the National Real Estate Investors Association in Covington, Ky., which promotes a code of ethics for investors and provides services to clubs like product discounts and newsletters. There are 157 nonprofit clubs, with 20,000 members, affiliated with the professional group, up from 88 clubs, and 14,000 members, a year ago, although Ms. McLean is quick to point out that they represent only about a quarter of all the real estate investment clubs in existence. 
 ''What our clubs try to do,'' she said, ''is help people make informed decisions about investing. Some do become millionaires, but it doesn't happen overnight.''
 Those starting out must first learn the ropes and understand the risks, and that takes time -- usually 6 to 18 months, on average, before most people absorb enough information to feel comfortable initiating their first deals, said Dan Schwartz, the vice president for the 300-member Metropolitan Real Estate Investors Association in Kenilworth, N.J., which has been around for 22 years. The club guides new members along in the process through ''mentoring breakfasts'' and speaker meetings that cover the basics. ''Our program is a get-rich-slow program,'' he said. 
 Newcomers accustomed to investing in stocks, in fact, will have to get used to a more hands-on approach to investing -- not to mention learn a whole new vernacular. 
 While investing in stocks involves some work -- you may scour a company's income report or research the price-to-earnings ratio -- there's little else to do once shares are bought except decide when to sell. Investing in real estate, on the other hand, may mean walking around neighborhoods in search of ''motivated'' sellers with ''junkers'' (in other words, people eager to dump properties that are in bad shape) in order to ''rehab'' and ''flip'' them (fix them up and sell them quickly for a profit). Then there are opportunities to ''bird dog'' (or let other investors know about specific properties and collect a finder's fee on their deals). Looking for ''positive cash flow''? There are multifamily rental homes to invest in. For the more passive investor, tax-lien certificates sold at auction might work (that's when you buy the right to repossess other people's homes if they don't pay their property taxes). 
 Some investors will rely mainly on real estate brokers to help them find properties, especially those outside their communities, while others prefer to look for deals themselves.
 On a recent field trip to Jersey City and Ridgefield Park, N.J., about 50 members of the Garden State Real Estate Investors Association got some firsthand lessons in rehabbing. Traveling by chartered bus, the group spent nearly six hours touring investment properties, all owned by other club members and in various stages of repair, then returned to the club's headquarters in Maplewood for some classroom lessons. 
 ''We've been careful about maintaining the original moldings and design,'' said Marcia O'Connor, 43, owner of the three-bedroom, one-bath house in Jersey City that was one of the stops on the tour. ''We used to do a lot of the renovations ourselves in the beginning, and now we can afford to hire people to do the work.'' 
 Mrs. O'Connor said that she and her husband, Michael, 41, with whom she invests in real estate full time, expect to spend about $40,000 to fix up the kitchen and bathroom and install exterior aluminum siding and a new roof. The couple paid $135,000 for the 50-year-old house in July -- ''We purchased it from another investor, who bought it at a foreclosure sale and pocketed about $30,000,'' she said -- and expect to put it on the market before the end of the year for around $250,000. 
 One of the best things about being in a club, said Mrs. O'Connor, who lives in Secaucus, is the access it provides to reliable contractors, suppliers and other skilled people. Some professionals, like lawyers, accountants and contractors, a few of whom may be members themselves, offer club or group discounts. (Mr. Banach, the mortgage broker, has even gotten some extra business.) ''We do share contractors,'' Ms. O'Connor said, ''and we'll warn each other, too.'' 
 It is this camaraderie that is the cornerstone of a successful club. Investing ''can be an isolating experience,'' said Barbara A. Karnes, who is executive director and co-founder of the Long Island Investors Group, which started more than four years ago and now has 450 members. While club newcomers get support and guidance from the more experienced members -- like, say, tips on setting up a limited liability company to protect personal assets or even leads on available properties -- the experienced investors, in turn, get future business partners, or in some cases, buyers for the coaching services they might be offering independently. 
 Many clubs provide access to these products on their Web sites or through the real estate ''gurus'' invited to speak at meetings, but most don't aggressively promote them. John T. Reed, publisher of the Real Estate Investor's Monthly newsletter in Alamo, Calif., warns newcomers to be wary of the clubs that do. ''In the early 80's a bunch of bogus gurus used to own clubs -- like the 'nothing down' club -- and their motives were solely to promote their own businesses,'' he said. ''There are still some clubs that are run by people whose motives are selfish.'' But, he added, ''most are good people.''
 Wesley Barney, the president and founder of the Ultimate Investors Real Estate Club of Flushing, Queens, said his main goal right now is to help the club's 275 members find affordable properties. ''The real estate market in New York City has appreciated so much that many people just can't afford it,'' he said. 
 Mr. Barney, a former New York City Fire Department inspector who became a full-time investor five years ago, said he sees opportunities in up-and-coming areas like Kansas City, Mo., Biloxi, Miss., and upstate New York. He recently found a six-family rental building for $66,000 in a Syracuse neighborhood that he said is turning around. 
 At the club's Oct. 7 meeting, held at the New Yorker Hotel, at Eighth Avenue and 34th Street, Mr. Barney invited two real estate brokers, Fred and Betty Danbach of Syracuse, to talk about buying in their hometown. 
 ''Syracuse has been a well-kept secret for years,'' Mr. Danbach told a diverse audience of 70, whose dress ranged from business attire to blue jeans. ''It's very undervalued. But the market is changing dramatically, and after the first of the year, it's going to explode.''
 Mr. Danbach said Syracuse's economy, which lost manufacturing jobs over the years, is poised to rebound, thanks, in part, to major development plans for the city. 
 Myrna Ortiz, 38, a technical support specialist from Ozone Park, Queens, is banking on this turnaround. She said she recently bought a newly renovated seven-family brick building in Syracuse, for $240,000, and now is looking for more investment property there, which was why she was at the meeting. (After her mortgage and other expenses are paid, she expects to clear about $1,000 a month.) ''I'm looking to create positive cash flow and the highest rate of return,'' she said. ''I want to improve my lifestyle -- I don't want to work in the rat race for the rest of my life.''
 Seated up front, Joe Guilfu, 44, a transportation analyst from Park Slope, Brooklyn, seemed a bit more tentative about investing. ''There's probably more opportunity in real estate'' than in stocks, he said, though he admitted that he doesn't own any property yet, not even his personal residence.
 Some club members may never take the plunge, largely out of fear of losing money. In the Long Island Investors Group, ''60 percent of the members are active seasoned investors,'' Ms. Karnes said. ''Twenty percent have never done a deal, and they probably never will.'' By several accounts, membership turnover rates run around 5 percent to 30 percent per club each year. 
 ''I've seen a lot of people have a bad experience, but oftentimes it's because of their failure to educate themselves about the industry,'' said Tony Reaves, a co-founder of the Garden State Real Estate Investors Association, who invests full time with his wife, Patricia, the group's president.
 Mr. Barney, who admits to taking a few ''hits'' himself when he started out about 20 years ago, agreed. ''Contrary to what you may hear about real estate, there are risks,'' he said. ''You must invest in education, or it could financially ruin you.''
 He said the clubs help to teach members all the basics: how to find properties, how to fix them up and estimate renovation costs, how to sell them or turn them into rental units, and how to understand some of the laws and tax regulations that affect property owners. 
 Mr. Banach, the mortgage broker from Long Island, seems to be finding these things out on his own. Although he hasn't lost any money, he says he has run across some potential problems in his quest to find the right deal. ''I was in one contract, a foreclosure in the Bronx, but it fell through,'' he said. ''Another deal was presented to me, but I was suspicious about a signature that did not match.'' But he isn't giving up. ''I think there are a lot of interesting opportunities out there,'' he said, explaining that he may join with a builder he knows to buy seven houses in Freeport for $1.5 million, tear them down and build higher-end homes and sell them for a profit.
 Finding opportunities gets easier with time and experience, said JoAnne Brissette, the founder and executive director of the 1,000-member Connecticut Real Estate Investors Association. She advises new club members to attend at least one meeting a month and pick up at least one new idea that they can store away for future use -- and to keep an open mind.
 ''I myself see things differently now,'' she said. ''When I drive home and see a cute little home with an uncut lawn that is not being cared for, I see a potential opportunity.''

Choosing the Right Investment Group
 ANNUAL dues for real estate clubs range from about $75 to $250; some have discounts for couples. 
 Here are some tips for finding the best one:
 The National Association of Real Estate Investors keeps a list of affiliated clubs on its Web site,nationalreia.com. Click on ''groups,'' then the appropriate state.
 Check out each group's Web site. They will usually contain information about the group's mission, as well as its history, size and calendar of events. Some also have chat rooms or property listings.
 Sit in on a few meetings and talk to club members -- you'll get a sense about a group's philosophy and goals. Many clubs allow nonmembers to attend monthly meetings, subgroups or workshops for a guest fee, usually around $25. 
 Ask about mentoring programs. These are important ways to network with the more seasoned investor who can show you the ropes. 
 Avoid clubs that aggressively promote products, courses and services.

HEADLINE: Artists at Play, Debunking Sexual and Cultural Stereotypes

BYLINE: By BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

 BODY:
SOMETIMES, tracking contemporary art across north Connecticut can be just as stimulating as, say, doing the rounds of Chelsea art galleries on New York's west side. Right now, dedicated viewers can make a trail from Laura Carton's downloaded domestic pleasure-domes at Real Art Ways in Hartford, to Olu Oguibe's mini-retrospective at the Contemporary Art Galleries at the University of Connecticut in Storrs. This is full-strength stuff.
 Ms. Carton, 36, downloads onto her computer pornographic images from the Internet, removes the writhing bodies, and then digitally reconstructs the backgrounds. Outputted as glossy photographs, the images depict standard pornographic cliches (the convent, the school, the public toilet) and a few specialty fantasy sites (the abandoned building, the graveyard). But shorn of buffed, blow-dried actors, they lose their practical function and become open-ended. Your imagination does the rest. 
 Ms. Carton is not the only contemporary artist to fall under porn's sway. But unlike her mostly male peers, who often show graphic sexual activity, Ms. Carton believes the suggestion of sex can be more titillating than depictions of the real thing. Her eerie photographs only hint at erotic activity. 
 Each of the photographs is titled after the Web site from which the image was lifted. Although few read as obviously pornographic, many contain subliminal sexual messages. Note, for instance, a gentleman's hat on the floor of a picture of a men's public urinal, or a golf ball ambling toward a flagless hole on a miniature golf course green. This last image arrives courtesy of an explicit gay male Web site, best limited to a knowing few. No prizes for guessing the symbolism there.
 What's particularly alluring about these images is the way they implicate the viewer in the missing action. Writing about the photographs, the curator of the show, Steven Holmes, notes that ''in order to complete the experience of looking at these images, the viewer has to replace what Carton removed.'' This can be an unnerving experience, especially when confronted with some of the more unusual backgrounds -- a barbershop, a graveyard or, rather more frighteningly, a handsome white steed in a beachside paddock. Yikes. 
 One problem with Ms. Carton's photographs is the image quality. Because she lifts her pictures directly off the Internet, she has no control over their size and density, giving her little latitude to alter or blow them up without significant image degradation. The result is often blurry, slightly pixilated photographs, which I'm guessing would be even more captivating and creepy if we could see them with the kind of precision and clarity that is often found on the Internet. This is a genuine formal challenge. 
 While Ms. Carton trades in sexual cliches, Mr. Oguibe deals with racial and cultural stereotypes. Born in Nigeria in 1964, he moved to London as a political refugee in 1989 before decamping for New York in 1995. Now based in Storrs, where he teaches at the university, his work is largely socially driven with a core interest in popular depictions of Africa, Africans and African-Americans. He also carries on a parallel practice as a writer, poet and art historian, and has written several books.
 Viewers addicted to sound bites and overnight polls may have trouble mustering the patience Mr. Oguibe's artworks require. Simply put, they take some reading. But for those with the time, a conceptual bent, a commitment to social justice and greater economic fairness among nations, then this exhibition has much to offer. It is also a tidy summation of Mr. Oguibe's artistic activities over the past few years, ranging from ceramics, painting and photography to sculpture and installation.
 Among the more accessible pieces is ''Ethnographia 2.1'' (2000), a witty wall installation of 22 drawings with text supposedly produced by a character traveling in late 19th-century America. The material, concocted by the artist, details encounters with various ethnic and religious groups -- Quakers, Irish -- along with the traveler's surprise at American social mores and local customs. It's all about the opacity of cultural difference and how misunderstanding can lead to skewed representations of others.
 Ideas of misunderstanding, place, voice, social justice and loss recur throughout these works. A nearby installation consists of a Bible with a page torn out, rewritten and then replaced to reflect African history and contemporary aspirations, while another mocks the G8 group of industrialized nations as a self-serving club mindlessly directing the fate of millions in impoverished nations.
 Unsettling as all this might seem, the bark of these slick, aesthetic-minded works is far bigger than their bite.
 ''Laura Carton'' is at Real Art Ways, 56 Arbor Street, Hartford, through Nov. 15. Information: (860)232-1006 or www.realartways.org. ''Olu Oguibe, An Introspective'' is at the Contemporary Art Galleries, UConn, 30 Bolton Road, Storrs, through Nov. 12. Information: (860)486-1511.


GRAPHIC: Photos: Olu Oguibe's print ''Bridge(Triptych)'' is on display at the University of Connecticut in Storrs. Mr. Oguibe teaches at the university.
 Real Art Ways in Hartford is featuring photographs by Laura Carton. She downloads pornographic images and removes the writhing bodies.

HEADLINE: Need for Draft Is Dismissed By Officials At Pentagon

BYLINE: By THOM SHANKER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 

 BODY:
Rumors of a secret plan to reinstate the draft are churning across the Internet, worrying some in Congress and even coloring the presidential campaign, but senior Pentagon personnel officials and Army officers insist that there is no need for a draft -- and that they do not want one, either. 
 To counter public fears that conscription is returning, these officials produced internal studies to illustrate the economic and demographic reasons why a draft is not necessary, and why it would be a step backward for the quality of the current all-volunteer force.
 Army and Pentagon officials hope that efforts under way to reorganize the service to form at least 43 combat brigades from today's 33 will create additional deployable units and alleviate the stress on the Army. And as both the Air Force and Navy shrink their personnel rosters, some of those departing personnel are being courted by the Army in a program that also serves as antidote to the draft. 
 If a decision is made that the American military should grow, then the Pentagon could ask Congress to finance a permanent expansion in personnel, including enough money to attract recruits and retain those in uniform without undercutting accounts for operations and weapons systems.
 Officials note that Congressional proposals for expanding the military, mostly in the range of 30,000 to 40,000 more troops, would hardly require a new draft to force conscripts from across the approximately two-million-strong cohort of current 18-year-old Americans.
 In fact, the demographics of America are cited by Pentagon officials as a major reason why the draft makes no sense today.
 The Pentagon's top personnel officer, David S.C. Chu, said the size of today's military -- 1.4 million in the active component, and 1.2 million in the National Guard and Reserve -- is a much smaller percentage of a much larger pool of possible recruits than the United States faced during World War II and into the 1950's.
 And since the military could not possibly absorb all the 18-year-olds in the population should a draft be reinstated, there is little doubt that a system of deferrals would be established that, just as in the Vietnam era, could create a caste-like system separating the privileged of America from the others.
 ''What do you do when not all need to be called and only a few are chosen?'' said Mr. Chu, who is under secretary of defense for personnel and readiness. ''It becomes a question of fairness.''
 Today's high-technology military also benefits from personnel who are committed to staying in the service for several years, allowing the armed services to reap full benefit from their costly training. During the draft, soldiers were required to stay in the service for only two years. But Pentagon studies show that current recruits need one to three years to reach full competency in combat or support skills.
 A study by Mr. Chu's office makes that point in arguing against reinstating a draft that was allowed to lapse on July 1, 1973.
 ''Draftees quit early; volunteers stay -- so today's midgrade and senior noncommissioned officers are well experienced,'' said the study, written by Bill Carr, deputy under secretary for military personnel policy.
 ''During the most recent draft, 90 percent of conscripts quit after their initial two-year hitch, whereas retention of volunteers is five times better -- about half remain after their initial (normally four-year) military service obligation,'' said the study, which was published in the spring 2004 edition of ''World Defense Systems,'' a military journal.
 Those statistics may not be persuasive to those who believe the United States is poised for a broader array of offensive military operations against other adversaries that would require a draft, nor to those who feel that a program of required national service would benefit the nation and America's 18-year-olds.
 But senior officers stress that the all-volunteer military is also more competent, better educated and more disciplined than in the final years of the draft.
 ''I served in the draftee Army,'' said Gen. Richard A. Cody, who is now vice chief of staff for the Army, the service most under stress from worldwide deployments.
 ''Those soldiers were just as loyal as today,'' he said. ''But it was like Forrest Gump. You know, 'Life is like a box of chocolates.' With conscripts, you never know what you're going to get.''
 General Cody said the strain to meet current global commitments cannot be minimized -- nor the strain to meet recruiting goals. But he said the young men and women who signed up today were of a higher quality than any he had seen in 29 years of command.
 ''I don't have rose-colored glasses on,'' General Cody said. ''But we don't need the draft and we don't want the draft. There are plenty of Americans who still want to be in the military.''
 Perhaps the most often-cited reason for opposition to a draft is the motivation of the all-volunteer force.
 ''The most important thing about a draft is that the people you draft, by definition, don't all want to be there,'' Mr. Chu said. ''The great strength of the volunteer force is the ranks of people who all made a positive, voluntary decision that this is what they want to do.''
 The current American military ''is also smarter than the general population'' from which conscripts would be drawn, according to the study by Mr. Chu's office. ''Over 90 percent of new recruits have a high school diploma, while only 75 percent of the American youth do; 67 percent score in the upper half of the enlistment (math/verbal aptitude) test,'' it stated.
 ''These attributes translate to lower attrition, faster training and higher performance,'' it concluded. 
 Mr. Chu said that studies of the military also showed that the all-volunteer force had fewer disciplinary problems than a draftee service.
 ''All that comes together in the performance of the force in the field, which is the ultimate test,'' Mr. Chu said. ''How does this force fight? How well does it carry out the nation's objectives? How disciplined is it in the face of challenges? I don't think anyone can look at the events of the three-plus years since 9/11 and not see the payoff in the volunteer force.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: With the military struggling to meet recruiting numbers, Gen. Richard Cody of the Army spoke to recruits in Times Square this month. (Photo by Spencer Platt/Getty Images) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HEADLINE: For Teenagers, Talk of a Draft Is Chilling

BYLINE: By JANE GORDON

 BODY:
AT dinner tables, in Boy Scout meetings, on chat rooms, in e-mail messages and on the phone, teenagers around the state are talking about a topic that hasn't been seriously discussed in Connecticut homes for more than 30 years. It is forced military conscription, otherwise known as the draft.
 In Suffield, Sean McGuinness, 17, talked it over with other Boy Scouts weeks ago, to get a sense of what his friends would do if drafted. At the private Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Vaughan Read, 17, started an online chat room in the spring on the topic. And in East Windsor, Alex Grant, 15, who is related to Ulysses S. Grant, must think about the draft from a perspective like none of his peers.
 ''If I were to be drafted, I would probably do other things than battle,'' said Alex, a sophomore at East Windsor High School. ''I would go for conscientious objector status. U.S. Grant is a relative of mine, but it doesn't mean I'm for war because he was a military man.'' 
 At ages when teenagers are commonly concentrating on school, flirting, thinking about college and following the World Series, the draft is a grownup concern that they are sharing with their teachers, their parents and each other. And with teenagers, talk breeds more talk.
 They dissect comments made by Donald H. Rumsfeld, the secretary of defense, wondering if he is hinting about restarting the draft. They tell stories about Army Reserve units that are serving longer in Iraq than originally planned, telling each other that proves that the military doesn't have enough soldiers and that a draft could be coming. Many students even knew the status and the names (H.R. 163 and S. 89) of Congressional bills that would reinstate the draft. 
 ''After that vote, the draft, which had been a concern, became almost a moot point with the students,'' said Michael Harrigan, the chairman of East Windsor's social studies department, referring to the defeat of the House bill. ''They said, 'Hey, the House of Representatives voted it down overwhelmingly,' and they obviously felt relief. But then the skeptics said, 'Well, it's 30 days before an election, so who is going to vote for that?' So the students realized the timing of the vote did not give a true picture of how our politicians may feel. I have found students are more skeptical these days.''
 The Horatio Alger Association of Distinguished Americans, a national nonprofit educational group in Virginia, asked more than 1,000 students this year whether they thought they would have to serve in the military. About 55 percent said yes.
 ''It's been a topic that most of my buddies have talked about,'' said Sean McGuinness, a Boy Scout who is a senior at Suffield High School. ''Economically and diplomatically, the way things are going right now, the odds of having a draft will be increased.'' 
 Rebecca Brown, 15, a sophomore at East Windsor, said her father is a veteran.
 ''My father served in Korea during the Vietnam War,'' she said. ''He had horrific stories. Now I'm worried about my brother, who spent four years in the Coast Guard, getting a call. He's 23, and he's living at home now.'' 
 At the Hotchkiss School, an online chat room, the Hotchkiss View, became a popular outlet for student's draft-related opinions. Vaughan Read, a senior, decided to create the Internet forum after students began discussing the issue in the cafeteria.
 ''My dad and his friends compared draft numbers during the Vietnam era the way my friends and I compare SAT scores,'' Vaughan said. ''I don't know if kids are taking it that seriously. But I kind of think a draft would make us as Americans more serious about what conflicts we choose to join. If you knew it would be your life or your son's or daughter's life that would be sacrificed, it might change your view.''
 Liz Paonessa, 16, a junior in the Civics and Law class taught by Leslie Traver at Lyme-Old Lyme High School, said she could not imagine going to war.
 ''None of my friends were at all interested in a draft, and I would definitely freak out if I were drafted,'' she said. ''I could just never see myself fighting in any way.''
 Other students said that, barring a deferment, they would go to war. ''I'd do it if I had to,'' said Meg Carley, 17, a senior at Darien High School. ''I'd only do it because it's the honorable thing to do.'' 
 Standing in the hall across from the guidance office at East Windsor High, David Hastings, the senior class president, said he had been discussing a draft with friends and teachers for some time.
 ''I hate the notion of going to war,'' he said. ''But if I was forced to go, I'd go. My friends said they'd go, too.''
 In other schools, like North Haven High School, the topic has hardly come up, said Lou Preziosi, an assistant principal. He is a volunteer registrar with the Selective Service. There are 116 volunteer registrars working in Connecticut schools, from administrators to teachers and guidance counselors. Mr. Preziosi and the school's career resource director, Robert Iverson, hung informational posters about Selective Service requirements at the school. They informed students at the annual senior assembly that they must register with the Selective Service. (Males are required to do so within 30 days of turning 18.) They delivered announcements over the school's intercom to remind students.
 ''I don't think it has hit home that the draft is even a possibility here, while the students are under the umbrella and safety of the high school,'' Mr. Preziosi said. ''They are hearing that candidates are saying there will not be a draft; maybe they are believing it.''
 Since 1973 and the elimination of the draft, the armed forces have relied on recruitment. Five high schools in Connecticut have centers for the Junior Reserved Officers Training Corps in their buildings: Bloomfield High, Crosby High in Waterbury, James Hillhouse High in New Haven, Westhill High in Stamford, and New Britain High. The number of recruits for the active Army, as opposed to the Army Reserve, from Connecticut for the past four years has averaged about 585, according to the United States Army Recruiting Command. The average for the Army Reserve is about 265.
 ''We met our fiscal year 2004 recruiting mission, so we're good to go,'' Doug Smith, a spokesman for the command, said about national recruitment. 
 United States Representative John Larson, a Democrat from East Hartford who is a member of the House Armed Services Committee, and 41 other members of the House, sent a letter recently to the Government Accountability Office asking for a study of recruiting and retention efforts in the armed forces. The letter mentioned that the National Guard had fallen short in its recruiting goals and pressed the point that it was looking like the armed forces were short on manpower. 
 ''Congressman Larson has always said he is opposed to a draft, and there is no official draft,'' said Michael Kirk, a spokesman for Mr. Larson. ''The president and the administration have taken steps to keep a lot of people in the military -- stop-loss orders, calling back members of the reserves who are retired military -- and these are measures that underscore the fact that our military is stretched very thin. So the legislators are trying to get to the root of the problem.'' 
 David Greenberg, an assistant professor of journalism, media studies and history at Rutgers University in New Jersey, has studied the historical opposition to the draft and said Americans rarely have embraced one.
 ''I don't think there will be a draft this time because it is politically unpopular,'' he said. ''For most of American history, we have not had a draft. Popular objections carried the day.'' 
 If Mr. Greenberg is right, the letters and e-mail messages that have been delivered to legislators may hold some sway. About 300 of them had arrived at the offices of United States Representative Rob Simmons by Oct. 21, about 300 at Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's Washington office, about 200 to Mr. Larson. Many of the letters were from teenagers.
 Rosa DeLauro, the representative for the Third District, said in an e-mail message, ''Rumors of the draft spread through my district, prompting many teenagers, their parents and loved ones to contact me with their fears.'' 
 At the McGuinness house in Suffield, emotions were varied. Vikki McGuinness, Sean McGuinness's mother, saw friends leave for Vietnam when she was a teenager.
 ''I remember the riots on TV and all the protests,'' Mrs. McGuinness said. ''It is scary to think my son might have to sign up for a draft.''
 Sean said he knows his parents are concerned for his safety. ''My father doesn't want me to go into it, neither does my mother, and personally, I don't know if I'm comfortable with a draft,'' he said. ''But if it happened, I would go, as long as my parents don't send me to Canada first.''

Michael Harrigan of East Windsor High School leading a discussion of the draft in his social studies class. (Photo by M.J. Fiedler for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 945 words

HEADLINE: When We Were Wooed

BYLINE: By JOHN FERLING. 
John Ferling is the author of ''Adams vs. Jefferson: The Tumultuous Election of 1800.''

 BODY:
With the presidential election hanging on the outcome of the vote in eight or so swing states, we're approaching America's quadrennial obsession with the Electoral College. New Yorkers often complain that the Electoral College disenfranchises them because nobody bothers to campaign hard in our reliably blue state. 
 Once, however, New York was a swing state. In the most bitterly contested election of American history -- no, it wasn't in 2000, but in 1800, when Thomas Jefferson ran against the incumbent, John Adams -- New York State, particularly New York City, was the battleground that decided the election. 
 Many of the hallmarks of this year's election were present in 1800. The mudslinging and negative campaigning, for example, included attacks on Adams's foreign policy and Jefferson's war record -- his comfortable lifestyle at Monticello during much of the Revolutionary War and his alleged failure as a wartime governor of Virginia. But there were also significant differences between then and now -- perhaps none more important than that in most states, including New York, presidential electors were chosen by the state legislators rather than by direct popular voting. What's more, each elector cast two votes -- for separate candidates. At the time, the Constitution stipulated that the candidate with the most votes, if those constituted a majority, was to be president. The runner-up became vice president. 
 From the outset in the 1800 election, it was widely presumed that New York's vote would be decisive. With 12 electors, New York had a level of clout that was surpassed only by that of Massachusetts (which was certain to give its votes to Adams) and of two Jeffersonian strongholds -- Virginia and Pennsylvania. Adams had carried New York in 1796 en route to winning the presidency by a scant three electoral votes. His re-election depended on winning the state once again.
 Adams's Federalist Party expected to retain its control of the New York State Legislature -- and, thus, its electoral votes -- in the state elections set for April 1800. Indeed, the Republicans, Jefferson's faction, were so despairing of winning a legislative majority that early in the year they proposed that New York change its method of selecting presidential electors. They sought to have the outcome of the popular vote in each district determine the elector for that district, a device through which the Republicans might pick up one or two of the state's electoral votes. But confident of winning control of the Legislature -- a victory that would enable them to name all 12 electors -- the Federalists rejected the proposal. 
 This Federalist Party decision to spurn the popular election of electors was one of the great blunders in the history of presidential campaigns. With New York City providing the decisive vote, the Republicans pulled off a stunning upset that gave them a hairsbreadth majority in the State Legislature. 
 In the race for the State Legislature, two things above all else accounted for the Republican victory in New York City. Aaron Burr -- a New Yorker who had been a United States senator and a state assemblyman -- understood the political system better than most of his contemporaries. He sensed that the city's workers, who historically supported the Federalists, were disillusioned and ripe for a change of loyalty. 
 Burr built a well-oiled party apparatus, one of the first in America. He spoke at street rallies, provided food and lodging for party workers who labored around the clock, and selected a slate of celebrity candidates. On Election Day, he sent party activists into the wards to get voters to the polls -- dispatching German-speakers to neighborhoods inhabited by German immigrants, for instance. The Federalists, led by Alexander Hamilton, did not bother with any of these tactics. 
 Burr, who later joined Jefferson on the Republican slate,was correct about the workers' disenchantment. Many had come to see the Federalists as elitists who refused to shake hands with artisans and who looked down on self-made men. To them, the Federalist Party had become the bastion of conservatives who abhorred participatory politics, upheld social traditionalism and were committed to an economy that favored the wealthy -- a party, in short, committed to blocking the changes that middle- and lower-class Americans had hoped would be realized through the American Revolution.
 In April, the Republicans captured all 12 of New York City's seats in the State Legislature, scoring overwhelming victories in the working-class wards of what were then the upper reaches of Manhattan. Their triumph in the city gave them control of the State Legislature. 
 The first lady, Abigail Adams, wrote to her sons that the Republicans had won because they had ''laid their plans with more skill than their opponents.'' She added that ''N York would be the balance'' in the fall's presidential election. She was right. New York's 12 electors cast all their votes for Jefferson and Burr. Of the votes cast by the 138 electors nationwide, 73 went to Jefferson and 73 to Burr. Adams came in third, with 65. All but one of the remaining votes went to Charles Cotesworth Pinckney, the other Federalist candidate. The outcome -- Jefferson as president, Burr as vice president -- was determined by the House of Representatives. 
 For the first time, a sitting president was turned out of office. For the first time, too, a presidential election turned on artful modern politicking -- in a swing state. As Burr explained to his vanquished opponents: ''We have beat you by superior management.'' 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: The Fellowship of the Reel

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS J. GILLISON

 BODY:
SHUCKING bait clams under a sliver of moon early on a recent Saturday, Tino Hernandez, a retired construction worker, rediscovered his friend of 25 years aboard the Pilot, their favorite fishing boat in Sheepshead Bay. 
 It had been 10 years since Mr. Hernandez, 65, had seen Mino Riviera, a 75-year-old retired X-ray technician. He happened upon Mr. Riviera, who has fished on the boat for almost 40 years, only by chance. ''It is good to be among friends,'' was all Mr. Riviera could say, for bashfulness. 
 Friendships -- old, new and revived -- are strong themes aboard the party fishing boats of Sheepshead Bay, which ply local waters so their customers can catch porgies, bluefish, sea bass, weakfish, tuna, mackerel, blackfish and more. The friendships sometimes constitute something of a second family, even though the anglers come from sharply different walks of life.
 Aboard the Pilot that Saturday morning, the party heading out into the dramatic blue and red sunrise included a Manhattan real estate developer, a tailor, a set designer from Williamsburg, some construction workers, a wholesale importer and a caretaker for the New York City Housing Authority. All had paid $39 for a chance to land some porgies.
 ''I could easily go out to Long Island,'' said Ray, a 53-year-old construction worker from Queens. ''But here it's like a family friend.''
 Social distinctions typically disappear when customers climb aboard. ''Whether they make a lot of money or whether they make less than an average income is really of no avail out here,'' said the captain, Thomas Marconi, who has been operating the Pilot for 40 of his 58 years. ''They're all equal when they come on my boat.'' 
 But these warm feelings are tinged with the bittersweet. Although Brooklyn officials are seeking to help the industry -- State Senator Carl Kruger, for example, has proposed turning some empty land nearby into a parking lot and providing jitney service to the marina -- the party boats of Sheepshead Bay have been on the decline for years.
 George Richford, the owner and operator of a party boat called the Pastime Princess, said that when he started working in the marina as a teenager in 1956, more than 40 fishing boats plied these waters, captains and crews earned a decent living, and both the industry's future and his own seemed secure. But on a recent visit only about 15 fishing boats were operating. Mr. Richford said he hadn't turned a profit in three years and even the last 10 had been a disappointment. ''You can't earn a living anymore,'' he said. ''This year is a total disaster. I'm down 60 percent.''
 Boat captains say several problems, including a slow economy, strict regulations on allowable catches and a serious lack of parking space brought on by the building of condominiums and other developments, are forcing them to relocate or leave the business altogether.
 One boat pilot said he once saw a customer spend nearly two hours searching for a parking spot one morning before giving up. And Robert Sapanara, captain of the 149-passenger Brooklyn, added, ''I've probably left at least a half a dozen people per night on the docks because we can't wait any longer.''
 An upturn of the industry may be possible, but the feeling of sunset at Sheepshead Bay is strong. At 10 a.m. aboard the Pilot that Saturday, the captain announced that a customer feared he was having a heart attack. The elderly man, a 25-year veteran of the boat, sat hunched in a corner of the cabin and complained of chest pains and leg cramps. The Coast Guard escorted the Pilot to Sandy Hook station, so the passenger could get medical attention. ''All of our clientele seem to be getting older,'' said Tom Dzurenko, a deckhand.
 But for the moment at least, people still gather in friendly clusters on the party boats, and social boundaries are easily crossed. 
 ''There's a lot of greeting and hugging and kissing in the mornings,'' said Sheila Madoo, a Trinidadian nurse from Harlem. ''It's like family.'' Ms. Madoo, for example, prepares special spices for Frank Brooks, who sells sausages and sodas on the Pilot on weekends. And the entire boat seems to know that Mr. Brooks's son, Frank, became a pitcher for the Pittsburgh Pirates in August. 
 FISHING next to Ms. Madoo was Michael Rosenberg, a 49-year-old lawyer. ''I met a retired police detective, I met a guy who sells shampoo to beauty salons -- you name it,'' he said of his previous fishing trips. ''People are very generous. Not like in normal society.'' 
 Also nearby was Henry Johnson, now retired from his job as a safety officer at an asylum for the criminally insane on Wards Island, who said he had encountered all types on the boat, including some former patients. ''I was kind of surprised myself,'' he admitted.
 Steve Orlando, a deckhand aboard the Pastime Princess, claims he met both his wives on Sheepshead Bay fishing boats, though he is currently a bachelor. ''You get to know people,'' he said. 
 But friendliness cannot stave off economic reality. ''If things stay the way they are, I don't give it five years,'' said Mr. Richford, the owner of the Pastime Princess. He isn't waiting to see if the industry will survive, however. At the end of the season, he intends to take his boat to Florida to start his business anew. ''If everything goes well,'' he said, ''I should be out of here by November.'' 
 Mr. Sapanara is equally pessimistic, saying he expects to cease operations sometime in the next five years. He inherited the family business from his father but now also works as a deckhand on the Staten Island Ferry to supplement his income. ''There's nothing left to pass on,'' he said. ''I have two sons, but there's nowhere for them to go.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: CAMARADERIE REIGNS -- Clockwise, from left: in the twinkle of daybreak, waiting for the Pilot to set sail
preparing the day's bait
 an impromptu game of poker in the ship's cabin, and a father-and-son moment. (Photographs by Michael Kamber for the New York Times) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

PERSON: Douglas J Gillison; Thomas (Capt) Marconi; George (Capt) Richford

GEOGRAPHIC: NEW YORK, NY, USA (92%) NEW YORK, USA (92%) UNITED STATES (92%) Sheepshead Bay (NYC); New York City

HEADLINE: Wolverines for the Other 364 Days

BYLINE: By BRENDAN I. KOERNER

 BODY:
THIS weekend is the zenith of the costume industry's year, as last-minute shoppers rush to buy wolf masks and witch hats. Come tomorrow, many of those guises will be in the clearance bins, as shop owners and costume manufacturers begin the long countdown to Halloween 2005.
 There is one group of companies, though, for which Oct. 31 is just another day: the makers of corporate- and school-mascot costumes. ''It used to be that summer was the slow time, but sales are pretty steady now,'' said Alan St. George, the president of one such business, Facemakers Inc. in Savanna, Ill. 
 When Mr. St. George founded Facemakers 32 years ago, costumes for mascots -- like Tony the Tiger for Kellogg's Frosted Flakes or the bear of Central Valley High School in Spokane, Wash. -- were scarcely even a cottage industry. ''There was only one other major firm,'' he said. ''All of their things were made of papier mache, which was kind of the old-fashioned way of doing it.'' 
 Facemakers broke from that tradition by using fiberglass, which is lighter and easier to produce from stock molds.
 The company has built a collection of more than 1,000 costume molds, from generics like wildcats to the Cool Llama, which comes with sunglasses and a fedora and costs $1,048. Dozens of animals are offered, often in differing styles. Mr. St. George has discovered that his clients fall into two camps. 
 ''There are those schools that like a ferocious, realistic type, then there are those that want something fun,'' he said. Thus Facemakers has five wolverine costumes, from a cuddly friendly wolverine for $699 to a giant ferocious one for $1,099; adding menacing clawed feet to the mean version will run a school an extra $229.
 Mr. St. George estimates that Facemakers sells more than 1,000 costumes a year, with prices for custom work peaking at around $5,000. Most costumes cost about $800, though a client rarely buys one without requesting at least a few alterations -- for example, lengthening an alligator's snout, or making the friendly wolverine's smile a bit broader. The rule of thumb is that costumes end up costing about twice the list price, after tweaks are made.
 Advertising has always been Facemakers' biggest challenge, given the small pool of people with the money, authority and desire to buy a Pixie Possum get-up for $1,298. In the early years, the company sent direct-mail appeals to high school athletic departments, with limited success. Word of mouth was the only real winning strategy, so Facemakers started sewing its address inside the mascots' heads -- at eye level. ''The person wearing the head is looking right at the address,'' Mr. St. George said. 
 The Internet has revolutionized the industry, letting regional players like Street Characters Inc. of Calgary, Alberta, and Alinco Costumes of Murray, Utah, reach customers across North America. Street Characters, which sells its products through Mascots.com, says it designs costumes under its own 12-step ''mascots ergonomic system,'' which is intended to make the fur more pliable and breathable.
 The competition has spurred Facemakers to offer a line of ''economy costumes,'' made in Mexico and costing as little as $399. The company's staff of 20 has also focused on making costumes more durable, so that schools short on cash needn't buy one more than once or twice a decade. 
 MOST characters, for example, now come with crepe rubber soles on their feet, after Facemakers found that the leather soles on its Smokey Bear costumes were deteriorating too fast.
 Facemakers adds to its revenue stream by offering accessories like stylized paw covers or cooling systems -- Dura-Kold vests and battery-powered exhaust fans inside the costumes. Whether it's Halloween or the Fourth of July, it can get mighty hot tramping around as a giant wolverine.


GRAPHIC: Photo: Facemakers, which makes costumes for corporate or school mascots, can design a wolverine, for example, to look happy or menacing. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
