LENGTH: 2508 words

HEADLINE: Is Kaiser The Future Of American Health Care?

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif. 

 BODY:
AFTER 18 years in private practice, Dr. Victor Silvestre was exhausted from his lonely battle, day after day, with a health care system that seemed to be working against him. A general practitioner, Dr. Silvestre found it increasingly difficult to get his patients appointments with specialists, who tended to focus on lucrative procedures instead of routine care. Paperwork and haggling with insurance companies, he said, took more and more time. ''There just had to be a better way,'' he recalled.
 For Dr. Silvestre, the better way was not across the border in Canada, or in some affluent nearby suburb, but in his own backyard, in Oakland. Two years ago, he joined Kaiser Permanente, the huge health maintenance organization based here. ''So many of the solutions, the ingredients of a more rational system for delivering health care, were there,'' he said.
 It may seem unlikely, given Kaiser's past image as a ham-handed H.M.O., but plenty of others are reaching the same conclusion. High-level visitors from across the political spectrum -- the Bush administration and National Health Service of Britain, for example -- are coming to California these days to look at Kaiser as an institution that is actually doing some of the things needed to improve health care. 
 Obviously, there is no single model for revamping the nation's costly, disjointed health care system, and Kaiser certainly has its share of problems. But according to economists and medical experts, Kaiser is a leader in the drive both to increase the quality of care and to spend health dollars more wisely, using technology and incentives tailored to those goals. ''Quality health care in America will never be cheap, but Kaiser probably does it better than anywhere else,'' said Uwe E. Reinhardt, an economist at Princeton who specializes in health issues.
 HEALTH care systems in most industrialized countries are in crises of one form or another. But the American system is characterized by both feast and famine: it leads the world in delivering high-tech medical miracles but leaves 45 million people uninsured. The United States spends more on health care than any other country -- $6,167 a person a year -- yet it is a laggard among wealthy nations under basic health measures like life expectancy. In a nutshell, America's health care system, according to many experts, is a nonsystem. ''It's like the worst market system you could devise, just a mess,'' said Neelam Sekhri, a health policy specialist at the World Health Organization in Geneva.
 In this political season, the health care debate has been mostly about who will pay the bill. President Bush talks about tax credits and health savings accounts that are intended to give people more control over their care but would also mean that they would pay more out of their own pockets. Senator John Kerry wants the government to pay more, and he has proposed a major, and costly, program to cover the uninsured. 
 The favored solution of many liberals -- and of no small number of health care experts -- is a single-payer system of health insurance, covering the entire population and underwritten by the government. For the foreseeable future, that is considered politically off-limits, which was the message Washington absorbed from the abandoned effort to fashion a national health program in the Clinton administration. 
 How to finance health care is only one side of the problem. The other is how to deliver the care more intelligently, and that is where the Kaiser experience holds lessons. Given the demands of an aging population and steady advances in medical technology, national health spending will continue to climb. Yet by all accounts, there is plenty of waste -- estimates range up to 30 percent or more of total spending -- from unnecessary clinical tests, hospital stays and prescriptions, and the bedeviling sea of paper used to handle bills, claims and patient records. 
 ''We're not going to spend less, but figuring out how to get the most value out of our health spending is going to be the big issue of the future,'' said David Cutler, a health care economist at Harvard.
 But Kaiser as a model? Wasn't Kaiser, an H.M.O., part of the ''managed care'' movement that faltered in the 1990's amid protests from doctors and patients? In fact, Kaiser, with its origins in the 1930's and 1940's, when the industrialist Henry J. Kaiser provided health care for his construction and shipyard workers, has always been a hybrid. The managed care concept of the 1990's was about having an outside bean counter, usually an insurance company, looking over the shoulder of the doctor -- managing costs instead of managing care.
 Kaiser has a different setup with different incentives. It emphasizes preventive care and managing chronic diseases like heart disease and diabetes to keep people healthier. And that saves money because healthier people require less costly care like hospitalization. 
 The country's largest private-sector provider of health care, Kaiser employs more than 11,000 physicians and 135,000 other workers, owns 30 hospitals and hundreds of clinics and serves more than eight million members in nine states and the District of Columbia. Seventy percent are in California. Kaiser is both insurer and provider; employers typically pay fixed yearly fees for each member, no matter how much care is provided. 
 Clearly, Kaiser has its limits as a model for others. It is unlike many mainstream health plans in that it is a not-for-profit company -- though one with annual revenue of more than $25 billion and operating margins of 5 percent. Its facilities tend to be large, and it has a lingering reputation for practicing an impersonal, regimented style of medicine that limits patient choice, despite recent efforts like the creation of physicians' personal Web pages and e-mail communication with patients. 
 Still, most health care experts who have studied Kaiser are impressed. ''Kaiser has a model that consciously manages both quality and costs in a way that has been very effective,'' said Margaret O'Kane, president of the National Committee for Quality Assurance, an independent group that monitors health plans.
 Kaiser's approach is best illustrated in two ways: its management of chronic illnesses like heart disease and diabetes, and its $3 billion initiative to use information technology to improve clinical care and streamline operations. 
 Across the country, health costs are skewed. In any given year, 90 percent of spending provides care for 30 percent of the population, and more than half of total spending goes to 5 percent of the population. Much of it is spent on people with chronic illnesses like heart disease and diabetes. So helping people with those ailments stay as healthy as possible offers much opportunity for cutting costs -- and for improving lives. 
 In Northern California, Kaiser has sharply reduced the death rate for its three million members there in recent years by monitoring and controlling blood pressure and cholesterol levels and by promoting the use of aspirin and beta blockers (to reduce the risk of heart attacks) and statins (to lower cholesterol). The death rate from heart disease among the Kaiser members is 30 percent lower than it is in the rest of the Northern California population, adjusted for age and gender.
 Four months ago, Jose Flores, 44, a postal worker in San Francisco, had double-bypass heart surgery. While still in the hospital, he was enrolled in a program of education and treatment, which is run by nurses and lasts a year. Patients receive instruction on diet, exercise and cholesterol management; smokers are placed in a course to help them quit. 
 Mr. Flores says he is on a drug regimen that includes beta blockers and Lovastatin, a generic cholesterol-lowering statin. He takes large doses of niacin, a vitamin that raises the level of high-density lipoprotein, the ''good'' cholesterol that protects against heart attacks. He walks for an hour, five days a week. His eating habits have been transformed, too: fried foods were once a staple of his diet, but no more. Blacklisted, too, are sour cream, cheese and corn chips. ''Now, I try to avoid all that,'' Mr. Flores said. 
 IN Northern California alone, Kaiser spends $55 million a year on chronic-care management programs. ''But what's really expensive is if we don't take care of these people and manage their chronic conditions,'' said Dr. Robert Mithun, chief of internal medicine at Kaiser's medical center in San Francisco.
 Dr. Mithun's comment may seem like no more than common sense, but it does not reflect the typical logic of the dominant fee-for-service model of health care. Most doctors and hospitals get a fee from insurers for each patient visit, clinical test, surgical procedure or day a patient spends in a hospital. In practice, the fee-for-service system is often an invitation to do more of everything -- more visits, more tests, more surgery. What gets done is what gets paid for, and insurers usually do not pay for preventive care or chronic care management provided by nurses or in group classes, like the ones at Kaiser. 
 In the fee-for-service medical economy, doctors and hospitals routinely strike different deals at different fees with many different insurers. The results are complexity, inefficiency and a constant bureaucratic tug-of-war between health care providers and insurers over claims.
 The Kaiser economy seems a world apart. ''What works at Kaiser is the integration of the financing and delivery of care, and the aligned incentives that allow you to make more rational decisions about health care for members,'' said Ms. Sekhri, the policy expert at the World Health Organization, who has studied Kaiser.
 Ms. Sekhri was a co-author of a 2002 report that compared Kaiser in California with the National Health Service of Britain. The report found that for comparable spending, the Kaiser system in California did a better job of keeping people with chronic conditions out of hospitals. And when Kaiser patients were admitted to hospitals, their stays were generally shorter. Recently, Britain sent groups of primary care physicians and hospital administrators to California to learn from Kaiser.
 The Labor government in Britain may look to Kaiser as an efficient model for its health service, which is run by the government. But the Bush administration is more interested in Kaiser as a model for the efficiencies and integration that can be achieved through information technology.
 In May, the Bush administration appointed Dr. David J. Brailer to the new post of national coordinator of health information technology. His mandate is to prod the nation's health care system into the computer age. Bringing patient records and prescriptions out of the pen-and-ink era promises to save both dollars and lives. The automation of an electronic system could sharply reduce medical errors, which are estimated to be responsible for 45,000 to 98,000 deaths a year, according to the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences. 
 Kaiser has been investing heavily in information technology for years. Its clinical information system includes electronic records with a patient's history, prescriptions and preventive health recommendations. A doctor can call up a patient's X-ray or magnetic resonance image on a desktop personal computer. Electronic prescribing -- a goal in the government plan -- is routine at Kaiser.
 Yet Kaiser is in the midst of a several-year, $3 billion program, called KP HealthConnect, to drastically improve and integrate its clinical and administrative systems and Web-based services for members. Once it is in place, Kaiser clinicians will be able to tap into a vast but flexible storehouse of data that uses intelligent software to automatically flag potentially harmful drug combinations for a patient or to suggest what treatments have been most effective for other people who are of the same sex, age group and -- eventually -- genetic profile.
 DR. BRAILER, for one, checks in regularly on the progress of HealthConnect. George Halvorson, Kaiser's chief executive, said, ''Policy makers are looking to us as the cutting edge of how health care can be supported electronically.''
 Kaiser has had setbacks in the program. Last year, it abandoned I.B.M. as its main partner on the project and chose to go with specialized health care software provided by Epic Systems, a private company in Madison, Wis. Despite the switch, HealthConnect is scheduled to be rolled out during the next couple of years across Kaiser's operations. 
 The conversion of inefficient paperwork to a digital network also opens the door to fostering more efficient markets in health care. Markets rely on information, yet the health care economy is one in which information on patients, treatments and outcomes is trapped on paper and isolated in clinics, hospitals and insurance offices -- instead of being shared, analyzed and compared, while still insuring privacy.
 The fee-for-service model exists because patient visits, clinical tests and surgical procedures can be measured. They are inputs, in economic terms. Whether those inputs are effective is another matter. 
 In recent years, there have been efforts to focus on the quality of health care. The National Committee for Quality Assurance conducts annual reports based on a health plan's use of practices shown to improve patients' health, from timely prenatal care to cholesterol management. Kaiser plans consistently earn excellent ratings in the group's reports, and, this year, it had four of the five top-rated plans in the Pacific region, its stronghold. 
 Dr. Francis J. Crosson, the executive director of the physicians' side of Kaiser, said, ''Our future has to be to compete on quality, offering people demonstrably better care and better value.''
 And the Kaiser system delivers quality while controlling total costs. A recent survey of health care costs in 15 metropolitan areas by Hewitt Associates, the human resources consulting firm, found that the cost for care per employee last year was lowest in the San Francisco area, where Kaiser members were about 35 percent of the insured population, at $5,515, and was highest in regions where Kaiser did not operate -- led by New York, at $6,818 a worker. 
 Quality yardsticks are helpful, but they still measure inputs -- ones associated with better health -- instead of tracking how patients fare. The longer-term goal is for health plans to use technology more, as leading companies in the rest of the economy do. For the health plans, that may mean constantly tracking patients, treatments and results. ''To have a real market for quality in health care, you need a product,'' Mr. Halvorson said. ''And that means reliable, timely information about outcomes, clinical-trial sorts of databases that show things like, for example, 50-year-olds in our system have fewer heart attacks.
 ''With the right informationand the right incentives,'' he added, ''capitalism creates very good solutions.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: Dr. Victor Silvestre, a general practitioner, renounced the headaches of private practice after 18 years and joined Kaiser Permanente two years ago. (Photo by Terrence McCarthy for The New York Times)(pg. 1)
Dr. Francis J. Crosson, executive director of Kaiser's physicians, says the company's future has to be ''offering people demonstrably better care.''
 George Halvorson, the chief executive, is overseeing an effort to create a powerful digital network. (Photographs by Terrence McCarthy for The New York Times)(pg. 4) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ORGANIZATION: Kaiser Permanente

HEADLINE: Can't Read, Can't Write, Can Hide It

BYLINE: By Leslie Kaufman. 
This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com

 BODY:
LITERACY experts say that 20 percent of the population of the United States cannot read or write English proficiently. In New York City alone there are more than one million adults who are so lacking in skills that they cannot fill out application forms or read basic contracts, according to Literacy Partners Inc., a nonprofit group that instructs such people.
 While Literacy Partners says such a handicap keeps many from becoming employed, there are also hundreds of thousands who are underemployed and tens of thousands who are hiding their lack of basic skills from an employer.
 They are people like Vanessa, a 38-year-old from the Bronx who works for a private agency that contracts with the Board of Education to provide therapy for disabled schoolchildren -- her clients are afflicted with illnesses from asthma to bone disease. 
 Vanessa asked to be referred to only by her middle name because she feared that her bosses might find out she cannot read. She has never told them and has amorphous fears about exactly what would happen if she did. ''To tell you the truth I don't honestly know what they'd do,'' she said, ''but for me it is a dark secret and embarrassing. I am not comfortable with it and I will keep it confidential until I am.''
 Susan McLean, executive director of Literacy Partners, said that hiding illiteracy from a boss is common among the students she serves. ''I've been doing this for 20 years and never had a student volunteer to a boss that they were illiterate,'' she said. Her tutors even know not to call students at work, she says, unless explicitly told that they can.
 As a child, Vanessa says, she was found to have a learning disability and placed in special education. Although she completed 12th grade, Vanessa only learned enough in school to bluff her way through situations that demanded reading comprehension. ''They would teach us basic skills to survive,'' she said, ''but no one really worked with us on learning.''
 Still, Vanessa says that since she was 15 she has held jobs from hospital candy striper to payroll office employee to day care worker. For most of her life, when she needed help with a form or a contract she would take it home to her mother or sister, who would decode it for her.
 Her aunt, who knows her condition but also understood her passion and talent for working with special-needs children, helped her get her current job. Vanessa says she loves her work, but admits that even talent has not stopped her from feeling trapped at times.
 ''There will be times when someone asks me to fill out a medical form for a child or to review some papers and I'll have to make excuses,'' she says. When the job needs to be done right away she will tell people that she has to rush a child to therapy or is too busy for some other reason. If the job can wait she brings the paperwork home and has her daughter, age 7, read it to her.
 Her daughter, she says, has no learning disability. ''She is a B student,'' Vanessa said. ''She is good.''
 But it was her daughter who finally made her tackle the problem. ''We were watching TV together and the ad for Literacy Partners came on and I thought, 'I am going finally do this; I am tired of living in the dark,''' Vanessa recalled. ''This has prevented me from making more money and getting better jobs and I thought I can make a better life for my daughter.''
 SO about a year ago, Vanessa joined a group of a dozen people who meet on Monday and Wednesday nights from 5:30 to 8:30 to develop reading skills -- though Vanessa always gets there at 5 o'clock just to be sure.
 ''They teach us to sound out words and to understand what we are reading,'' she said.
 For example, this summer she was out of work for three months and needed to file for unemployment benefits. Her teacher helped her read the form and understand what she was signing.
 Vanessa says she sees improvement, but it is a day-to-day process. She adds that her group is full of other people who are in her situation -- going to work and hiding their secret from their bosses. 
 ''We have conversations about this all the time,'' she said. ''That is why I like going.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: ILLITERACY FEARS -- More than one million adults in New York City lack the skills to read or write English, and experts say many of them keep their problem a secret at work. (Photo illustration by Yoni Brook/The New York Times)

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 1183 words

HEADLINE: Belatedly, Africa Is Converting to Lead-Free Gasoline

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 30 

 BODY:
When Kenyans go to the gas pump, they have several options -- regular, super, premium, diesel and, increasingly, a choice that has many local motorists scratching their heads, unleaded.
 Lead-free gasoline may be the fuel of choice in most of the world but sub-Saharan Africa lags years behind when it comes to converting to cleaner-burning gasoline. On this continent, gas is sold at slick, modern stations and at roadside stands, where vendors use their mouths to help siphon fuel from plastic jugs. Many motorists mistakenly regard unleaded gas as suitable only for the latest model cars. 
 ''I don't use it,'' said Avtar Singh, who pulled his 1990 Nissan into a Nairobi gas station the other day. ''I'd have problems with my engine with the unleaded.''
 Ninety percent of the gas used worldwide is lead free, specialists say, with the use of leaded fuel concentrated in developing countries. But now, prompted by the United Nations, the United States Environmental Protection Agency and others, a movement is sweeping through Africa to phase out leaded gasoline. Concerned about the damage to people's health caused by lead, many countries from Senegal to South Africa have set a target date of 2005 for phasing out leaded gas.
 In the United States, the Clean Air Act, passed in 1970, began the gradual removal of lead from gasoline. It was finally outlawed in 1995, reducing lead levels in the air by an estimated 98 percent.
 In 2000, Sudan became the first country in sub-Saharan Africa to switch to unleaded gas, a decision based as much on economic concerns as on environmental concerns. Sudan had built a refinery, north of Khartoum, which provides gasoline for domestic consumption and an export market that demands unleaded.
 Switching to unleaded alone does not bring clean air, to which anyone who has spent time in Sudan's congested capital can attest. Decades-old taxis with fumes seeping into their interiors compete with belching buses on the streets. 
 Still, the reduction of lead levels has been shown to save lives. A conference on leaded gasoline that the United Nations Environment Program held in Dakar, Senegal, in June 2001 prompted many other African countries to follow Sudan.
 Conference delegates expressed alarm at data showing that lead reduces the brain function of children and increases the risk of heart attacks and strokes in adults. Governments have begun teaching motorists about the risks. 
 ''When inhaled, lead causes very serious health problems,'' Ratemo W. Michieka, director of Kenya's National Environmental Management Authority, said in a recent notice published in local newspapers.
 One of the few studies of the health effects of lead in Africa, conducted in Egypt in 1995 and updated since, found that the I.Q. of children was lowered by slightly more than four points as a result of lead, and adults exposed to lead had significantly higher levels of strokes, heart attacks and other ailments. Egypt switched to unleaded gas in 1999.
 The poor suffer most from leaded gas, health specialists say. They are most likely to live, work and walk on busy, polluted highways. A recent survey in Kenya found the highest lead levels in urban areas, but elevated levels were also detected countrywide in corn, water and milk.
 African governments now say that unleaded gas will soon be the fuel of choice. South Africa, the continent's economic powerhouse, has said it will no longer use leaded fuel by 2006 affecting smaller countries nearby.
 Similarly, in West Africa, many smaller countries say they will change when larger neighbors do so. Cameroon, which exports to Central African Republic, Chad and Equatorial Guinea, says it will stop distributing leaded gas in November 2005. 
 Environmental activists, while thrilled with these moves, consider the change a first step in cleaning Africa's air. Countries must also begin replacing jalopies with newer cars with more efficient engines. Then there is the question of sulfur, an additive in diesel fuel that causes widespread damage to health. In switching to unleaded gasoline, African countries face a variety of challenges, and those that refine their own fuel face the greatest difficulty.
 In Ethiopia, where the government controls fuel imports, the conversion was swift. Government officials stopped importing leaded gasoline in January 2004 and replaced it with unleaded fuel with little public participation, or even knowledge. 
 But countries like Kenya face a more complicated task. With both fuels now available, government officials must first battle the widespread belief among motorists that leaded gas is required for older cars. 
 Oil companies began adding lead to gas in the 1920's as a cost-effective way to increase fuel octane and thus control engine knock. But specialists commissioned by the United Nations say that even older cars without catalytic converters, the bulk of the vehicles on African roads, can run on unleaded fuel.
 ''Leaded gasoline is the worst fuel one could imagine for any engine, including those designed for leaded gasoline,'' said one of the specialists, John J. Mooney, an inventor of the catalytic converter.
 In one effort to change public opinion, Jane Akumu, a United Nations program officer, has been holding seminars for gas station attendants throughout Kenya to teach them about the health hazards of leaded gas. By the end of the sessions, she said, most vow to encourage their customers to use a safer fuel.
 Stations in Kenya typically charge the same price for unleaded gasoline as for leaded, unlike those in some other countries. Specialists also say that the unleaded variety can eventually save money for consumers by reducing damage to exhaust valves, exhaust pipes and spark plugs.
 However, the switch has financial ramifications for the government. Most of the gasoline available in the country is processed on the coast in Mombasa at a refinery that is jointly owned by the government and by Caltex Oil Corporation, Kenya Shell and British Petroleum. Built in the 1960's, it is not equipped to handle unleaded fuel.
 A recent change in regulations requires that all imported gasoline, about 30 percent of the total, be unleaded. But what to do with the refinery, which also provides 144 jobs and another 1,500 related to its operation, remains a difficult issue.
 An outside consultant has estimated that it will cost more than $161 million to alter the Mombasa refinery to process unleaded fuel. Another option, at $88 million, would turn the refinery into a storage facility for imported fuel. A third option would be to close it.
 While the owners ponder the tough choices, Kenyan officials say they are committed to phasing out leaded gasoline by the end of 2005. 
 At Parklands Service Station, one of Nairobi's busiest, Ramesh C. Bhalla is not so sure. He offers only leaded and diesel fuel and is in no rush to offer unleaded. Only a tiny percentage of people who pull up to his pumps ask for lead-free gas.
 ''Our customers have always used leaded petrol and are still learning about this unleaded,'' Mr. Bhalla said. ''It's a new thing for us.''

Lead has been shown to reduce brain function in children, putting students in Nairobi, Kenya, above, at risk. (Photographs by Guillaume Bonn for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 1449 words

HEADLINE: Swing Time

BYLINE: By Walter Kirn

 BODY:

VILLAGES
By John Updike.
321 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $25.
 SEX scenes in fiction are a problem. Whether they're rendered crudely and directly, through graphic close-ups and blunt four-letter words, or delivered elegantly and obliquely, through misty impressions and lofty euphemisms, most displays of literary lovemaking tend to make the reader's flesh crawl. They feel like overcooked pornography, undercooked lyric poetry or -- worst of all -- some odd, jarring combination of the two. Only the juvenile and the information-starved actively seek out such passages; the mature and the experienced regard them as unavoidable ordeals.
 Though the young John Updike must have known all this (he seemed to know everything about his medium, almost from the start) he nevertheless resolved about four decades ago to make the big, detailed, extended sex scene a hallmark of his art. In ''Rabbit, Run,'' ''Couples'' and other novels and story collections from the 1960's and 70's, the supernaturally fluent chronicler of somewhat-moneyed North-eastern domesticity perfected a new, arresting approach to what bookish sophomores call ''the good parts,'' gaining for himself a reputation as possibly America's most eloquent and most gynecologically thorough dirty mind. In early and middle Updike, every set of human genitals had its own distinctive physicality, often presented with clinical precision, as well as a soulful individuality. What Henry James did with clothing and furniture -- turned them into characters -- Updike did with the reproductive organs and with their behavior when aroused.
 ''Villages,'' Updike's 21st novel, recaptures and concentrates the erotic essence of the earlier books but adds a mellow, retrospective tone. It's a remembrance of copulations past, and of the Edenic post-pill, pre-AIDS moment that made the more casual of those hook-ups possible. In its period, settings and cast of characters, the story also overlaps consistently with Updike's own biography, tempting one to read it as a confession. In the end, the book gratifies in every way -- as an exhibition of educated prurience, an elegy for an era and an inquiry into the morals of a striving upper-middle-class white male.+
 His name is Owen Mackenzie, though he might as well be called ''Anonymous.'' Between his small-town Pennsylvania youth, his heady college years at M.I.T. and his affluent Connecticut middle age, Owen comes off as a heraldic figure, a broad generational composite, whose hypothetical coat of arms might feature a set of golf clubs, a leather-bound appointment calendar and a station wagon. The man in the gray flannel suit? Not quite, but close. He's individual enough to win our animal sympathies and representative enough to stimulate our intellects. Owen's story might not be yours, but Updike suggests that it's a lot of people's, including, maybe, his own.
 The novel's tidy, full-circle timetable begins with a typical day in Owen's life, then doubles back to show the life itself. At 70, as he wakes up in the bedroom that he shares with his early-rising second wife, Julia, Owen is financially secure, emotionally stable, physically normal and spiritually average. Though he's on his way out of this world, he's going slowly, consoled by a poetic appreciation for the great, stately cycles of the cosmos. Of birds, he's capable of thinking this (in concert with Updike, his authorial shadow, who sometimes speaks through him and sometimes for him): ''We are mere dots beneath their wings, our cities foul and barren interruptions in the discourse of predator and prey.'' A handsome home, a loving wife and a broad perspective worthy of Thoreau -- the retired computer software engineer lacks for nothing except time.
 The account of how Owen spent the time he once had proceeds in the usual Updike manner: straight ahead, from A to B, without gimmicky chronological distortions but with frequent intermissions for reverie and meditation. Though Updike has dabbled in experimental fiction in much the same way that his frisky New England husbands dabble in adultery, he's at heart a solid artistic conformist who succeeds by embracing conventions, not spurning them, and embracing them so avidly and strenuously that they yield surprising new juice. Time is a river -- he accepts the truism. But he also sees that this river is full of whirlpools where emotion and awareness spin in place, creating little images of eternity.
 In ''Villages,'' it's sexual energy that whirls these vortexes. On the playground equipment shed of his elementary school, the young Owen finds a crude, archetypal piece of graffiti that permanently affects his vision of the female body: ''Close by, an older, more knowing hand had incised in a pencil that gouged its lines deep into the yellow-painted wood what looked like a swollen letter M but, on examination, was a naked woman, legs bent at the knee and spread to reveal between them a slit, a pumpkin-seed shape, curls of hair around and above it, and below it a dot that Owen could not name even to himself, in the silence of his head, it was so shameful.'' Truly definitive descriptions of familiar human artifacts are profoundly rare in fiction, but certainly this is one of them.
 For everyboy Owen to leave his sheltered small town and crash the great cocktail party of the world, Updike must do his authorial duty and assign him a plausible, suitable career. As long as it pays enough to situate Owen in the neighborhood where Updike wants him to live, and as long as it suits Owen's pre-established temperament (practical-minded, a little shy), any of dozens of occupations might do. Writers are control freaks, though, and they don't like to settle such open matters with coin flips, although it might be better if they did, since the overly thought-out choices they finally do make usually feel slightly rigged. They remind us -- sometimes joltingly -- whom the protagonist really works for, and it's not the reader or himself.
 Updike forces Owen to write software chiefly because the rise of the computer industry traces much the same historical arc as the sexual revolution. The early, postwar machines were slow and awkward, as were the early, postwar swingers, but by the 70's both were fast and smooth. Having done himself this convenience, Updike seeks to portray it as somehow essential and profound by filling in the inevitable gaps between Owen's libidinous adventures with plenty of well-researched, brainy talk about binary logic, printed circuits and so on. Reading these sections, one senses -- quite correctly -- that it's unnecessary to read them.
 Not so for the good parts, which are brave and excellent, even when they're vaguely nauseating. Because Updike seldom blinks when viewing human nakedness (or lets his couples turn off the bedroom lights) his sex scenes are an acquired taste, just as sex itself is, he reminds us. Owen's transformation from a sensitive schoolboy who's sickened and transfixed by filthy pencil drawings into a prowling middle-aged libertine who has sex with a young employee during office hours does not proceed seamlessly. It moves by fits and starts, through pangs of revulsion and flashes of revelation. As he consummates his first illicit liaison, Owen notes, in classic Updike fashion, the difference between his lover's vaginal textures and his wife's. The lover's organ is ''smoother, somehow simpler, its wetness less thick, less of a sauce, more of a glaze.''
 Such erotic gourmandism feels dated now, but it accurately reflects the mind-set of Owen and his peers, who made Playboy magazine an institution and books such as ''The Sensuous Man'' best sellers. In those days and for those men, sex was a sort of winery tour. A new lover was rolled around inside the goblet first, then sniffed and tasted, sipped and savored. The process was all very conscious and humane and behind it lay a philosophy of pleasure that Updike, near the end of ''Villages,'' touchingly resurrects for those of us who recall its existence but are foggy on its particulars. Call it the Hefner Creed. ''The unfaithful man and woman meet for a plain purpose, dangerous and scandalous, with the blood pressure up and the pupils enlarged and the love-flush already reddening the skin: is there not a praiseworthy economy in this, as opposed to sex spread thin through the interminable mutual exposure of a marriage?''
 The era that spawned such thinking has passed, but some of the rascals who were present at its dawn -- including Updike's Owen and Owen's Updike -- are still alive and possessed of functioning memories. ''Villages'' reads like their collective farewell. Good night, you precious darlings, we have to go.

PERSON: Walter Kirn; John Updike

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 31, 2004
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 14LI; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 673 words

HEADLINE: No Pay as You Go

 BODY:
The bottom line on mass transit anywhere is that the masses cannot really pay for it. Government subsidies are necessary to keep buses, trains and subways running -- and it's more than worth it, considering the congestion, air pollution and disruptions to the economy that would come if cars became the only method of getting around.
 All that is especially true in the metropolitan New York area. Riders foot more of the costs here than almost anywhere else in the nation. But if the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is required to pay too much of its own way, commuting by rail or express bus will become too expensive for many riders. Drivers will suffer as well, as the competition for parking and highway space increases and the authority raises its bridge tolls through the roof. 
 Washington, Albany, City Hall and the suburbs will have to pay a fairer share of the costs of getting eight million people to work and back. The authority has been sounding warnings about a $436 million deficit next year, and alerting commuters to service cutbacks and fare increases. That deficit could eventually grow to $1 billion or, according to State Comptroller Alan Hevesi, maybe $2 billion.
 The reason for this deep hole is not hard to figure out. Over the last 25 years, the authority has borrowed lots of money to make the subways and trains cleaner and more efficient -- including, most disturbingly, a monster 2000 bond issue to help finance a $17 billion capital maintenance and expansion program. That New Yorkers now enjoy better mass transit is good for everybody. But the authority borrowed more than it could pay back on its own, and the bill is coming due.
 Officials at the authority are already planning to make sure suburban commuters and city straphangers pay their share -- or more -- of the additional costs. Commuter rail ticket prices could go up by about 5 percent, and so could the prices for E-ZPasses, the tolls on bridges and the costs of daily and monthly MetroCards. At the same time, the authority's leadership is talking about cutting or not replacing thousands of workers, mostly on subway and bus lines, including over 350 employees working on the Long Island Rail Road and almost 200 working for Metro-North. 
 So far, however, there have been few helpful offers from President Bush, Gov. George Pataki, Mayor Michael Bloomberg or the State Legislature. That's unacceptable, given the of mass transit to the state and regional economy. 
 For starters, the city must increase its contribution to the authority. Mayor David Dinkins, facing financial problems, began cutting the city's contribution, and Rudolph Giuliani and Mr. Bloomberg followed suit. Today's city contribution is one-third of what it was 20 years ago. The suburbs should chip in more for maintenance and other improvements, as should the federal government, not least because of the additional burden the system must bear as a prime terrorist target. Washington requires the authority to have bomb-sniffing dogs , shoulder bigger liability insurance premiums and take other measures. The estimated cost is $500 million, and Washington should pay it.
 Then there's the state. Republicans tend to resist offering more money; Democrats tend to resist making the system more efficient. The parties should switch roles. The Legislature, including suburban lawmakers who oppose consolidating rail lines, must help the authority restructure itself and streamline commuter bus lines. 
 Then there's Mr. Pataki. The governor's appointees, who essentially control the authority, have been willing to let the state off the hook. Mr. Pataki likes to be there when there is good news, like a long stretch without fare increases. Now he is arguing that a fare increase should not be necessary -- without, however, taking steps to solve the problems. That won't work. Unless the state provides more help with mass transit's growing debt, any fare increase will land on the governor's watch. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Editorial

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: URBAN TRANSIT SYSTEMS (92%); PUBLIC FINANCE (90%); PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION (90%); URBAN BUS SYSTEMS (90%); TRAINS (90%); MOTORCOACHES & BUSES (89%); CITIES (89%); URBAN RAIL SYSTEMS (89%); SUBURBS (89%); CITY GOVERNMENT (89%); US STATE GOVERNMENT (88%); US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2008 (84%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (78%); GOVERNMENT GRANTS & SUBSIDIES (78%); CITY LIFE (78%); PRICE INCREASES (74%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (73%); TRAVEL TICKETS (73%); BOND ISSUES (64%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (59%); AIR POLLUTION (57%); BONDS (50%) Transit Systems; Finances; Editorials; Railroads; Subways; Buses

ORGANIZATION: Metropolitan Transportation Authority

PERSON: GEORGE W BUSH (58%); RUDY GIULIANI (56%); MICHAEL BLOOMBERG (56%)

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 31, 2004
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 3; Column 1; SundayBusiness; AT LUNCH WITH -- RICHARD KARLGAARD; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 1295 words

HEADLINE: Yes, You Can Follow Your Bliss to Anytown, U.S.A.

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
EVERYONE knows the downside of living in or near big cities: sky-high mortgages, nightmare commutes, endless bustle, nonstop work. But tunnel vision? Isn't that the purview of laid-back small towns?
 No. At least not in Richard Karlgaard's view. The way he sees it, the denizens of Silicon Valley (he is one of them), or of Manhattan (ouch! -- the only place this reporter has ever lived) or of other high-energy, success-oriented places are so busy listening to one another that they often miss the point.
 How else to explain why Mr. Karlgaard, a former trade magazine editor who is now publisher of Forbes magazine and writes its ''Digital Rules'' column, was caught short when the Internet bubble burst? How else to explain why he wrote what he now calls ''gush'' about Global Crossing to the very end? 
 ''I lived among people who were all drinking the same Kool-Aid,'' he said. 
 The humbling self-knowledge didn't make him move to the heartland. But it did make him think. How many people, he wondered, would do better, and be happier, if they lived in smaller, quieter places? 
 For Mr. Karlgaard, 50, the question was not rhetorical. By vocation, he is a seeker of proof. By avocation, he is a newly trained pilot with a newcomer's zeal for the air.
 So, over the summers of 2002 and 2003, he took to the sky in a single-engine plane and visited scores of relocated urbanites to ask how they liked their new homes. 
 He discovered that, yes, the lower cost of living was a joy. But the psychic pluses and minuses were eye-opening, too.
 He lays it all out in ''Life 2.0: How People Across America Are Transforming Their Lives by Finding the Where of Their Happiness'' (Crown Business, July 2004). And during a recent lunch at a Forbes-owned town house in Greenwich Village, Mr. Karlgaard -- his oh-so-New York black garb seemingly clashing with his insistence that he's ''more at home in Albuquerque than at the St. Regis'' -- elaborated on why even the most devoted urbanite could live happily elsewhere. 
 Do you thrive on theaters, museums and four-star restaurants? Air fares are low enough to make frequent trips back to the big city possible. Do you work for a big ad agency or newspaper? The Internet lets you do that from anywhere. Do you crave the aura of Fifth Avenue or Rodeo Drive and the intellectual stimulation of urban centers? Small towns are actually pretty with-it these days. 
 ''The Internet, multiplexes, 24-hour fitness centers, high-tech clothing that guards against cold -- all of them have made it a lot less stultifying to live in hick towns,'' he said. 
 Mr. Karlgaard is not from a big city. He was born in Bismarck, N.D. His mom stayed home with four children. His father was a high school physical education teacher who later became athletic director for all of Bismarck's public schools.
 Throughout high school, and even as he studied political science at Stanford, Mr. Karlgaard's main passion was track and field. His first job was as an editorial assistant at Runner's World magazine, and he wrote a book called ''The Last Word on Running.'' It came out soon after ''The Complete Book of Running,'' Jim Fixx's best seller. As a result, Mr. Karlgaard said, ''we sold maybe 1,500 copies'' even though the book received good reviews. 
 Chastened, Mr. Karlgaard drifted for a time, taking jobs as a security guard and as a dishwasher. He finally realized, after reading H.L. Mencken, Saul Bellow and others, that he, too, wanted to ''do lively things with the English language.''
 He took various technical writing and advertising jobs and eventually started his own business writing and producing brochures. 
 Along the way he married Marji Unsoeld, whom he met on a blind date. They have two children and live in a big house in Los Altos, Calif., five miles from Palo Alto.
 The brochure business was lucrative but not satisfying. So in 1985 he and Anthony B. Perkins, a friend and banker, founded the Churchill Club, a commercial forum to discuss political ideas. Three years later they started Upside, a technology magazine. It was long on information and satirical caricatures of industry honchos, but short on profit. They sold it in 1992; Mr. Perkins went on to found the magazine Red Herring, and Forbes chose Mr. Karlgaard to found and edit Forbes ASAP, a supplement chronicling the disruptive impact of technology. 
 Six years later, when the publisher of Forbes quit, Steve Forbes, the editor in chief, offered the job to him. He took it -- with the proviso that he could stay in California and write a column on technology and that other Forbes executives would do most of the financial heavy lifting.
 ''I'm more of an editor at large, really,'' he said. 
 These days, he is more of a chronicler of the mobile society. He is full of advice for people who contemplate leaving the urban rat race. Herewith, some tips gleaned during lunch:
 Realize that pulling your children out of fancy urban schools will help, not hurt, their college chances. ''It's easier to get into Harvard from a Sioux Falls public school than from a New York private school,'' Mr. Karlgaard said. To explain, he quotes a friend, the dean of admissions at an Ivy League college: ''The applications from kids who have 'traveled extensively,' who have Stanley Kaplan-enhanced SAT's, they all look the same. The kid who was on the rodeo team stands out -- and can add diversity to the student body.''
 Review your track record for impulsive decisions. If you've done well by following your gut, then move if your instincts point that way. If you've regretted acting on impulse, he said, ''think 10 times'' and test your financial assumptions with a calculator and legal pad. ''It's a good way to add rationality to the process,'' he said. 
 Be honest with yourself about your career. If you are a rising star at a Wall Street firm, you still need the face time. But telecommuting can work if your career has peaked. ''To move successfully, you must feel you have nothing to lose,'' Mr. Karlgaard said.
 Recognize that some careers are better pursued in smaller places. A physicist who wants to lead a weapons development program may belong in Washington, but one who really wants to figure out cold fusion may do better at Cornell. And it is often easier to shine in smaller towns. ''My dad would never have become the athletic director for the New York City school system,'' Mr. Karlgaard said. 
 Focus on what you are running to, not from. Questionnaires on Web sites likefindyourspot.com can help you determine how much stock you put in an area's climate, public schools, museums or prevalent religions -- and can point you toward places most likely to make you happy. And don't fall prey to outmoded stereotypes: yes, there are thriving Jewish communities in Texas. 
 Be realistic about what you are leaving behind. Do you really go to the theater or the shore more than three times a year? How often do you really see your best friends? ''If you no longer are carrying the mortgage on a million-dollar apartment, you can afford to go to the city or the beach whenever you want,'' Mr. Karlgaard said.
 Don't think that moving will make a bad life idyllic. Granted, it is easier to deal with problems if your bills are modest and you are not trying to cram a family of five into 950 square feet. But an incompatible marriage in Metropolis will still be incompatible in Anytown. And weigh the psychic cost of not moving. ''If you think your problems could be solved by moving, even if they can't, you'll never forgive yourself for not trying,'' he said. 
 Test drive the move. Take a vacation to the spot you're considering. If you likeit, rent out your urban home and rent a place in the new location. ''If it turns out you're miserable,'' he said, ''you can always return.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: The Internet has made it easier for many people to leave big cities for the quiet of small towns, says Richard Karlgaard, the publisher of Forbes magazine. (Photo by Richard Perry/The New York Times)

LENGTH: 437 words

HEADLINE: For Economy, Jobs May Be Tie Breaker

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
THE presidential election -- and whether it will be decided by Wednesday -- is this week's market focus.
 But the jobs report due on Friday -- as well as some other data coming out this week -- will help determine whether the economy has the legs its needs to keep running at an annual growth rate of 3.5 percent to 4 percent.
 While recent economic data has been generally positive, there have been some unexpected signs of weakness. 
 The Commerce Department said Friday that the economy grew at a 3.7 percent annual rate in the third quarter, slower than the 4.3 percent consensus forecast gathered by Bloomberg News. The University of Michigan index of consumer confidence for October fell, but much less than expected, and the Chicago Purchasing Managers Index last month jumped to its highest level since 1988. 
 Industrial production came in at a weaker-than-expected 0.1 percent in September. The forecast was for growth of 0.3 percent. But September retail sales rose a robust 1.5 percent, twice Wall Street's expectation. 
 Orders for durable goods, which include cars, appliances and airplanes, were up 0.2 percent in September, less than half the forecast. But without transportation, orders surged by 1.7 percent in September, almost six times the forecast of 0.3 percent growth. 
 David J. Greenlaw, chief United States fixed-income economist at Morgan Stanley, said, ''The economy is still on a pretty solid growth projection.''
 But he added that ''the signals of late have been a little mixed, reflecting the impact of high oil prices and, perhaps, some election uncertainty.''
 ''The key to sustaining strong economic growth is going to be job growth,'' he said, ''and that is why the jobs report this week is so important.''
 Wall Street analysts are predicting that 175,000 new nonfarm jobs were created in October. That is above both the 170,222 monthly average for this year and the monthly average of 136,769 since job growth resumed in September 2003.
 If the jobs forecast is on the mark, which it rarely is, there will still have been a net loss of 646,000 nonfarm jobs since January 2001, the month when President Bush took office.
 Without government jobs, that net loss would be 1.6 million through September.

MANUFACTURING GAUGE -- Another important indicator will come in tomorrow's report from the Institute of Supply Management, which measures the health of the manufacturing sector. That gauge is expected to be at 58 in October, down slightly from 58.5 in September. A reading of 50 or more means that the manufacturing sector is growing. The index has slipped from a two-decade high of 63.6 in January.


GRAPHIC: Graph tracks change in nonfarm payrolls for 2003 and 2004. (portion of 2004 is estimated.)

SECTION: Section 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk; The Neediest Cases; Pg. 36

LENGTH: 3496 words

HEADLINE: The Hope of Charity, Reflected in 3 Working Families Who Found Help

BYLINE: By KARI HASKELL

 BODY:
Around the corner from a multimillion-dollar housing construction site at 105th Street and Central Park West, a couple in a subsidized apartment care for an ailing son. They are worried about how to pay an escalating electric bill. If their service is suspended, the machine pumping nutrient-rich milk into their son's stomach will stop.
 In Brooklyn, a woman takes custody of her teenage brother, adding to personal strains that include her grandmother's death, a divorce, and the difficulty of raising her daughter alone. 
 And in Yonkers, another single mother is trying to rebuild her life and provide shelter for her six children after a fire destroyed their home. 
 For these people, and many others among the working poor, every day is a struggle. They work hard in jobs that are the backbone of New York City -- building superintendents, police dispatchers, health aides, service industry employees. But for all their toil, their resources are all but exhausted by family needs, rent, and mounting bills. They can't seem to get by, let alone get ahead. 
 According to recent reports, the hardships of the working poor persist despite signs of economic recovery. The statistics, from the Community Service Society, a New York agency that assists low-income families, say that one-fifth of residents live below the poverty line, defined by the federal government as an income of $18,392 for a family of four. Of those residents, two-thirds are members of working families, whose wages are too low to pay for basic needs like housing and food.
 The problem is echoed on a national scale, according to a recent study by the Working Poor Families Project, a nonprofit group that assists low-income families. The group found that more than 9.2 million working families were low-income, with 2.5 million of those officially in poverty. 
 For the working poor -- many of whom are trying to survive without safety nets like savings, job security or health insurance -- even a little help can make a huge difference.
 For more than nine decades, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has been providing that help to thousands of New Yorkers.
 Today, the Neediest Cases begins its 93rd annual fund-raising campaign, which will run through Jan. 31. The fund has been aiding and comforting New York's homeless, gravely ill and poverty-stricken since 1912. They draw hope and strength from the fund, through the services of seven New York charities that are its beneficiaries.
 ''From our partnerships with the seven Neediest Cases agencies, we know how skilled they are in helping people who are hungry, hurt, confused or in turmoil beyond their control,'' said Jack Rosenthal, president of The New York Times Company Foundation. The foundation underwrites all the administrative costs, so all donations go directly to those in need. 
 Those contributions cover an array of services: life-saving medicine and medical equipment, utilities, rents, even hot meals. The elderly can find companionship and purpose through volunteer programs financed with Neediest Cases money. The young can find the resources they need to help them excel at school and enter the work force.
 The working poor are among those who benefit the most from the Neediest Cases. At present, workers in New York from the ages of 18 to 64 who are below the poverty level average $6.77 an hour, according to the Economic Policy Institute. In comparison, in 2003 the average wage per hour in New York City was $19.03. 
 At such a level, even working extra hours or a second job is unlikely to make a meaningful difference. The Neediest Cases tries to fill the gap.
 ''The New York Times Neediest Cases is both window and mirror for its readers,'' said John Ruskay, executive vice president and chief executive of UJA-Federation of New York, one of the seven charities supported by the fund. ''It is a window into another New York, one that is far away, even if it so close. It is a mirror that provokes all of us who read it to look at our own lives and see what kind of responsibility we have to help our neighbors.''

In the Beginning
 The Neediest Cases tradition began almost a century ago, on a frigid Christmas Day in 1911, when, according to accounts, the New York Times publisher, Adolph S. Ochs, encountered a shabbily dressed beggar.
 Stirred by the homeless man's plight, Mr. Ochs established the Neediest Cases, and the newspaper first sought contributions in 1912. In the beginning, The Times printed 100 short profiles of the city's most disadvantaged people. Today, daily articles tell the stories of New Yorkers who are at their lowest point, but finding help and hope through the Neediest Cases.
 Contributions range from just a few dollars to $1 million from organizations like the Starr Foundation. Since its inception, the fund has raised close to $207 million for New Yorkers in crisis and despair, including those affected by the terrorist attack of Sept. 11, 2001. 
 Over the last three years, the Neediest Cases raised nearly $27 million. (The Neediest Cases invests contributions from trusts and estates of more than $50,000 in an endowment. The income, recently more than $1 million a year, goes into the next year's campaign.)
 The 2003-2004 campaign, which raised $8.3 million, was the third most successful in the fund's history. An unsteady economy translated into fewer donors than in the previous year, though donors on average gave more generously, according to Mr. Rosenthal. A new survey by Community Service Society, one of the fund's seven beneficiary charities, paints another challenging picture for this year's campaign. 
 The society surveyed 1,300 New York City residents, including 1,000 low-income and 300 upper-income New Yorkers. Among the findings: 9 out of 10 lower-income residents say that their family finances have not improved over last year; 36 percent say they are worse off. The biggest problem facing New Yorkers, both groups of respondents say, is finding and keeping a job. 
 For Ana and Manuel Acevedo, the worries run even deeper.

A Rare Disease
 In their apartment on West 104th Street in Manhattan, the sound of coughing echoes down the stark hallway. The sound rouses Ana, 47, her husband, Manuel, 52, and their 13-year-old daughter, Stephanie. They nearly collide rushing to the bedroom to assist the Acevedos' son, Jose, 21. 
 Although he lies at a 45-degree angle to keep saliva from his lungs, it often pools in his throat. The first person through the door grabs the suction tube and gently puts it inside his mouth.
 His throat cleared, Jose rests on his pillow. His family relaxes, for an all-too-brief moment. 
 Depending on the day, Mr. Acevedo and Stephanie will go back to their rooms, but Ms. Acevedo will remain and sleep on a futon. She is careful not to disturb a feeding machine pumping nutrient-rich milk through a tube to her son's stomach.
 Jose suffers from an obscure degenerative disease resembling adrenoleukodystrophy, a rare deterioration of the fatty myelin sheath around the nerve fibers in his brain.
 To the Acevedos, it seems not so long ago that Jose ran and played with other children. 
 ''He was completely healthy,'' his mother said as she opened a photo album chronicling her son's transition from active boy to severely disabled adult.
 ''It started at 3 with urinary incontinence,'' she said. Then his speech and balance began to falter. At the time, the family lived in the Dominican Republic.
 There, the medical tests were inconclusive. The doctors advised the Acevedos to seek help in the United States; to do so, they gave up careers as engineers.
 Settling in New York City, they confronted new obstacles -- a language barrier, diminishing savings and a search for work. Mr. Acevedo was hired by a construction company in Albany, while his wife stayed in the city to navigate a complex medical system. 
 For Jose there were more tests, but few answers. ''Even 15 years later they don't know what he has,'' his mother said.
 Jose's abilities degenerated. He can no longer walk or speak. 
 ''It became too much to take,'' Mrs. Acevedo said of managing her troubled family with her husband so far away. 
 He returned to New York City, where he took a series of menial jobs before finding the superintendent's position he has held for the past 10 years, earning $300 a week.
 His employer provides their apartment, but their resources are meager. Medical bills and a medical attendant are paid by Medicaid. But there is much Medicaid does not cover. They spend $2,000 a year for diapers alone. 
 After 9/11 their situation became more complicated when Mrs. Acevedo lost her $25,000-a-year administrative position. In the last three years, Jose has had four bouts of pneumonia, keeping him out of special education classes at Public School 79. He stopped taking food by mouth in the last year to reduce the probability of more pneumonia. Recently he spent a month in the hospital recovering from a back operation to straighten a progressive curvature of his spine related to his illness. 
 Besides the feeding machine, Jose relies on several other devices. He lies on a warm electric pad to improve his circulation. He can't regulate his body temperature, so an air conditioner and heater cool and warm his room as needed.
 The various machines have increased the family's utility bill drastically. Consolidated Edison worked out a payment plan. But the family still could not keep up, and in July they owed $2,528.79. 
 ''We had no way to pay,'' said Mrs. Acevedo. ''There was nothing left to sell.'' She had sold her jewelry, including her wedding ring, long ago.
 But she found help on July 26, 2004, when her St. Mary's Hospital caseworker contacted the office of Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, in St. Cecilia's Parish. The archdiocese is another of the seven agencies supported by the Neediest Cases.
 ''When I heard her case, and the situation with the son, we knew it was an emergency,'' said Arlex Cardona, a case manager at St. Cecilia's Parish Services. Mr. Cardona drew on the Neediest Cases to pay the Con Edison bill. 
 ''It feels good to trust in humanity,'' said Mrs. Acevedo ''It is so surprising, when you have nothing and you are helped by other people.''
 Recently the family encountered another setback. Mr. Acevedo lost his job after an elderly resident's complaint. They will be allowed to stay in their subsidized apartment -- if they find work. "If you asked me if I change something, I would say no,'' said Ms. Acevedo, clutching the photo album. 
 ''I would do the same,'' she continued. ''Until the day we can't offer him the proper care, we will do everything we can for him.'' Her eyes welled. ''He knows how much we love him; he is happy.''

Poor and Single
 The Acevedos, married 25 years, have found strength in each other -- but many of the working poor are singles who do not have the same sort of family support in a crisis. 
 Single mothers head 24 percent of the families in New York City, compared with 14.8 percent in the rest of the nation, according to the Community Social Service survey.
 Nicole Patrick, 33, lives in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, and works from 3 p.m. to 11 p.m. Thursday through Monday as a police dispatcher. She earns about $14 an hour. 
 Two years ago, she had to make a life-altering decision.
 Her grandmother, Evelyn Randle, a powerful surrogate mother to Ms. Patrick, was dying of cancer at age 83. The situation was especially dire because Ms. Randle was the foster mother of Ms. Patrick's teenage half brother, Jason Washington. 
 Ms. Patrick barely knew Jason, who is now 15, but knew his hardships all too well. Before her grandmother was granted custody, he was in foster care because of their mother's drug dependency. 
 ''She spoke with me about taking him in, but my marriage was rocky at the time. We were divorcing,'' Ms. Patrick said. 
 Despite her personal strain and the responsibilities of caring for a daughter, Felicia, now 7, Ms. Patrick became Jason's legal guardian in 2002. 
 Ms. Patrick and her daughter moved into a government-subsidized apartment in a project building in Crown Heights. She took on her new challenges: Jason's well-being, $502.71 in rent, and other bills.
 Her relationship with Jason began unsteadily. When she was at work, it was easy for him to break her rules, and to find trouble. ''He was fighting, coming home late, and missing classes,'' Ms. Patrick said.
 Feeling alone and powerless, she went to the family court office seeking disciplinary help. 
 ''I wanted to send him to strict boot camp,'' she said. Family Court referred her to the Bedford-Stuyvesant Family Center, which is supported by the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, another beneficiary agency of the Neediest Cases. 
 ''They were adjusting to their new roles, from sibling to guardian,'' said the family's social worker, Kimberly Sandwall. ''We focused on developmental needs and parenting skills.''
 Together, they established a schedule of individual and joint counseling to forge communication and respect. 
 Jason was initially reluctant. He had found counseling unhelpful in the past. But this time was different.
 ''I could talk more,'' he said. ''They listened to me.'' Through his dedication to the program, which includes attending peer groups and career awareness classes, his outlook has changed. 
 ''Now he has a different understanding of the family,'' Ms. Patrick said. ''I have toned down. We don't argue as much.'' 
 And when money was tightest, the center provided Jason with a MetroCard for traveling to his meetings. For the family, there was access to a food pantry.
 Resources were tested again when Jason needed school clothes. Clothing competed against another need: unexpected travel costs. During the Republican National Convention, Ms. Patrick's hours at the call center were extended. So Felicia went to her father's, and Jason joined relatives in Pittsburgh. Giving Jason a getaway for two weeks was a good thing, but paying for it was a different story. 
 ''Paying the fare, I couldn't buy him clothes he needed for school,'' said Ms. Patrick. Ms. Sandwall came up with solution. 
 ''She said there was a fund that could help; it was such a relief,'' Ms. Patrick said. She and Jason were given $255 from the Neediest Cases for an itemized shopping list that included four shirts, five pairs of jeans, sneakers, and two belts. 
 The support of the center and the fund have helped Ms. Patrick feel less alone. As for life at home, ''it's gotten better,'' she said, smiling at Jason. ''It's gotten better.''

Starting Over
 Among the growing ranks of the working poor, many, like Desiree Marrow, 37, discover that poverty is not necessarily the result of one event, but of many. 
 At various points in Ms. Marrow's life, circumstances seemed to conspire against her. After her parents divorced when she was a child in Mount Vernon, N.Y., her working mother left her care to her aunts and a grandmother, she said. 
 ''They were always out,'' Ms. Marrow said during an interview at her Yonkers apartment. ''It was up to me to make my own decisions.''
 At 16 she had a child, Ksawn Collymore-bey, now 21; two years later came Makeba Marrow, now 19. Ms. Marrow's relationship with the father ended after four years. 
 She continued into two more relationships and had four more children, Jennara Marrow, 15, Karizma Marrow, 11, Irvin Campbell Jr., 8 and Dominique Campbell, 7.
 Men, it seemed, were full of empty promises. She recited the offenses -- they were abusive, they used drugs, they were in and out of jail. 
 She developed her own problem with drugs, and began selling them. Each night, her sleep was restless. She feared the police knocking at her door. A drug arrest could mean jail, or even the loss of her children. 
 ''I had to get myself together,'' she said. ''My kids had seen my down, now they had to see my ups.'' 
 Two years ago she enrolled in an outpatient rehab program. Clean and sober, she was ready to work. Her job search began when she read about a training program offered by Westchester Jewish Community Services, funded by UJA-Federation of New York, an agency supported by the Neediest Cases. 
 ''We wanted to help her stay on track,'' said Joan Thomas, her caseworker, recalling their first session. 
 With agency support, Ms. Marrow earned a certificate in home aid. She works 30 hours a week, for two clients, earning $214 a week.
 ''I like giving back and taking care of people,'' she said.
 Celebrating a job and a drug-free year, Ms. Marrow was hit with a setback that can devastate a paycheck-to-paycheck family. A fire caused by faulty wiring nearly destroyed her family's apartment. ''I literally had to start over,'' she said. 
 In two weeks, she found another apartment on the same block. To cover the rent of $1,250 and other living expenses, she receives $500 from the Human Resources Administration, and uses her weekly salary as a home assistant. She doesn't receive any child support. Her daughter Makeba contributes $200 a month from her sales position at Old Navy, and the family gets food stamps.
 Apart from the few things salvaged from her old place -- her bedroom set and a few dressers -- the apartment was unfurnished.
 ''I was asking everybody I knew for anything they could donate,'' she said. Some friends gave her thin mattresses for the children, who use them to sleep on the floor. Her father gave her a television.
 Ms. Marrow's living room would have remained bare, but Ms. Thomas, her caseworker, used the Neediest Cases fund to provide $800 for a couch, two chairs, an ottoman and two tables with two lamps. 
 The furniture helped restore her sense of dignity, and now she has another goal: a nursing degree. ''I am trying to improve myself for kids,'' she said. ''They are all I have.''

A Contribution to Build On
 The Starr Foundation, a private charitable group established by Cornelius Vander Starr, founder of the insurer American International Group, has donated $1 million in stock to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund for the fifth consecutive year. 
 ''Few institutions do more for distressed New Yorkers, both with its extensive direct grants and with monumental gifts like this for the Neediest,'' said Jack Rosenthal, president of The New York Times Foundation, which administers the Neediest Cases. ''And once again, by making its gift at the start of the campaign, the Starr Foundation creates for others what we hope is motivating momentum.''
 Its reach is broad, but the Starr Foundation's biggest areas of giving, according to Florence A. Davis, president of the Starr Foundation, include education, health care and other needs such as food programs for the poor, job training, and literacy programs. 
 ''The fact of the matter is that the solutions to poverty are very difficult and necessarily long term,'' Ms. Davis said. ''And in the meantime, we have to sustain a human level of existence for people in our city. That's what has attracted us to the Neediest Cases Fund, because the funds are really intended for families who need help now -- families who will otherwise become homeless, or families coming out of homelessness that need that extra help paying the heating bill.''
 Since its creation in 1955, the Starr Foundation has given $1.5 billion in grants. The group -- one of the largest private philanthropies in the United States, began its involvement with the Neediest Cases Fund in 1980, when it donated $33,500. This year's gift brings the Starr Foundation's cumulative donations to the Neediest Cases to about $8.4 million.

HOW TO HELP

To delay may mean to forget.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 31, 2004
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 5; New Jersey Weekly Desk; JERSEY; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 828 words

HEADLINE: A Wasteland in Sudan, Empathy in Newark

BYLINE: By FRAN SCHUMER

 BODY:
IT'S hard to drag yourself out on a Monday night in autumn, but earlier this month, those who drove to downtown Newark to hear more about the latest hellhole on the planet were oddly energized. There, in a beautiful museum that is underused -- the Newark Museum -- a group of Christians, Jews, African-Americans, Africans and Hispanics converged to learn more about what they could do about the devastating war in Sudan.
 ''I don't want my grandchildren wondering why we didn't do anything while this was going on,'' United States Representative Donald M. Payne of New Jersey said, echoing a sentiment that was common throughout the audience.
 The conference, organized by the Rutgers Institute on Ethnicity, the N.A.A.C.P. of Newark and other groups, featured Mr. Payne, who showed photographs of smiling children and sad-eyed mothers driven from their homes in Darfur in western Sudan. Maria Sliwa, a leader against slavery in the Sudan, and Gerald Martone of the International Rescue Committee, described the onslaught of the Janjaweed, Arab herders who have murdered, tortured and pillaged Darfurians, using the rape of women and, in some cases, children as young as 8 years old, as a principal weapon. 
 ''Some things are so bad that in fact you can get a coalition together,'' said Allyson Gall of the American Jewish Committee, a principal organizer of the conference.
 For people whose knowledge of the situation is limited, the evening provided a crash course in global politics and human fallibility. On the 10th anniversary of the atrocities in Rwanda, a combination of economic scarcity, ethnic rivalry -- both sides are Muslim, though one side is made up of Arab tribesmen and the other African villagers -- and a power struggle by the government in Khartoum, the capital, has cost at least 70,000 lives and displaced 1.5 million people. During a typical assault by the Janjaweed -- it means ''evil horseman'' -- the men rush to save their cattle and the women rush to save their children. When the women fail, they are raped and maimed. Even then, some return in search of lost children, whose bodies or heads they often find stuffed in wells.
 Asked why she came, Clarice Jackson, a retired teacher and lawyer from Orange, asked how she could not. ''We're slowing down in our activities, but we just had to do this,'' said Mrs. Jackson, who attended the conference with her husband, Alfred. Looking back on the close to, but not capacity, crowd, she expressed her one disappointment: ''That auditorium should've been full.''
 Harry Zutz, 80, a retired physician from Maplewood, said his motivation for coming stemmed from his reading last year of Samantha Power's Pulitzer-Prize-winning, ''A Problem From Hell: America and the Age of Genocide.'' 
 ''Being Jewish, I've become obsessed with genocide and ethnic cleansing,'' said Dr. Zutz, a former member of Health Volunteers Overseas, which trains medical personnel in underdeveloped countries. ''Survivors of the Holocaust say, 'Never again,' and yet there's this insouciance when it's another ethnic group involved.''
 Among a handful of Darfurians at the conference, Ishag Ahmed, treasurer of the Darfur Rehabilitation Project, said he hoped that foreign troops would intervene, but given the United States' involvement in Iraq, and the United Nations' resistance on the issue -- China does business in the Sudan, where oil was discovered in the 1970's -- he doubted such a solution was imminent. 
 Meantime, like other Darfurians -- about 20 live in New Jersey -- he eagerly awaits news from home. His mother, a brother and nine nieces and nephews survived a rampage by the Janjaweed, and are now safe, thanks to money provided by Mr. Ahmed and another brother.
 Other Darfurians are not so lucky. Starving in makeshift camps with scant supplies, the displaced are rapidly dying. Asked about priorities, the panel said that the village elders cited not only food and water, but schools. The day goes more quickly when the children have something to think about other than food.
 ''In America, we're all preoccupied with the election -- and rightfully so,'' Dr. Zutz said. ''Meanwhile, this goes on. '' 
 The son of Ukrainian immigrants who attended public school in Delaware, Dr. Zutz said that his own evolution as a global citizen happened slowly. ''I can't believe how stupid and unsophisticated we were,'' he said. ''It never occurred to me until years later, for instance, that there weren't any blacks in my school.''
 His perspective broadened in the 1960's when he read Rachel Carson's ''Silent Spring,'' and books about world poverty and hunger. Eventually, he enrolled at Drew University, and received a master's degree in theological studies. During the next 20 years, he and his wife visited Africa, India, Afghanistan and Bangladesh as members of the health volunteers.
 ''Forgive my verbosity,'' he said after a long conversation on Darfur. ''I find so few people who are interested in the subject.''
