Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1047 words

HEADLINE: Looking for Flu Vaccine, and Answers, in the Drug Capital

BYLINE: By KIRSTY SUCATO

DATELINE: PEAPACK 

 BODY:
ON a recent brisk morning, more than 400 elderly people some with canes, walkers and wheelchairs -- began lining up outside the Borough of Gladstone and Peapack Municipal Complex here as early as 4 a.m. for a chance to get a rare flu shot.
 The irony of such a sight -- here amid the wealth and privilege of Somerset County with its hilly horse farms, stone churches and country clubs -- did not escape the notice of a large crowd, the likes of which had not been seen since Police Chief Greg Skinner was sworn in a year and a half ago. After all, this is the very epicenter of pharmaceutical power, only miles from the headquarters of such industry giants as Aventis, Merck and Pfizer.
 Indeed, of the world's 20 largest pharmaceutical companies, 15 have major facilities in New Jersey, employing 63,000 people and adding $23.8 billion a year to the state's economy, according to industry groups. 
 ''I believe in our country 100 percent and I back the U.S.A.,'' said 71-year-old Judy M. Peres of Far Hills. ''However, for something like this to happen is almost unbelievable. For all these old and sick people, for them to have to stand outside for an hour and a half is absurd.''
 She hoped her husband, David, 76, would not be late for his next appointment -- for radiation treatment, at Morristown Memorial Hospital -- and that his cashmere sweater, jacket and fedora would fight the autumn chill as he sat on a folding metal chair she had brought from home. 
 The friendly chatter and the free coffee and donuts supplied by the Friends of the Peapack and Gladstone Library did not mollify her.
 ''He's a terminally ill cancer patient and the last thing in the world he needs is flu also,'' Mrs. Peres said. ''That could do him in. Now he was out there for an hour and a half so he really needs the flu shot now. He'll probably be sick tomorrow.'' 
 Actually the couple and the 409 others vaccinated at the clinic that day were fortunate. Lucy A. Forgione of the Bernards Township Health Department had scored 500 doses of vaccine from the Visiting Nurse Association of Somerset Hills, a private agency that had purchased vaccine directly from Aventis Pasteur, the world's largest manufacturer of flu vaccine. 
 Like hundreds of thousands of health workers nationwide, Ms. Forgione was left hanging on Oct. 5 when her supplier, Chiron Corporation, defaulted on its promise to provide more than half of the nation's supply of flu vaccine -- 46 to 48 million doses -- because it was contaminated with bacteria, resulting in one of the worst crises in the history of the nation's flu vaccination program.
 Vaccination clinics nationwide are being canceled indefinitely just as the influenza virus begins its nasty march, bringing muscle aches, sneezing, hacking coughs, fever and even death to the frail and elderly. About 36,000 Americans die each year from the flu.
 In New Jersey, more than 20 hospitals and most nursing homes, which house 60,000 residents, are still without supplies. Even with an additional 2.7 million doses promised by Aventis in January and another 1.5 million proposed to be imported from Canada, health agencies will receive slightly more than half of the flu vaccine that they ordered, said New Jersey's health commissioner, Dr. Clifton R. Lacy.
 Officials are trying to determine how much vaccine remains in New Jersey and get a count of residents who need it most, he said. Nationwide, about 60 million doses will be available and about 43 million people are considered high priority. 
 ''We will have a significant shortfall,'' Dr. Lacey said, ''but if you reallocate it optimally you can satisfy the need for the priority groups.'' 
 For now, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have issued guidelines urging that priority be given to people over 65, those with chronic medical conditions, children on long-term aspirin therapy, pregnant women, infants 6 to 23 months, health care workers, residents of nursing homes and long-term care facilities, and people who live with babies under 6 months old.
 Health officials who have spent years proselytizing for flu vaccine are now left urging residents to wash their hands frequently, cover their mouths when coughing and sneezing, stay home when they are sick and seek antiviral medicines that can slow the effects of the flu virus.
 ''The sad thing is that people will not get immunized,'' said Karen Ellis, the community health program manager for the Visiting Nurse Association of Somerset Hills. ''It's just a fact. You can't shut down half of your incoming vaccine without ramifications. You just can't do it.''
 In the last week, the State Legislature passed and Governor McGreevey approved a measure authorizing the health commissioner to redirect vaccine supplies to the most needy and impose a $500 fine on health care providers who give flu vaccine to people outside the high priority category.
 But for people like Anita A. Schwartz, a Basking Ridge resident in her 70's, the measures are too little, too late. 
 Her search for a flu shot was stressful, and Ms. Schwartz says, something that should have been avoided by better planning. It led her from her doctor's office to a Rite Aid Pharmacy to a clinic at the King Super Market in Mendham, where she and her 84-year-old husband waited in line for two hours before leaving because of the cold. Finally, a phone call to the Basking Ridge municipal building alerted her to the clinic at Peapack and Gladstone. And she was one of the lucky ones.
 ''I feel the government was remiss,'' she said. ''I feel that you do not put this kind of responsibility in the hands of supermarkets.''
 Others were more forgiving.
 ''I don't think we can blame anybody,'' said F. Arthur Winter, a retired chemical engineer from Basking Ridge. ''We were caught short because the British government shut the supplier down.'' 
 His wife, Dolores agreed, but added, ''We have a lot of talent in the United States and we just need to address the problem to make it widely available and to recognize that it needs to be widely available.'' 
 Ms. Winter mused about the dozens of pharmaceutical companies that make their home in New Jersey and said dryly, ''Even though we are seeing all these corporations, we shouldn't feel that entitles us in any way to anything different.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: Jay Abberman of Bernardsville getting a vaccination at the Gladstone and Peapack Municipal Complex. (Photo by Dith Pran/The New York Times)(pg. 1)
 Brother, can you spare a flu shot? People preparing for a flu shot clinic at the Gladstone and Peapack Municipal Complex. Of the world's 20 largest pharmaceutical companies, 15 have major facilities in New Jersey -- not that it's helping residents get hold of flu vaccine. (Photographs by Dith Pran/The New York Times)(pg. 5)

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 2251 words

HEADLINE: As Far as Political Polls, N.J. Owns the Pole Position

BYLINE: By ROBERT STRAUSS

DATELINE: PRINCETON 

 BODY:
SET off from the parking lot of Building 502 at the Carnegie Center there is a well-kept basketball court, and Frank Newport -- long and lanky -- looks like he would be a natural. 
 But these days, Mr. Newport, editor in chief of the Gallup Poll, has been spending about 16 hours a day inside the nondescript building trying to figure out whom the American people will put in the White House.
 Come Tuesday, the eyes of Texas and Massachusetts and all points in between will shift a bit north on Route 206, to downtown Somerville, where Edison Media Research will be tabulating exit polls for a consortium of television networks and major media outlets (including The New York Times) so they can declare -- perhaps -- a winner.
 For Gallup, it has been a bit of a bumpy campaign trail. 
 ''You have to have tough skin sometimes,'' said Mr. Newport of Gallup. ''You should read our e-mails. You show Bush going ahead and you get the Democrats railing. Once we show Kerry doing better, the Republicans hate that.''
 Ever since George Gallup came East from Iowa and found his dream farmhouse in Princeton, the town has been an epicenter of political polling. Generations of pollsters learned their trade at Gallup, with some splitting off to start their own polling organizations.
 ''Like in Silicon Valley, where tech firms spread upon each other, because Gallup was here, many public opinion polling firms have sprung up in and around Princeton,'' he said. ''You get one major company in a geographic area, like in Detroit, and others naturally spring about.''
 The Gallup progeny are myriad. 
 Andrew Kohut, director of the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press, which conducts several political and policy polls, is a former president of the Gallup Organization. Mr. Kohut founded -- though he is no longer associated with -- Princeton Survey Research Associates International, which does the Newsweek Poll. 
 And many of those who have worked for Gallup over the years were products of Rutgers University, which oversees the Eagleton Institute of Politics, home of the Star-Ledger/Eagleton-Rutgers Poll. Even the Texas Poll, the oldest state poll, has a New Jersey lineage, since Gallup taught Joseph Belden -- who founded the Texas Poll in 1937 -- polling techniques.
 Nor does the state's symbiotic relationship with polls end there. New Jersey -- for years considered a bellwether state because of its variegated population -- became a ripe subject for polling. Gallup and Eagleton have long monitored New Jersey politics, policy, and lifestyles, and in 2001, Fairleigh Dickinson University in Madison started the PublicMind Poll, concentrating on New Jersey issues. Even Quinnipiac University in Connecticut finds New Jersey interesting enough to poll -- one of only five states it monitors.
 ''We could be in California, we could be anywhere,'' said Larry Hugick, chairman of Princeton Survey Research Associates, who worked at Gallup under Mr. Kohut. ''But many of us have come from New Jersey, and this is a great place to stay. It's a good place for fertile minds.''
 In the cases of Quinnipiac and Fairleigh Dickinson, there is a dual purpose in polling. It is both an academic exercise underwritten by the universities, and a way to get the school's name out in public.
 ''We felt we had a great collection of political scientists at Fairleigh Dickinson and it occurred to us that one of the best ways to engage them in the university was to give them the opportunity to do public opinion research,'' said Peter Woolley, executive director of the FDU PublicMind Poll.
 If it were not for the poll -- ubiquitous during campaign season -- Quinnipiac University would be largely unknown outside Connecticut, obscured by schools like Yale, Wesleyan, and Trinity.
 ''Colleges are in the knowledge business,'' said Maurice Carroll, a former reporter for Newsday and The New York Times who is director of the Quinnipiac University Polling Institute. ''But this is a serious thing. We didn't just make a tiddlywinks team to get the school publicity.''
 During the presidential polling season, it seems that all of the New Jersey-based polls are tripping over each other to get out the latest, and sometimes cutest, results.
 For instance, three weeks ago Mr. Newport started a six-to eight-minute weekday Webcast to illustrate Gallup's polls. While the Webcast is primarily produced in a studio down the hall from his office, Mr. Newport -- with some trepidation -- moved it outside to the parking lot to explain a poll on gas prices.
 Then there is the PublicMind poll, which dipped into the offbeat a bit. In early October, it released a survey showing that more people thought the television mobster Tony Soprano would vote for George W. Bush over John Kerry, mostly because they thought Mr. Soprano would think Mr. Bush a strong leader. The same poll noted that New Jerseyans were generally not swayed by Bruce Springsteen's endorsement of Mr. Kerry -- that those who were going to vote for Mr. Kerry would not care whether Mr. Springsteen endorsed him.
 Gimmicks notwithstanding, most of the pollsters agree that this year's presidential race -- because of its closeness and volatility -- can stand on its own. And while they have not changed their methodologies, there clearly are things going on that have made this race difficult to poll about. For instance, there has been a lot of talk about people who only own cellphones and cannot be reached by pollsters using their ordinary method of random sample dialing
 For his part, Mr. Hugick of Princeton Surveys dismisses that notion.
 ''There are certainly more cellphone-only homes than there were, but I don't know that there are enough to worry about,'' he said. ''It is a disproportionate amount of low-income youth, which tends to vote less anyway, and also somewhat equivalent to what in the past would be no-phone homes. ''There are other issues, though: call-blocking, caller-ID, and just the propensity to not get on the phone with someone you don't know.''
 To Jeffrey Levine, director of the Center for Public Interest Polling at the Eagleton Institute for Politics at Rutgers, predicting turnout this year is particularly challenging because of the unusually large number of young people who registered to vote this fall. 
 ''It is always a challenge to reach younger people,'' said Mr. Levine. ''They are more transitory. They tend not to be home. In low-turnout years, they tend not to vote, but we are just not sure what will happen this year.''
 Mr. Hugick and the other pollsters made it clear that it is not necessarily an issue of counting the homes with only cellphones, but replacing them in a survey to get the right mix of age, registration, income, race, and other demographics to make a poll accurate. That still means they have to make more calls just to get the responses necessary for an accurate survey -- usually about 1,000 people properly distributed in terms of demographics.
 ''That's the key, whether you get a good sample,'' said Mr. Hugick. ''It's what got Dr. Gallup his reputation in the first place.''
 In 1935, fresh from the University of Iowa with a Ph.D., George Gallup moved East to be a researcher for a New York advertising agency. Then a friend suggested that he look at a piece of property in Princeton, a perfect place to raise his young family. In his leisure time, mostly at home, Mr. Gallup indulged in his pastime, political polling.
 In 1936, the presidential race -- for a time, anyway -- seemed to be a runaway for the Republican challenger, Alf Landon. The Democratic incumbent, Franklin D. Roosevelt, had not extricated the country from Depression and fascist governments were emerging throughout Europe. The most prominent poll of the day, conducted by the magazine Literary Digest, showed Mr. Landon winning. Its method was getting lists, primarily of magazine subscribers and automobile buyers, and mailing them postcards to return. More than two million people responded.
 Yet Gallup knew the poll was flawed, and he was determined on getting the proper random sampling of the voting population. He maintained that the Literary Digest had severely undercounted farmers and others less affluent -- people who would not necessarily subscribe to magazines or have recently bought cars. His result was the same as the election -- overwhelmingly for Roosevelt.
 ''His reputation was established, but more importantly, his methodology was vindicated,'' said Mr. Newport.
 Even so, Mr. Gallup did not quit his day job right away. Election polling did not have the market it does today. Nonetheless, he took his time establishing his business in Princeton, eventually building it up into a large marketing and polling organization. When Mr. Gallup died in 1984, his children took over the business for a while, but eventually merged the Gallup Organization with a Nebraska company in 1988. The official international headquarters for the Gallup Organization is in Washington, while the national headquarters is in Omaha. But the Gallup Poll, the political polling arm, stayed in Princeton.
 ''Most people thought George Gallup was a professor, but he had nothing to do with the university,'' said Mr. Newport. ''But we like being in Princeton. I think it's more we like being on neutral ground. If you are in New York or Washington, you are in kind of a bubble. Here in Princeton we are a little more removed. Our job here is to represent what people across the country are thinking. I don't need to be in Washington prowling the streets and interviewing staffers. I don't care what they think.''
 That does not mean that pollsters here do not get edgy about accusations that they are unfair. For instance, this year Gallup has been accused of leaning more toward Mr. Bush since it assumes, from its research, that Republicans tend to be more likely voters than Democrats. 
 Mr. Hugick said the point of the Newsweek poll is to see what people are thinking at that moment rather than trying to project to Election Day, so it is prone to swing by the news of the day and anger one side or the other. Quinnipiac tends to use students as interviewers, in part reaching their academic purpose of involving students in the process, so it is criticized for not employing true professionals.
 ''What is most amazing this year is that people are, indeed, changing their minds during the fall,'' said Mr. Kohut, who commuted from Princeton to Washington for several years after going to work for Pew. He now lives in Washington and retains a small financial interest in Princeton Survey Research Associates. 
 ''When you have a dynamic scene, particularly at the end of an election, it is really exciting,'' he said. ''Your heart goes in your stomach.''
 Mr. Kohut said most pollsters welcome the newcomers like Fairleigh Dickinson's PublicMind. As he put it, the more good polls there are -- especially if they are asking complementary types of questions, such as in New Jersey -- the more the public benefits. For their part, the academics are particularly happy to be in the polling fray.
 ''We're political scientists by profession and political junkies by temperament,'' said Mr. Woolley of PublicMind. ''But we want to do it right and want to use our expertise to interpret the other polls, then figure out things they didn't ask and we want to know.''
 While several polling organizations have gone to Internet responses, those based in New Jersey are still wedded to the idea of personal contact by phone. For his part, Mr. Newport is sometimes nostalgic for the days of door-to-door surveys, which Gallup did not completely give up until the late 1980's.
 ''There are advantages to an in-person interview,'' he said, ''even if it is more labor-intensive.''
 He then explained: ''We used to laugh about the question, 'Are you overweight?' We thought that on the phone, more people were saying their weren't overweight. But you go out and see a 300-pound person, it's hard for them to say they aren't overweight.''
 Though they live in a world of seemingly raw data, the pollsters all claim there is art in their work, particularly in a close election. Mr. Newport pointed out that no incumbent since Harry Truman had an approval rating of less than 50 percent at election time and won -- and even Truman's number was calculated a couple of weeks before the election, so it may not have been accurate on Election Day. Mr. Bush has been teetering on the 50-percent line for weeks.
 Mr. Hugick's favorite last-minute indicator concerns the lingering undecided voters. If you take the last Gallup Poll -- the one being conducted today -- the undecideds usually break as much as 10-to-1 for the challenger. In other words, if the final poll is 48 percent to 48 percent, with 4 percent undecided, it is probable that Mr. Kerry will pick up enough of that vote to come out on top.
 ''In the 1992 election, though, almost all of that vote went to the third-party candidate, Ross Perot, so Bill Clinton didn't pick up much in the end,'' he said. ''What it seems is that if you are undecided at the very end, you are more likely just trying to figure out if you want the guy to stay in office. If you have gone that far, you probably really want a change.''
 By week's end, the pollsters will be able to relax, though only for a moment.
 ''Oh, then we're going to have to see what people think of Codey and how the governor's election will play out next year,'' said Mr. Carroll from Quinnipiac. ''We're addicted. It's a great living.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: Feeling the pulse of the nation: Larry Hugick, above left, chairman of Princeton Survey Research Associates, and Frank Newport of Gallup, standing, preparing for a television segment. (Photographs by Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 8; Column 5; Sports Desk; PRO FOOTBALL; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 1030 words

HEADLINE: In the N.F.L., It's Not About Money, but It Is

BYLINE: By DAMON HACK

 BODY:
Down the interstate from an 80-foot tire, one of the many symbols of industry in Michigan, National Football League owners and the players association director, Gene Upshaw, met last week in Dearborn to haggle over what often inspires tussles between labor and management in business.
 ''When we say it's not about the money, it's about the money,'' Upshaw said in a telephone interview Wednesday. ''We're not making the economic argument that the players are being trampled on, but it's an argument on fairness and on what we contribute to the game. We may not get everything we want, but they're not going to get everything they want either. And we're going to get more.'' 
 With the National Hockey League in a lockout, and with memories of labor standoffs in Major League Baseball and the National Basketball Association still fresh, the N.F.L. finds itself in a difficult renegotiation of its collective bargaining agreement.
 If the sides fail to negotiate an extension before 2007, that season will be played without a salary cap, a bargaining tool clearly in the union's favor and a situation the owners do not want to invite. The current agreement ends in the spring of 2008.
 Over the course of the league's 10-year-old pact -- which has been extended four times -- amicable relations have been maintained between union and management and particularly between Upshaw and Commissioner Paul Tagliabue. 
 Though neither side envisions a work stoppage, which last occurred in the N.F.L. in 1987, several factors could at least contribute to a debate, notably the union's desire for more money in the league's designated gross revenue pool, which pays the players under the salary cap system.
 Upshaw said the league's agreement had flaws in a 2004 economy, with the N.F.L. the most lucrative sport in North America.
 He said the eight highest-revenue teams were earning more money (as much as $100 million more) than other clubs through an increase in unshared revenue, the money each team pockets through its local ventures like radio broadcasts, stadium advertising and team magazines.
 Although some owners in smaller markets have voiced similar concerns, Tagliabue disagrees with Upshaw's view of the league's financial structure.
 ''To me, it's an oversimplification,'' Tagliabue said Thursday. ''First of all, some of the so-called haves, one of the things they do have is a lot of debt from having to build a stadium from their own family resources. If you're financing a stadium yourself, you're going to end up with a lot of annual construction costs, amortizing interest and costs that go to the bank, not to the owner.''
 Harold Henderson, the chairman of the N.F.L. management council and the league's chief negotiator, acknowledged that a disparity in revenue exists among some teams. But in finding common ground, Henderson said the league and the players' association ''have some issues on which we are very far apart.'' 
 ''When it came to ephedra, it was a pretty easy negotiation,'' Henderson said of discussions with Upshaw on the substance now banned by the league. ''This one, it's money. It's different. He's been pretty tough. It's pretty likely we'll get a deal done, but it's certainly not a positive thing and it's not a certain thing.''
 Stephen Ross, a professor of law at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, said in a telephone interview Friday that he did not believe the N.F.L. would go the way of hockey, whose players were locked out 45 days ago and are scattering around the world in search of a game.
 ''The football union has this huge leverage that the hockey players don't, which is an uncapped year,'' Ross said of the 2007 season. ''Secondly, the have-not teams are sort of on Upshaw's side. He wants more money to be put into the designated gross revenue, which will increase the salary cap, and he would prefer that the money be shared among the owners.''
 Upshaw and Tagliabue, Ross said, are trying to figure out ''how do we make the pie as big as possible and then we can fight about splitting up the pie.''
 ''Gene Upshaw's problem isn't with Paul Tagliabue, Gene Upshaw's problem is with those eight teams,'' Ross said. ''The difficulty is that there are individual owners who are saying, 'I'd rather have a smaller pie and get a big piece than have a big juicy pie and get a small piece.'''
 Dan Rooney, the Pittsburgh Steelers owner, said he agreed with Upshaw that there was a noticeable disparity in revenue among teams, ''and we're not one of the ones that are at the bottom.''
 One factor that may actually spur an agreement is the concurrent negotiation involving the league's television contract, which is shared revenue among the owners that also pays the players' salaries.
 The current television deal, which ends after the 2005 season, is worth nearly $18 billion over eight years.
 The N.F.L. will garner a more lucrative television contract if the collective bargaining agreement is extended because it would show the networks that the sport will be stable into the next decade.
 The players, like the league, have benefited from labor peace.
 ''One thing we don't want is to kill the goose that laid the golden egg,'' Upshaw said.
 The owners do not want to edge too close to the uncapped year of 2007, where salaries would no longer have a ceiling.
 ''Anything that is unknown is better to be left unknown,'' said John York, the owner of the San Francisco 49ers.

	 	 		--------------------	 	

Dolphins Sue Williams
 MIAMI, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Miami Dolphins have filed a lawsuit in federal court against Ricky Williams, who an arbitrator has ruled owes the team more than $8.6 million for breaching his contract.
 A Dolphins spokesman, Harvey Greene, would not say Saturday if the lawsuit, filed Friday, was related to the arbitrator's ruling last month. 
 A phone call Saturday to Williams's lawyer, David Cornwell, was not immediately returned.
 Williams left the Dolphins shortly before training camp, saying he disagreed with the N.F.L. over a disputed drug test. He is seeking to return to the league. The Miami Herald has quoted Williams as saying he has failed three drug tests -- in May 2002, last December and sometime last spring.


GRAPHIC: Photo: Paul Tagliabue (Photo by Associated Press)

SECTION: Section 11; Column 4; Real Estate Desk; POSTINGS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 519 words

HEADLINE: A Costly Summer For Renters in Manhattan

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Despite the siren song of low interest rates and the lure of home ownership, rents on Manhattan apartments rose during the peak summer rental season to the highest level in three years, according to two new market surveys.
 One survey, by Halstead Leasing Consultants, found that the average rent on a Manhattan apartment rose by more than 5 percent during the spring and summer, and 7 percent for the year, to $2,707 a month. Still, on average, rents remained nearly 9 percent below the peaks set in 2000, at the end of the stock market boom. 
 Another survey, by Citi Habitats, also showed a significant increase in rents, and a declining vacancy rate, to 1.7 percent, in 140 buildings tracked from month to month in Manhattan. Andrew Heiberger, president of Citi Habitats, said the vacancy rate was more than 4 percent after Sept. 11, 2001, while it is as much as 10 percent nationwide.
 The Halstead report found that rents on larger apartments increased slightly faster than on smaller apartments, with two-bedroom apartments averaging $3,846 a month, as many would-be buyers found themselves priced out of two-bedroom condominiums, which sold at an average price of nearly $1.4 million over the summer.
 Nancy Packes, president of Halstead Leasing, attributed the rebound in rents to rising demand for apartments as the economy picked up, coupled with a decrease in the supply of highly sought after new rental buildings, as developers focused on ever more lucrative condominiums instead.
 In 2004, Ms. Packes said, Manhattan has gained about 60,000 jobs. At the same time, developers are on track to complete about 2,900 market-rate apartments in Manhattan below 96th Street this year, 40 percent fewer than in 2003.
 David J. Wine, the president of Related Residential Development, said that with the price of land in Manhattan so high, the trend toward building condos rather than rental buildings is likely to continue, putting upward pressure on rents.
 And with the number of concessions -- such as free rents and subsidized broker fees -- falling, the bump-up in rents actually paid by tenants may be larger than the survey suggests. ''During the height of the summer months, many of the free-rent concessions and owner-paid commissions went away,'' Ms. Packes said. 
 The Citi Habitats survey confirmed that beginning last winter, average rents began to rise in all apartment sizes and continued through the summer. Mr. Heiberger said that the heated sales market, larger bonuses paid to employees in the financial services industry, and a continuing decline in the crime rate contributed to the price increases. 
 ''The rental market in Manhattan has shown incredible resilience and significant growth,'' he said. 
 According to the Halstead report, average monthly rents on two-bedroom apartments were up to $3,846, from $3,547 in the corresponding period last year, for an increase of 8 percent. One-bedrooms were up from $2,289 to $2,471, or 7.9 percent. Studio apartments were up the least, from $1,749 to $1,804, or 3 percent, and had actually declined slightly during the spring and summer. JOSH BARBANEL

HEADLINE: More Than Bush-Kerry on the Ballot

BYLINE: By FRAN SILVERMAN

 BODY:
WHEN residents go to polls on Tuesday they will not only be deciding which presidential candidate is best, but they may also be deciding whether their town should build a new wastewater treatment plant, buy a new fire engine or spend millions to renovate schools.
 Taking advantage of the expected high turnout at the polls, towns have put more than 50 referendum items on Tuesday's ballot. They range from minor charter revision questions to million-dollar bonding issues. From Stamford and Plainfield, where voters will decide whether to increase the term of the town clerk, to Waterbury, where they have to weigh in on a $101 million school construction project, to Portland where residents are deciding whether to establish a new ethics commission, this election is as local as it is national.
 ''The questions directly involve how local government is going to spend money on big projects and how, through the charter, the dynamics of government may change in a year,'' said Kevin Maloney, a spokesman for the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities. ''They have a direct impact on how life in a community will be.'' 
 But some town officials fear that while the presidential election will bring more voters to the polls, the referendum questions will get lost in the hoopla of the national campaign.
 Minor issues such as extending the term of a registrar of voters or spending $375,000 to replace a fire truck may seem irrelevant, arcane or even silly to voters who are grappling this year with such issues as Iraq, stem-cell research and abortion.
 ''Some of these issues will have a low level of saliency,'' said Darryl McMiller, assistant professor of politics at the University of Hartford. ''They are below the radar for many.''
 Still, Mr. McMiller and others political analysts said referendums were part of New England's fiercely historic commitment to participatory democracy. In a state like Connecticut where many communities still hold town meetings, ballot questions allow every resident to have a direct say.
 ''Connecticut has more of this than other places because we have 169 fiefdoms that have a wide variety of forms of government, such as first selectman, council, strong mayor, weak mayor, town managers,'' said Christopher Barnes, director of development for the Department of Public Policy at the University of Connecticut. ''Sometimes you use referendum to get around the mess of town government. A lot of referendum happen because we don't have faith in representative democracy where you take the minutia out of the hands of the mass public.'' 
 Political experts said people often express the desire for more control over political decisions.
 ''If you look at the history of referendum, it's about allowing people to play a role in government, particularly around issues involving money,'' Mr. McMiller said. 
 Towns sometimes grapple with whether to place a referendum issue on a November election ballot, or on a separate ballot at a different time of year, officials said. During separate elections, towns may not get enough voters to cast ballots, although those who do may be more interested and informed about the issue. Town officials said separate referendum elections often attract only the residents who want to defeat a proposal. The November ballot, however, is less costly for local governments and guarantees a good representation of voters, they said.
 Residents will be doing themselves a disservice if they neglect to vote on a referendum issue, they said.
 ''In many ways local questions may impact your daily life more so than the national election because it oftentimes relates to the quality of your schools, the quality of your roads, and the level of your property taxes,'' said Larry Perosino, spokesman for the secretary of state's office, which oversees referendums. ''Unfortunately, though, we do see that some voters miss the questions simply because they are going in with the thought of voting for the presidential candidate.''
 In Plainfield, Helen Coombs, the town clerk, admitted that she's been so busy registering voters, she hasn't had time to think much about the referendum question that could benefit her.
 Plainfield has seven referendum questions on Tuesday's ballot, including one that will increase the term of the town clerk and tax collector to four years from two.
 ''I guess I'll vote for it. It is a pain to constantly run for re-election,'' said Ms. Coombs, a Democrat, who has been town clerk since 1993.
 In Cheshire, Joe Michelangelo, the public works director, said he hoped residents would pay attention to the referendum on the $1.4 million appropriation for a pump station.
 ''It affects 20 percent of sewage users in Cheshire,'' he said. ''They have to be able to flush their toilets, too.''
 Clinton has the most questions, 12, on the ballot. They range from whether the town clerk and tax collector should be hired rather than elected, to whether the duties of the public works commission be revised.
 First Selectman James McCusker Jr., a 10-year incumbent, said many of the questions have been discussed for years. Officials, he said, were eager to get them on the ballot in this presidential election so the town's 8,000 registered voters could finally settle them.
 Coventry voters have only one question on the ballot Tuesday: They must decide whether to approve a $1.7 million appropriation for a new police station. The station is on the first floor of town hall. Police Chief Beau Thurnauer said the jail cell at the station dates to the 1800's. The cell, located right in the middle of the station, has no ventilation system or floor drains.
 ''The people who occupy cells don't often come with cologne,'' Chief Thurnauer said. ''It's pretty nasty.''
 The station's location in town hall also prevents victims and those charged with crimes from having any privacy as visitors to town hall pass them on the way to other offices, he said. Male and female police officers, who have to share one coed locker room, also have no privacy. If approved, the average taxpayer in town will pay about $24 a year for the project, Chief Thurnauer said.
 In Oxford, residents will decide whether to establish a foreign trade zone. The zone allows manufacturers to import raw materials without paying tariffs, assemble products with the materials and then export them for sale. If the products are sold in the United States they are subject to reduced tariffs. First Selectman Augie Palmer said the town, which has a small general aviation airport, will benefit by adding new businesses to its tax rolls. 
 ''The Town of Oxford enjoys a very low mill rate, but that doesn't mean we should sit back if we want to keep it low,'' Mr. Palmer said.
 He said eight companies are already interested in opening a location in the zone, which would be on 2,500 acres near the airport. 
 Mr. Palmer considered the issue just as important as the presidential ballot.
 ''This is a weighty issue,'' he said. ''It's our economy.''
 With interest rates low, a number of municipalities are asking voters to approve road and school renovation projects. Vernon has a $19 million sidewalk, road and bridge project on the ballot and Enfield a $24 million one. Manchester has a $35.2 million appropriation question for renovations and additions to its high school. South Windsor is asking voters to approve $92 million to renovate all its elementary schools. Glastonbury is asking residents to approve $29.5 million for the design and construction of a new elementary school.
 In Waterbury, members of the Independent Party gathered signatures to force a referendum on a $101 million school renovation project to deal with overcrowding. And that item is just one of eight. The rest deal with charter issues, including whether the mayor should serve a four-year term and be allowed to appoint five members of an 11-member board of education.
 In a city where the past three mayors have been embroiled in scandal and corruption investigations, city officials said they were not worried that those questions will get ignored.
 ''We have a very embarrassing past history here,'' Mayor Michael J. Jarjura said. ''The charter needed a major overhaul.'' 
 He said voters might feel funny taking a long time in the voting booth to go through all the referendum questions, especially if in a presidential year there are long lines behind them. 
 ''I think people feel when they are behind the curtain, they want to open it right away,'' Mr. Jarjura said. ''I say, 'Take your time. Why rush?'''


GRAPHIC: Photos: Voters in Plainfield will decide on the term for the town clerk, Helen Coombs, above. In Coventry, a new police station is on the ballot. (Photographs by C.M. Glover for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1254 words

HEADLINE: Aided by Uruguay's Problems, Left Is Expected to Gain Power

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Oct. 30 

 BODY:
Aided by a severe economic and social crisis, a coalition of left-wing groups that includes former guerrillas is poised to win at the ballot box here Sunday what it could not achieve through armed struggle a generation ago: political power in a country that was once one of the most prosperous in Latin America.
 The former guerrillas, the Tupamaros, are the largest single component of the group known as the Progressive-Encounter-Broad-Front-New-Majority, whose candidate for president is Tabare Vazquez, a charismatic 64-year-old doctor who is making his third run for the office. Although opponents have tried to make an issue of the Tupamaros' violent past, those efforts have largely been disregarded. 
 ''We have changed a lot because the world has changed, but what remains the same is our commitment to changes that benefit the excluded majority,'' Senator Jose Mujica, leader of the Tupamaro faction, said in an interview here. ''Our path and our methods depend on the historical context.'' 
 Dr. Vazquez needs 50 percent of the vote to avoid a runoff on Nov. 28, and polls show him either just above or just below that figure. He finished first in the initial round of the 1999 balloting, with 40 percent of the vote, but lost decisively in the runoff, which is widely assumed to have been put in place specifically to make it more difficult for his coalition to win.
 An oncologist and former mayor of this capital city, Dr. Vazquez has promised to follow moderate policies if elected, saying that while his ''eyes are on utopia, my feet are on the ground.'' He has also said he plans to continue practicing medicine one day a week and will delegate much authority to his staff, ''since we medical people are used to working in teams.''
 A Socialist, Dr. Vazquez himself never joined the Tupamaros, although a brother, now the head of his security detail, was a member of an even more militant group and was in jail during the military dictatorship that was in power from 1973 to 1985. Founded in 1963, the Tupamaros were originally urban guerrillas who assassinated police officers and kidnapped government officials and diplomats, including a British ambassador and Dan Mitrione, an American adviser to Uruguayan security forces whose death in 1970 while in the Tupamaros' hands inspired the Costa-Gavras film ''State of Siege.''
 The election here is being closely watched throughout Latin America and in Washington. If Dr. Vazquez wins, he would join Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva of Brazil, Nestor Kirchner of Argentina and Hugo Chavez of Venezuela in a bloc of heads of state who, to varying degrees, have expressed opposition to or skepticism about American-led pressures to follow free-market policies. 
 Despite its small size, Uruguay has the potential to be part of ''the most important revolution in recent Latin American history,'' Dr. Vazquez told an ecstatic throng of several hundred thousand people here on Wednesday night at a rally closing his campaign. Brazilian and Argentine officials have openly endorsed his candidacy, provoking irritation in the government here and complaints of interference in Uruguay's internal affairs.
 In an effort to increase Uruguay's bargaining power regionally, the current president, Jorge Batlle, has closely aligned the country with the United States. Dr. Vazquez's campaign platform, on the other hand, calls for ''independence with respect to political and military alliances under the hegemony of great powers,'' and at a news conference here on Friday, he vowed to ''recover'' the tradition of neutrality ''that in recent years has been lost.''
 A victory by his coalition would also produce a fundamental shift in the country's domestic politics by bringing the left to power for the first time. Two centrist parties founded in the middle of the 19th century, known as the Colorados and the Blancos -- the Reds and the Whites -- have alternated in power, except when coups left the military in control of this nation of 3.5 million people. 
 ''This election is reiterating a change produced in the last two elections, which is that the two traditional parties are confronted with an important new force,'' Julio Maria Sanguinetti, a Colorado leader who served two terms as president of Uruguay, from 1985 to 1990 and from 1995 to 2000. ''We're no longer in a two-party scenario in which it is Blanco versus Colorado and Colorado versus Blanco.''
 The current Colorado government is so unpopular that its candidate, Guillermo Stirling, is expected to win only 10 percent of the vote. But the Blanco candidate, Jorge Larranaga, a 48-year-old lawyer, has been moving to the left and taking populist positions in the hope of forcing a runoff. He had the support of about 30 percent of those asked in recent polls.
 Uruguay was once known as ''the Switzerland of South America'' because of its highly educated, predominantly middle-class population and its strong network of social benefits, paid for mostly by exports of meat and wool. But its economic standing has severely eroded over the past generation, culminating recently in the worst financial crisis in its history.
 After the banking system and currency in neighboring Argentina collapsed nearly three years ago, Uruguay, whose economy was largely driven by that of its much larger neighbor, also went into a tailspin, with the economy contracting by more than 10 percent in 2002. Although Mr. Batlle has been praised by financial experts and foreign diplomats for handling the emergency deftly, the populace blamed him and the Colorado Party for the decline in living standards, in which many people also lost their savings.
 ''We need a change, a complete change,'' said Anabel Puppo, 47, a government employee who said she had always voted for the traditional parties but would cast her ballot for Dr. Vazquez. ''We need jobs, so that my children don't have to leave the country in order to work, and we need someone who won't let thieving bankers walk away with our money.''
 The economy has more recently recovered and may expand by as much as 11 percent this year. But Dr. Vazquez has scored points with voters, promising that his priority will be to ''address the social emergency afflicting Uruguay'' and to seek ''a more equitable distribution'' of the nation's wealth.
 To some, that smacks of pandering and is out of line with the harsh economic realities the country continues to face. ''The left is proposing to build a new future by restoring or reconstructing a past that was much better,'' in economic terms, said Luis Eduardo Gonzalez, director of the Cifra public opinion polling firm and a leading political analyst.
 Dr. Vazquez's coalition is a fractious one, ranging from unreconstructed Communists to European-style social democrats like Senator Danilo Astori, whom Dr. Vazquez has mentioned as his future economic minister in order to reassure the financial markets. To hold the alliance together, some analysts say, Dr. Vazquez has fudged many of his own positions, which will become clear only after he takes office next March and is forced to make hard policy choices.
 Even after two decades of public life, ''Tabare Vazquez is a mystery,'' said Pablo da Silveira, a university professor and prominent political commentator. ''No one knows what he really thinks because he has said everything and its opposite.''
 But at his news conference on Friday, Dr. Vazquez dismissed those objections and said his program was clear. ''We are going to govern for change and govern for the people,'' he said.


GRAPHIC: Photos: Tabare Vazquez, a 64-year-old doctor and a Socialist, needs 50 percent of the vote to avoid a runoff in Uruguay's presidential election today. (Photo by Eduardo Di Baia/Associated Press)
 Jorge Larranaga, the candidate of the centrist White Party, has been moving to the left in the hope of forcing a runoff in the presidential race. (Photo by Andres Stapff/Reuters) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: WAR & CONFLICT (90%); POLITICS (90%); PHYSICIANS & SURGEONS (90%); VOTERS & VOTING (90%); RUNOFF ELECTIONS (90%); LIBERALISM (90%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (89%); REBELLIONS & INSURGENCIES (89%); ECONOMIC POLICY (78%); ECONOMIC NEWS (78%); PLATFORMS & ISSUES (78%); PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS (78%); ECONOMIC CRISIS (78%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); ELECTIONS (78%); BALLOTS (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (77%); INTERVIEWS (75%); HISTORY (74%); TRENDS (74%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (73%); CIVIL WAR (72%); CITY GOVERNMENT (69%); POLLS & SURVEYS (68%); EMBASSIES & CONSULATES (60%) Elections; Election Issues; Banks and Banking; Civil War and Guerrilla Warfare; Economic Conditions and Trends; Social Conditions and Trends; Politics and Government

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 3; Column 1; SundayBusiness; NEWS AND ANALYSIS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 1197 words

HEADLINE: Not as Much Ventured, But More to Gain?

BYLINE: By GARY RIVLIN

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, CALIF. 

 BODY:
WHEN members of the Early Stage Venture Capital Alliance gathered here last month for its annual golf outing, the conversation turned -- as it invariably does when venture capitalists congregate these days -- to the resurgence of fierce competition among firms seeking to invest in promising start-ups. 
 Silicon Valley is again silly with venture capitalists jostling one another to own a piece of any young technology company with a plausible business model. And with this heightened competition comes fear that the exorbitant inflation that hit the venture industry in the late 1990's will return as investors again start throwing millions after the cockamamie and the absurd. 
 So the good news in the venture world last week was the seemingly bad news that venture investing was down in the third quarter -- way down. After five consecutive quarters of robust growth, the research concern VentureOne found, the amount venture capitalists invested fell 15 percent, to $4.6 billion, from $5.4 billion in the second quarter. 
 Other data last week were even more dismal -- or more encouraging, depending on one's perspective. By the calculations of PricewaterhouseCoopers, Thomson Venture Economics and the National Venture Capital Association, the three firms that publish the quarterly MoneyTree Survey, venture investing in the third quarter fell by 26 percent, in dollar terms, from the second quarter. The 601 deals that venture capitalists consummated from July through September were the fewest in any quarter since 1996.
 It is unclear whether this is a sign of real restraint or just a pause in a resumption of the kind of reckless rush that led to the tech bubble and bust, some investors said. But, they added, it is at least a move in the right direction. ''As a venture investor, this is great news,'' said Mitchell Kertzman, a venture capitalist at Hummer Winblad Venture Partners in San Francisco. ''I'd like to see these numbers go down by more. Too much money being invested leads to an undisciplined environment. It leads to bidding wars.'' 
 Mr. Kertzman's view was seconded by more than a half-dozen other venture capitalists, and by Mark G. Heesen, the president of the National Venture Capital Association. ''To be frank, a 25 percent increase in venture investing would be more alarming'' than a steep decline, he said in a statement.
 At the height of the Internet boom, venture firms collectively invested $23 billion to $29 billion a quarter. That figure plummeted to less than $5 billion a quarter by mid-2002 and held steady in the $4 billion range through the third quarter of 2003. But venture investing jumped 36 percent from the fourth quarter of last year to the second quarter this year, to $5.9 billion, the MoneyTree survey showed. That prompted venture capitalists to fret over a return to the crazy days of 1999 and 2000, when hype was high but the return on investment was depressingly low, if not negative. 
 ''In my opinion, the entrepreneurial activity we've seen doesn't justify the increase in the rate of investing we've been seeing,'' said Paul Koontz, a partner at Foundation Capital a venture capital firm in Menlo Park, Calif. ''There just aren't that many great ideas tied to great teams to explain that kind of increase in investment.'' 
 Part of the problem is that while the number of money-making ideas worthy of a venture investment may be limited, there is a chronic overabundance of venture capitalists, left from the boom years when the number of venture firms more than doubled. 
 ''There's just too much money in the market chasing too few deals,'' said John C. Occhipinti, managing partner at the Woodside Fund in Redwood Shores, Calif. A year ago, a start-up considered itself fortunate if one venture firm was willing to cut a check for an ownership stake. Today, Mr. Occhipinti said, ''it's not uncommon to have six or seven or more firms competing on a single deal.''
 Examples abound. Jack Danahy, chief executive of Ounce Labs, a software security start-up in Waltham, Mass., closed on a first round of financing in February. Since then, Mr. Danahy figures that he has heard from 20 venture capitalists interested in investing in future rounds. 
 Steve Baloff, a partner at Advanced Technology Ventures in Palo Alto, Calif., said: ''With areas like security -- areas that are hot -- you have to scratch your head when you see the level of activity there. Why does the world need another 100 security companies when we've already got 800, or something like that?'' He described as ''very good news'' this past quarter's steep decline in investing. 
 Venture capitalists, of course, do not care if their rivals lose money, but they do worry that the tendency to invest in 10 start-ups in a market that can handle no more than one or two companies harms everybody. 
 ''Too many companies in one space diffuses the message and increases the cost of business,'' said Ted Schlein, a venture capitalist at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers in Menlo Park, Calif. ''It used to be you had to spend as much money as your dumbest competitor. We certainly don't want to go back to those days.'' 
 The numbers released last week help quell concerns about a return to those bad old days. But the third quarter is often, though not always, an off quarter for venture investing, because of summer vacations and other distractions.
 ''I'd caution against drawing any conclusions on a single quarter,'' Mr. Kertzman said. According to VentureOne, venture capitalists have invested $15.4 billion in 1,536 deals this year, versus $13.6 billion in 1,492 companies through the first nine months last year.
 ''We're going to see these numbers keep going up and down as everybody tries to figure out if it's safe to get out from beneath their beds and tinfoil hats and invest again,'' said Paul S. Kedrosky, a academic director of the Von Liebig Center for Entrepreneurism and Technology Advancement at the University of California at San Diego. So far, venture capitalists are acting with appropriate caution, added Mr. Kedrosky, who teaches venture capital courses in both the business and engineering schools. ''A bunch of undisciplined people are so far acting with amazing discipline,'' he said.
 THAT caution is evident in data that show that a larger portion of venture money went into first-round deals last quarter than at any time over the last two years. ''To me this says we're seeing a return to fundamental, early-stage, new company starts,'' said Jonathan Feiber, the managing partner at Mohr, Davidow Ventures in Menlo Park, Calif. ''At the same time, we're seeing a fall-off of later-stage funding rounds supporting the myriad of companies created during the bubble.''
 Still, some people worry that evidence of bubble behavior remains. Mr. Koontz of Foundation Capital says that for each company his partnership has financed, another 49 that he and his partners rejected have received financing from rival firms. 
 ''Every day sees more companies that don't deserve it getting funding,'' he said. ''In many ways the discipline that was lost during the crazy bubble days hasn't returned to the venture industry to the degree people think it has.''


GRAPHIC: PhotoChart: ''Investment Wrinkle''Venture investing in the third quarter fell 26 percent from the second quarter. HEADLINE: Want to Profit From Vodka? Follow That Grey Goose

BYLINE: By JIM RENDON

 BODY:
INSIDE one of Manhattan's monuments to vodka consumption, the Pravda bar in SoHo, Mike Lee orders a vodka on the rocks, letting the bartender choose among the esoteric collection of bottles lined up behind the bar. 
 Mr. Lee, 30, a stockbroker, usually drinks expensive vodkas like Belvedere, Chopin or the new Absolut brand, Level. But at Pravda, he can't order those mainstream brands. 
 ''The bartender just rolls his eyes when I ask for one of those,'' he said.
 Those vodkas, and even Pravda's more obscure imports -- like Jewel of Russia and Zubrowka Bison Brand, from Poland -- are gaining popularity as the vodka market grows. Vodka accounted for 26.6 percent of all spirits sold in the United States in 2003, up from 24.2 percent in 1998, according to the Adams Beverage Group. And sales of superpremium brands, those costing $30 a bottle or more, were up 21 percent in 2003 over the previous year, according to the Distilled Spirits Council.
 Distillers would not release specific figures, but high-end vodkas are clearly profitable. ''There is more margin involved for everyone'' for high-priced vodka, said Monsell Darville, vice president and group marketing director at Bacardi, which owns Grey Goose, a French vodka. 
 These vodkas are drawing converts. Mr. Lee used to drink whiskey, but he said that he gradually preferred vodka's cleaner taste and that, after drinking vodka, he usually felt better the next day.
 ''The following day I used to reek of whiskey,'' he said. 
 This high-end market barely existed 15 years ago, when Absolut was alone at the top. Now Absolut, at $20 a bottle, is in the middle of the market. Grey Goose, vodka originally owned by Sidney Frank Importing that sells for $30 a bottle, is now the top-selling high-end vodka. In August, Bacardi bought the brand for a reported $2 billion. 
 Jerald O'Kennard, director of the Beverage Testing Institute, said that new brands were being introduced all the time, and that they were desperate to differentiate themselves. Wyborowa Single Estate is sold in a bottle designed by the architect Frank Gehry. Magazine ads for Level, Absolut's stab at the high end, promote two distillation methods, with no mention of what they are or why they matter. Ciroc, a French vodka, is made from grapes, not potatoes, rye or wheat, as other vodkas are.
 In general, marketing for expensive liquor seems to be paying off. While the entire spirits market grew 3.9 percent from 2002 to 2003, according to the Distilled Spirits Council, superpremium brands grew 11.1 percent.
 When people ''have a cocktail, they want it to be a special occasion,'' said David Ozgo, chief economist at the Distilled Spirits Council. ''There is a certain romance,'' he added, ''to sitting down with a martini glass to have a drink with friends.''
 The lure of the martini glass is what drew Maximilla Lukacs, 27, a filmmaker and musician, and her friend Danielle Devincenzo, 26, a musician and clothes maker, to Pravda. Sitting at the bar, they sipped at yellow and green vodka drinks in frosted martini glasses.
 When they want to drink vodka, this is where they go. But it's not for the vodka itself. Ms. Devincenzo is not normally a vodka drinker. ''I drink Patron,'' she said, referring to a brand of tequila. ''But these drinks are so great. This place makes me want to drink vodka.''
 Marketers strive to present vodka as a versatile liquor that mixes well with just about anything. 
 But that also presents a challenge to distillers. Vodka is often thought of as an essentially flavorless alcohol; in fact, the Code of Federal Regulations defines it as being ''without distinctive character, aroma, taste or color.''
 DISTILLERS have fought this reputation by promoting everything from the ingredients -- select wheat, locally grown rye -- to the distilling process and the kind of water used. Wyborowa Single Estate, for example, is produced with ingredients all derived from the same Polish farm: the rye is grown at the estate, the water pulled from a well there. Mr. Darville strives to link Grey Goose with the culinary history of France, and with what he said was the uncompromising French attitude toward food and drink.
 While the impact of much of this on the vodka itself is debatable, there are basic differences among the brands. The one best known to those who worked their way up to the top shelf the hard way is the afterburn that some vodkas leave when they go down. The burn is usually associated with inexpensive vodkas, which typically use corn as a base for the alcohol, said Robert Plotkin, an author and founder of BarMedia, a beverage consulting firm.
 A vodka's base ingredients are its most defining feature, Mr. O'Kennard said. Potato vodkas tend to be creamy. Wheat vodkas are often sweet. Rye creates a spicy flavor. 
 Yet few people drink vodka straight up, the best way to differentiate among brands. Even at Pravda, where bartenders take pride in the vodkas they pour, the bar menu is a long list of martini-glass concoctions.
 After it is splashed over ice and spun in shakers with three or four ingredients, the vodka itself becomes less important, Mr. O'Kennard said.
 ''If you use these vodkas in a Bloody Mary or a vodka tonic, the subtleties will not show up,'' he said.
 But more and more people feel that it is worth it to spend a few extra dollars on their Bloody Marys anyway.

QUICK READ
Here are some tips for savoring good vodka:

DRINK -- vodka at room temperature not chilled, as most people do said Robert Plotkin, an author and founder of BarMedia, a beverage consulting firm. Chilling a vodka, or drinking it over ice, greatly reduces its flavor.

LET -- vodka breathe for at least five minutes after pouring, Mr. Plotkin said. Smell the vodka. Though it is a subtle drink, he said, it does have a bouquet.

SWIRL -- it over your palette, with your mouth slightly open. After you swallow, be aware of the finish, or aftertaste.

LOOK -- for vodkas that infuse flavors during the distillation process rather than afterward, said Jerald OKennard, director of the Beverage Testing Institute. Infused flavors can have a more natural taste.

DON'T ASSUME -- that vodka has to be very expensive to be good. Mr. O'Kennard's organization does regular taste tests and often finds $12 vodkas that stand up against their $30 competitors. Test results can be found at www.tastings.com.


GRAPHIC: Photo: Anthony Settecase pours one of the 80 types of vodka at Pravda, a bar in SoHo. The popularity of vodka, especially at the high end of the market, has climbed. (Photo by Michael Nagle for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: When We Were Wooed

BYLINE: By JOHN FERLING. 
John Ferling is the author of ''Adams vs. Jefferson: The Tumultuous Election of 1800.''

 BODY:
With the presidential election hanging on the outcome of the vote in eight or so swing states, we're approaching America's quadrennial obsession with the Electoral College. New Yorkers often complain that the Electoral College disenfranchises them because nobody bothers to campaign hard in our reliably blue state. 
 Once, however, New York was a swing state. In the most bitterly contested election of American history -- no, it wasn't in 2000, but in 1800, when Thomas Jefferson ran against the incumbent, John Adams -- New York State, particularly New York City, was the battleground that decided the election. 
 Many of the hallmarks of this year's election were present in 1800. The mudslinging and negative campaigning, for example, included attacks on Adams's foreign policy and Jefferson's war record -- his comfortable lifestyle at Monticello during much of the Revolutionary War and his alleged failure as a wartime governor of Virginia. But there were also significant differences between then and now -- perhaps none more important than that in most states, including New York, presidential electors were chosen by the state legislators rather than by direct popular voting. What's more, each elector cast two votes -- for separate candidates. At the time, the Constitution stipulated that the candidate with the most votes, if those constituted a majority, was to be president. The runner-up became vice president. 
 From the outset in the 1800 election, it was widely presumed that New York's vote would be decisive. With 12 electors, New York had a level of clout that was surpassed only by that of Massachusetts (which was certain to give its votes to Adams) and of two Jeffersonian strongholds -- Virginia and Pennsylvania. Adams had carried New York in 1796 en route to winning the presidency by a scant three electoral votes. His re-election depended on winning the state once again.
 Adams's Federalist Party expected to retain its control of the New York State Legislature -- and, thus, its electoral votes -- in the state elections set for April 1800. Indeed, the Republicans, Jefferson's faction, were so despairing of winning a legislative majority that early in the year they proposed that New York change its method of selecting presidential electors. They sought to have the outcome of the popular vote in each district determine the elector for that district, a device through which the Republicans might pick up one or two of the state's electoral votes. But confident of winning control of the Legislature, the Federalists rejected the proposal. 
 This Federalist Party decision to spurn the popular election of electors was one of the great blunders in the history of presidential campaigns. With New York City providing the decisive vote, the Republicans pulled off a stunning upset that gave them a hairsbreadth majority in the State Legislature. 
 In the race for the State Legislature, two things above all else accounted for the Republican victory in New York City. Aaron Burr -- a New Yorker who had been a United States senator and a state assemblyman -- understood the political system better than most of his contemporaries. He sensed that the city's workers, who historically supported the Federalists, were disillusioned and ripe for a change of loyalty. 
 Burr built a well-oiled party apparatus, one of the first in America. He spoke at street rallies, provided food and lodging for party workers who labored around the clock, and selected a slate of celebrity candidates. On Election Day, he sent party activists into the wards to get voters to the polls -- dispatching German-speakers to neighborhoods inhabited by German immigrants, for instance. The Federalists, led by Alexander Hamilton, did not bother with any of these tactics. 
 Burr, who later joined Jefferson on the Republican slate,was correct about the workers' disenchantment. Many had come to see the Federalists as elitists who refused to shake hands with artisans and who looked down on self-made men. To them, the Federalist Party had become the bastion of conservatives who abhorred participatory politics, upheld social traditionalism and were committed to an economy that favored the wealthy -- a party, in short, committed to blocking the changes that middle- and lower-class Americans had hoped would be realized through the American Revolution.
 In April, the Republicans captured all 12 of New York City's seats in the State Legislature, scoring overwhelming victories in the working-class wards of what were then the upper reaches of Manhattan. Their triumph in the city gave them control of the State Legislature. 
 The first lady, Abigail Adams, wrote to her sons that the Republicans had won because they had ''laid their plans with more skill than their opponents.'' She added that ''N York would be the balance'' in the fall's presidential election. She was right. New York's 12 electors cast all their votes for Jefferson and Burr. Of the votes cast by the 138 electors nationwide, 73 went to Jefferson and 73 to Burr. Adams came in third, with 65. All but one of the remaining votes went to Charles Cotesworth Pinckney, also a Federalist . The outcome -- Jefferson as president, Burr as vice president -- was determined by the House of Representatives. 
 For the first time, a sitting president was turned out of office. For the first time, too, a presidential election turned on artful modern politicking -- in a swing state. As Burr explained to his vanquished opponents: ''We have beat you by superior management.'' 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

PERSON: Thomas (1743-1826) Jefferson; John (1735-1826) Adams; John Ferling

GEOGRAPHIC: NEW YORK, NY, USA (92%) NEW YORK, USA (99%); VIRGINIA, USA (92%) UNITED STATES (99%) New York State

LENGTH: 673 words

HEADLINE: No Pay as You Go

 BODY:
The bottom line on mass transit anywhere is that the masses cannot really pay for it. Government subsidies are necessary to keep buses, trains and subways running -- and it's more than worth it, considering the congestion, air pollution and disruptions to the economy that would come if cars became the only method of getting around.
 All that is especially true in the metropolitan New York area. Riders foot more of the costs here than almost anywhere else in the nation. But if the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is required to pay too much of its own way, commuting by rail or express bus will become too expensive for many riders. Drivers will suffer as well, as the competition for parking and highway space increases and the authority raises its bridge tolls through the roof. 
 Washington, Albany, City Hall and the suburbs will have to pay a fairer share of the costs of getting eight million people to work and back. The authority has been sounding warnings about a $436 million deficit next year, and alerting commuters to service cutbacks and fare increases. That deficit could eventually grow to $1 billion or, according to State Comptroller Alan Hevesi, maybe $2 billion.
 The reason for this deep hole is not hard to figure out. Over the last 25 years, the authority has borrowed lots of money to make the subways and trains cleaner and more efficient -- including, most disturbingly, a monster 2000 bond issue to help finance a $17 billion capital maintenance and expansion program. That New Yorkers now enjoy better mass transit is good for everybody. But the authority borrowed more than it could pay back on its own, and the bill is coming due.
 Officials at the authority are already planning to make sure suburban commuters and city straphangers pay their share -- or more -- of the additional costs. Commuter rail ticket prices could go up by about 5 percent, and so could the prices for E-ZPasses, the tolls on bridges and the costs of daily and monthly MetroCards. At the same time, the authority's leadership is talking about cutting or not replacing thousands of workers, mostly on subway and bus lines, including over 350 employees working on the Long Island Rail Road and almost 200 working for Metro-North. 
 So far, however, there have been few helpful offers from President Bush, Gov. George Pataki, Mayor Michael Bloomberg or the State Legislature. That's unacceptable, given the of mass transit to the state and regional economy. 
 For starters, the city must increase its contribution to the authority. Mayor David Dinkins, facing financial problems, began cutting the city's contribution, and Rudolph Giuliani and Mr. Bloomberg followed suit. Today's city contribution is one-third of what it was 20 years ago. The suburbs should chip in more for maintenance and other improvements, as should the federal government, not least because of the additional burden the system must bear as a prime terrorist target. Washington requires the authority to have bomb-sniffing dogs , shoulder bigger liability insurance premiums and take other measures. The estimated cost is $500 million, and Washington should pay it.
 Then there's the state. Republicans tend to resist offering more money; Democrats tend to resist making the system more efficient. The parties should switch roles. The Legislature, including suburban lawmakers who oppose consolidating rail lines, must help the authority restructure itself and streamline commuter bus lines. 
 Then there's Mr. Pataki. The governor's appointees, who essentially control the authority, have been willing to let the state off the hook. Mr. Pataki likes to be there when there is good news, like a long stretch without fare increases. Now he is arguing that a fare increase should not be necessary -- without, however, taking steps to solve the problems. That won't work. Unless the state provides more help with mass transit's growing debt, any fare increase will land on the governor's watch. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Editorial

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: URBAN TRANSIT SYSTEMS (92%); PUBLIC FINANCE (90%); PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION (90%); LAYOFFS (90%); URBAN BUS SYSTEMS (90%); TRAINS (90%); MOTORCOACHES & BUSES (89%); CITIES (89%); URBAN RAIL SYSTEMS (89%); SUBURBS (89%); CITY GOVERNMENT (89%); US STATE GOVERNMENT (88%); US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2008 (84%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (78%); GOVERNMENT GRANTS & SUBSIDIES (78%); CITY LIFE (78%); PRICE INCREASES (74%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (73%); TRAVEL TICKETS (73%); BRIDGES & TUNNELS (69%); BOND ISSUES (64%); BONDS (64%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (59%); AIR POLLUTION (57%) Transit Systems; Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates); Labor; Layoffs and Job Reductions; Buses; Bridges and Tunnels; Tolls; Railroads; Editorials; Transit Systems; Finances; Subways
